business.start.para: The SPEAKER (Mr Neil Andrew) took the chair at 9.00 a.m., and read prayers.

debate.para: Debate resumed from 19 March, on motion by Mr Howard:
That this House:
(1) condemns Iraq's refusal, over more than 12 years, to abide by 17 resolutions of the United National Security Council regarding the threat it poses to international peace and security;
(2) recognises:

(a) that Iraq's continued possession and pursuit of weapons of mass destruction, in defiance of its mandatory obligations under numerous resolutions of the United Nations Security Council, represents a real and unacceptable threat to international peace and security;
(b) that Iraq's behaviour weakens the global prohibitions on the spread of weapons of mass-destruction, with the potential to damage Australia's security; and

(c) that, as more rogue states acquire them, the risk of weapons of mass destruction falling into the hands of terrorists multiplies, thereby presenting a real and direct threat to the security of Australia and the entire international community;
(3) abhors:
(a) Iraq's continued support for international terrorism; and
(b) the institutionalised widespread and grave abuse of the human rights of the Iraqi people over many years;

(4) notes that United Nations Security Council resolutions adopted under Chapter VII of the United Nations charter, in particular resolutions 678, 687 and 1441, provide clear authority for the use of force against Iraq for the purposes of disarming Iraq of weapons of mass destruction and restoring international peace and security to the region;

(5) endorses the Government's decision to commit Australian Defence Force elements in the region to the international coalition of military forces prepared to enforce Iraq's compliance with its international obligations under successive resolutions of the United Nations Security Council, with a view to restoring international peace and security in the Middle East region;

(6) expresses its unequivocal support for the Australian service men and women, and other personnel serving with the international coalition, our full confidence in them and the hope that all will return safely to their homes;
(7) extends to the innocent people of Iraq its support and sympathy during the military action to disarm Iraq of its weapons of mass destruction and the reconstruction period that will follow; and
(8) notes that the government is committed to helping the Iraqi people, including through humanitarian assistance, to build a new Iraq at peace with itself and its neighbours.
upon which Mr Crean moved by way of amendment:
That all words after “That” be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
“This House:
(1) insists that Iraq must disarm under the authority of the United Nations;

(2) believes that in the absence of an agreed UN Security Council resolution authorising military action against Iraq, there is no basis for military action to disarm Iraq, including action involving the Australian Defence Force;
(3) insists that there should be no commitment of Australian troops to a war in Iraq outside the authority of the United Nations;
(4) concludes that Australian involvement in a war in Iraq without UN authorisation is not in Australia's national interests or in the interests of maintaining international peace and security; and
(5) expresses its confidence in our servicemen and women and our full support for them and their families”.

talk.start.para: —The decision of the Howard government to commit Australian troops to an invasion of Iraq is not only the worst possible decision that could be taken in the current circumstances, it is the worst security and diplomatic decision taken by any Australian government since the end of World War II and the establishment of the United Nations. The pre-eminent issue for this parliament, and our obligation as representatives of all Australians, is national and global security—not Iraq. As one paper editorial pointed out last year:

quote.para: Australians do not need to be persuaded that Saddam Hussein is an evil despot who kills and oppresses his own people and whose regime is a threat to his neighbours. That is true of the leadership of perhaps a third of the world's nations ...

speech.para: Modern terrorism is without doubt the No. 1 security issue. A war with Iraq distorts and dangerously undermines that critical security priority.

It is a disgrace that this government has restricted members of parliament in this debate to half the usual speaking time on a decision which is the most significant any nation can take—to send its citizens to war. That is typical of the Howard style of government. I have previously spoken in this House and outside it against plans for war with Iraq. Because of time restrictions, I will not repeat many of the points I have previously made, although they are relevant today.

This war, without UN support, will worsen national and global security. That view has been expressed by distinguished Australians like General Peter Gration, former Chief of the Defence Force; senior Office of National Assessments analyst Andrew Wilkie, who resigned in protest over this government's push to war; and Ray Funnell, former Chief of the Air Force, who last week said on ABC Radio that what the Prime Minister has done `... is he's followed, almost in lock step a man who has demonstrated ... strategic stupidity. And I refer here to President Bush.'

For the first time in our nation's history, Australia will be the aggressor; invading another nation. This government is subserviently following America on a path of strategic stupidity. Strategic stupidity: that is the damning—and accurate—assessment of one of Australia's most respected and senior military figures, ignored by this Howard government.

In the US, similar concerns have been expressed by General Brent Scowcroft, former National Security Adviser to Republican Presidents Ford and Bush Sr; by General Zinni; by General Clark; and by many senior members of the military and the legislature. Veteran US Senator Edward Kennedy said earlier this month:

quote.para: Surely, we cannot afford to shatter the very coalition we need in order to combat the obviously greater and more imminent threat we face from Al Qaeda and its terrorists ...

Two weeks after 9/11, Secretary Rumsfeld claimed that we had “bulletproof” evidence of the link. But a year later, CIA Director Tenet conceded in a letter to the Senate Intelligence Committee that the Administration's understanding of the link was still “evolving” and was based on “sources of varying reliability.”
In fact, the link is so widely doubted that intelligence experts have expressed their concern that intelligence is being politicized to support the rush to war.
The Bush Administration was wrong to allow the anti-Iraq zealots in its ranks to exploit the 9/11 tragedy by using it to make war against Iraq a higher priority than the war against terrorism.

speech.para: The US Senate's longest serving member, Robert Byrd, has commented:

quote.para: The President is on the wrong track in insisting on rushing into war without the support of the international community, and specifically the United Nations. Not only is America's reputation on the line, but so is our war on terror.

speech.para: Put simply, those who advocate war have failed to present any credible evidence of links between Iraq and terrorists. Liberals who have claimed otherwise think they have better information than the CIA and the US Senate intelligence committee. They should give them a ring. In fact, they are desperately promoting misconceptions and lies to prop up the case for war.

Perversely and dishonestly, this government claims that war with Iraq is needed to provide support for the UN—the same UN that President Bush has badgered, threatened and now ignored. Their logic is that we should support the UN by starting a war that the UN does not support. That is simply idiotic. US Senator Byrd has attacked the Bush administration's diplomacy and this point by saying:

quote.para: The world is now wondering, which is the greater threat to the relevance of the U.N.: a rogue nation that flaunts the will of the international community; or a permanent member of the Security Council that views the institution as useless unless it submits to its will? ... More threats of U.N. irrelevance will only portray the United States as a bully superpower.

speech.para: Air Marshal Funnell made similar comments:

quote.para: If you look back to the 12th September 2001 and the immediate aftermath of that horrific event in New York and Washington, President Bush was leading a nation that was united in a great and deserved cause and he was supported without reservations by the nations of the world and by the UN. And contrast that with today, just 18 months later, his nation is divided, most of the world is against him, alliances are crumbling, multi-national institutions that have been developed over decades are under enormous pressure and how do President Bush and his egregious Secretary of Defence react? They react by trumpeting we don't need any of you.'

speech.para: Ray Funnell continued:

quote.para: Well, I'm sorry, Mr President but you do. I mean, if you want to remain leader of the free world you have to be something more than just a military superpower and a diplomatic bully. Leadership requires more than just telling people what to do or else—but that's the way he goes about it.

speech.para: The sad but inescapable truth is that this push to war without UN support risks undermining the UN itself and the system of international peace and order that Australia, as a middle-ranking power, relies on.

Those who support this war of invasion have even argued that we need to go to war with Iraq to teach North Korea a lesson. Both the Prime Minister and the Minister for Foreign Affairs have used this ploy. I find it frightening that anyone in a position of responsibility could be so shallow and ignorant as to suggest that as a basis for international relations, much less a campaign of war. In fact, what it does is to highlight just how much this war with Iraq distorts our genuine security priorities.

Perhaps most dishonestly, the government now asserts that war is needed on humanitarian grounds to protect Iraqi citizens—Iraqis just like the ones fleeing persecution on the MV Tampa. This government went to extraordinary lengths to deny them the chance to be considered as refugees in Australia. Does anyone really believe that the same government that turned its back on these refugees is now asking us go to war to protect the refugees' brothers and sisters who are still in Iraq? Indeed, these humanitarian concerns have been notably absent from the UN resolutions. They have been injected into the debate in recent weeks by increasingly desperate politicians facing strong opposition from their own people.

If the case for war is so strong, why is it that only three of the 190 nations in the UN have committed troops to it? Why aren't the 30-plus nations who joined together in 1991 to remove Saddam Hussein from Kuwait with us today? Why aren't the Islamic nations who supported the 1991 Gulf War with us today? Why aren't the scores of nations involved in the war against al-Qaeda in Afghanistan with us today? Why aren't our neighbours, who supported the war on terror and who have worked with us so closely both before the Bali bombing and since, with us today? Why aren't the nations of the world—virtually all of whom supported the war on terror following September 11—with us today? How has the Bush administration turned the support and sympathy of the world for America following September 11—including from many of its traditional foes—into open anger and defiance?

Liberal politicians like to dismiss these criticisms by saying that Labor is anti-American. Are they saying that Ray Funnell and Peter Gration are anti-American? Are US Senators Kennedy and Byrd anti-American? Is former federal Liberal Party President John Valder, whom I have quoted in earlier speeches, anti-American? That claim by our opponents is self-evident nonsense and the refuge of those who have nothing but fear and smear to support their case. Instead of sending our troops halfway around the world to invade Iraq, we should be working with our allies and friends in our region and around the globe to deal with terrorists who were responsible for acts such as September 11 and the Bali bombings. That must be our security priority—whether George W. Bush likes it or not.

In the seconds remaining, I want to record my support, and that of my constituents, for our troops. I wish them a speedy and safe return. My heart and best wishes are with them. We know they will perform their duties with courage and valour. Make no mistake, they and their families have our unconditional support. It is those responsible for this war, not our troops, who deserve our criticism.

talk.start.para: —The war party.

—It is this Liberal government and this Prime Minister—as the member for Werriwa said, the war party—who deserve our condemnation, and it is they who will face the anger of an increasingly concerned Australian population.

—The invasion by Australia of another country is the most grave action that this nation can take to oppose that country and its policies. This parliament is asked to support such action, which may begin in three hours time from now. In addressing that question as a parliamentarian, I am conscious of the concerns and representations of my electors. Each of their communications to me—both for and against action—I am personally responding to: as an officer in the reserves of the armed forces of this country, I am conscious of the welfare of our serving men and women and their families; as a proponent in this place 12 months ago of the International Criminal Court, and as a barrister who practised extensively in international law before entering parliament, I am conscious of the importance of the lawfulness of any military strike by Australia; as a parent and husband, I am conscious of the long-term consequences of failure and error; as a representative of the people, I know that I must ultimately act on the basis of what I believe to be the right course. That course is set out in the motion moved by the Prime Minister in the House, and I endorse it.

speech.para: The opposition opposes the motion, but an examination of its amendment shows that it agrees with the government on two fundamental points. First, it agrees that the basic objective for Australia's policy towards Iraq is `that Iraq must disarm'—to quote from the opposition amendment and the government proposal. Second, and for this I am gratified, both sides accept that the Australian service men and women involved in the conflict have the unequivocal support and full confidence of the parliament.

The difference comes down to legal authority. Those opposite claim that only a UN-led force may disarm Iraq. I disagree. In my view, UN authority to disarm Iraq already exists. In 1990, Security Council resolution 678 authorised military action against Iraq. It authorised the use of all necessary means to liberate Kuwait and to restore international peace and security in the area. The military action was spectacularly successful. As a term of the cease-fire, which was expressly requested by Iraq on or shortly after 3 April 1991, Iraq agreed unconditionally to destroy, render harmless and remove all of its chemical and biological weapons. So much is recorded in resolution 687. Similar conditions related to other weapons of mass destruction.

However, Iraq did not disarm. Then, in 1998, we had Operation Desert Fox—the military action by the US and some of its allies against Iraq attempting to enforce disarmament. It was supported in the Australian parliament by the Labor opposition. There was no doubt whatsoever on any side that the legal authority for that action, principally by the Clinton administration, derived from the terms of resolution 678.

In November 2002 a further Security Council resolution, numbered 1441 and passed unanimously, accepted that Iraq was in `serious breach' of its obligations recorded in 16 previous resolutions. That resolution is still in effect today. It means that Iraq has breached the conditions of the 1991 cease-fire. It also means military force to secure the objectives of the UN is authorised. It was true in 1998, and it is true today. It is also commonsense that ignoring basic cease-fire conditions ought not be permitted by any responsible UN member state, nor by the UN itself.

In 1991, it was the Hawke Labor government that decided to join the US-led Operation Desert Storm. It was the Hawke government that accepted the cease-fire and its terms which Saddam has now broken repeatedly. In 1995, when it was necessary to threaten military action against Saddam because of his failure to cooperate fully with weapons inspectors, the Keating Labor government supported that course on the basis I have set out. In 1998, the then Labor opposition, led by the member for Kingsford-Smith, who now so noisily opposes war, strongly endorsed the military action against Iraq on the same basis. Now, when the Howard government prepares to finish the task of disarming Iraq, Labor opportunistically opposes it.

This is Bob Hawke's war, and the coalition is finishing the job he failed to do. It is not the first time that Labor has spectacularly failed Australia's foreign policy interests. It did so over East Timor, when it abandoned the striven people of that country 30 years ago. Only the coalition has the moral courage to do what is right—right for Australia, its people and for the world.

The real position of the opposition is that it has no position. It has manufactured a legal excuse to hide its foreign policy failures and to exploit what it sees is a mass of potential supporters which it supposes is opposed to government policy. Michael Costello, the former chief of staff to the member for Brand, let the cat out of the bag on the ABC last week when he said:

quote.para: This is the simplest international issue I have ever seen. It is clear, uncomplicated, straightforward, the legal authority is there.

speech.para: The ALP has again shown that it is a failed, irrelevant institution and that it will not address the real interests and concerns of the Australian people nor of the world. This debate, if nothing else, proves that the member for Hotham leads a pathetic rabble.

Now let me address the real opposition, the left-wing political establishment in this country which wields such influence in the media and in our educational and professional bodies. These are the members of the postmaterialist left and the cynical left who staff the political desks of some media outlets, some unions and some professional bodies. They are intellectual despots who do not believe in the Australian value of a fair go.

The first attack of this opposition is that the government course lacks all credibility because it is supported only by the USA and the UK. It is hard to think of any other nations I would want to see ourselves allied with more. Our three nations have been beacons of justice and have carried the banner for world peace and international prosperity more than any others. We should be proud to be so allied. But in fact there are 27 additional countries which have joined the coalition to disarm Iraq, and I seek leave to table a list of those countries.
Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I thank the House. Almost all of these countries have been oppressed by dictators and state-imposed terrorist regimes. They know what it is like to feel the heel of a killer like Saddam. There are 15 other nations which have indicated their logistical support, and now even the skittish French, who derailed the UN peace process, have publicly stated that they will support the effort if Saddam uses his ugly weapons of mass destruction.

speech.para: This other opposition attack by alleging that Saddam is not so bad, that what he has done he did in the interests of Baath socialism, and that Australia is just as bad by denying entry to Iraqi refugees fleeing his regime. That latter assertion is incorrect, as the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs has shown in detailed responses in this House. Their argument also fails to address the point that, if Saddam is overturned as a result of his wicked recalcitrance, persecution of Iraqis will cease and that refugees can, if they wish, return home. But, most grossly, it fails to address the horrible record of abuse of human rights in Iraq by Saddam and his nefarious sons, which was set out in the addresses of others in this House, including the member for Bennelong and the member for Higgins.

Another criticism is that this action will invite terrorist activity against Australia. The member for Batman joined this attack, predicting that road transport, ships and trains would be blown up. There is no evidence of this, and the true position is that all Western nations are vulnerable to international terrorists, as is shown by the German nationals blown apart in Tunisia and the French nationals killed in Pakistan. These incidents show why it is necessary for all right-thinking nations to act to make the world a more secure place. Australia cannot escape notice by rolling itself up into a little ball and hoping that the world will not see us. The world changed on 11 September 2001 and, sadly, several of my constituents were reminded of that by the terrorist acts in Bali on 12 October 2002.

We cannot dismiss lightly the possibility, which I believe to be real, that Saddam's weapons of mass destruction could fall into the hands of terrorists. He has a record of supporting financially suicide bombers in Israel, who have wreaked such terrible havoc on so many innocent people, and we know that terrorist cells have operated with immunity in parts of Iraq.

Finally, let me speak of a better future for Iraq and this country's relations with a free Iraq. I look forward, as the result of our action, to a new tradition of Arabic democracy in the Middle East. I look forward to the day when the people of Iraq can enjoy the financial benefits of their oil reserves and wells to increase their standard of living and amenity. I warmly encourage the Iraqi groups in Australia who have contacted me, including the Assyrian Church of the East, with proposals for Australians to lead the humanitarian programs to rebuild Iraq, so that Australia is remembered in that unfortunate country not only as liberators but also for our record of kindness and support. This would be consistent with Australia's great tradition for standing up for the underdog, the weak and the downtrodden. I urge all Australians to move forward with the Australian government in that great endeavour to forge a new Iraq.

talk.start.para: —When I was first considering running for parliament and facing the prospect of sitting in this chamber, the things in my mind were domestic issues: high-quality, affordable health care for all Australians, affordable education, fair and compassionate government services, a just taxation system, support of those in need and concern for my constituents in Chisholm. What I did not dwell on was the prospect of debating the commitment of Australian forces to war. And the first thing that I want to do is to send my best wishes and prayers for the safety of our Australian troops overseas. They have my support and appreciation for their commitment to Australia and their profession as military personnel. My objections to the actions of this government are in no way a reflection on or criticism of Australian service personnel. They do Australia proud.

speech.para: That being said, I do not believe that the government should have committed Australia and, subsequently, Australian troops, to armed conflict. The commitment of Australia to any armed conflict must be a decision of last resort. But that is not the case with the government's actions this week. Diplomacy and actions in which the entire world community are able to act cohesively must be our objective. Unfortunately, the US administration appears to be ignoring world opinion—holding a view that, unless the Security Council agrees with the United States, then the Security Council is wrong.

Over the last few years the US has exercised a number of vetoes while sitting in the Security Council chamber. As a permanent member, it was the right of the US to do so. In fact, six of the last eight vetoes at the Security Council have been exercised by the United States. So the US has no fundamental objection to a veto. Importantly, at no time did the exercise of the veto by the US constitute a failure of the United Nations or a demonstration that its processes were unworkable. The structure of the United Nations Security Council is such that, for any action to be authorised by the council, the concurrence of all five permanent members is required—the five declared nuclear nations. Throughout the history of the United Nations, this has avoided any permanent member using their status to coerce the council into acting against the wishes of any member. This has ensured that Security Council approval for military action is a very high bar to jump—approval is not automatic.

That the Security Council did not accept the draft proposal recently put forward by the US, Britain and Spain indicates that the case for war was not proven. But the current US administration seems to hold a different view when other permanent members are exercising a veto. This had been described as a failure of the Security Council. This is a view that I do not share. I think it critical that every attempt is made to remove weapons of mass destruction from Iraq by peaceful means before considering military conflict. The UN gives us the legal and moral authority to undertake military actions. It shows that the body whose charter is to safeguard world security has collectively reached a decision, with the approval of all five declared nuclear powers, to act in the interest of world security. And, in the absence of such a determination by the members of the United Nations Security Council, further efforts should be put toward diplomatic solutions, such as increased weapons inspections. Instead, the US has committed itself to war.

The disastrous consequence for us here in Australia is that the Prime Minister has, at the behest of US President George Bush—in one lone phone call—also committed us to military conflict. This is not a conflict that we are undertaking to preserve or defend Australia. This is not a conflict that we are undertaking to repel an aggressor of a sovereign nation. This is not a conflict that we are undertaking as a result of a determination of the United Nations Security Council that the world community must act to preserve world peace. This is a conflict we are undertaking because the Prime Minister of Australia was willing to go all the way with the USA and did not even consider Australia's broader interest beyond the US alliance.

In the absence of a UN Security Council resolution, the only reason I can see for Australia to enter armed conflict is if our nation or one of our allies is facing imminent attack. Prior to this action being decided 48 hours ago, Iraq was not, in the foreseeable future, planning to attack either Australia or one of our allies. Neither has Iraq been implicated with the attack in the US on September 11 nor in the bombing of Bali. Australia should not be committing our armed forces to military conflict in Iraq. We should be actively engaging in diplomatic dialogue to reduce both the risk of war and the risk posed by the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction. Iraq does not pose a direct threat to us or our allies. We are not in clear or present danger of attack from Iraq. The Prime Minister's tortured argument that Iraq's weapons pose a threat to us through their possible use by a third party is not logical. If such a potential was the only cause for action, the presence of international weapons inspectors removes the danger. One email I received summed it up nicely. It said:

quote.para: Today in a televised interview Mr Howard asks, “What is the alternative to war?” and in the next news item Chief Weapons Inspector Hans Blix gives him the answer as he expresses his disappointment that the weapons inspections were not given more time and that the “impatience” of some put an end to a process that was working.

speech.para: Indeed, last night Hans Blix yet again addressed the Security Council expressing his disappointment at curtailing a process that was working and had been delivering outcomes.

Australia's interest is served through our strong engagement in multilateral forums such as the United Nations and through our strong support for our alliance with the United States. This is not an anti-US stance. Our support of the UN and our support of the US are not mutually exclusive. We are able to disagree with our friend and ally America while maintaining and valuing the ANZUS treaty. There is nothing that compels us to act, in this case against our national interest, with the US in Iraq. As a good friend we can disagree. Instead, the Prime Minister has chosen to support unilateralism over the collective security that is afforded to Australia through our UN engagement. He has chosen to place Australia and Australians in danger through his commitment to this conflict.

I urge the Prime Minister and all members of his government to rethink this commitment and question deep within themselves whether they genuinely believe this to be in Australia's best interest. I certainly believe the constituencies of all members of this House are also urging them to do just that. I certainly do not, and the majority of Australians do not, support the course of action that the Prime Minister has sent us hurtling down. The majority of Australians are opposed to the government's actions. Yes, Saddam Hussein is a despotic leader, yes he has committed atrocities, and yes he should be disarmed—but not by unilateral aggression. This does not stop terrorism; it in fact gives the green light to other nations to say, `Aggression is okay. You just mount a supposedly logical argument and you can embark on a unilateral action; you can invade another nation-state.' Terrific: India and Pakistan can now have a legitimate war over the disputed territories of Kashmir—both countries with nuclear weaponry. We give the green light to South Korea or North Korea to decide to embark on military conflict. Who next? What next?

Where is the voice of reason from the Liberal Party? Where is the spirited defence of the sanctity of human life from those opposite in the chamber? We have heard nothing but silence. Not even a lone voice has been heard in dissent from the backbench in respect of the Prime Minister's stance. I despair at the lack of individualism shown by the defenders of free choice in the government. Where is the doubt, the concern and the understanding of their constituents' views? They have been silenced in defence of an indefensible act.
I trust our service personnel are quickly and safely returned to their loved ones in Australia. I condemn the actions of this government.

talk.start.para: —This motion commits our troops to disarming Iraq, by force if necessary. It is the weightiest motion to have come before this House in a very long time. The resort to force, with its risks and the prospect of casualties, both civilian and military, is something that everyone in this House abhors. For a considerable period we all hoped that this would not come to pass, and that a peaceful resolution would be achieved. It is a cause of immense distress that these hopes have been dashed.

speech.para: Many elements come together to precipitate a commitment to military action, but the fundamental element here is Iraq's refusal to rid itself of weapons of mass destruction. Under the 1991 cease-fire that brought an end to Iraq's war of aggression, and the terms of which were incorporated in UN Security Council resolution 687, Iraq unconditionally committed to the destruction of its weapons of mass destruction. The succeeding 12 years have seen nothing less than a sustained resistance by the Iraqi government to all international efforts to enforce UN resolution 687. Despite every United Nations sanction and every incentive for compliance, Iraq remains in substantial breach of its obligations to unconditionally remove, destroy or render useless all of its chemical and biological weapons, and to fully declare and verify this.

Such has been the success of Iraq's resistance that noncompliance has come to be seen as the norm. The reality is that without the commitment of the Bush and Blair administrations at the Security Council, and the massing of forces on the Iraqi borders, there would have been no readmission of weapons inspectors. And despite the massing of such forces Iraq has still not accepted the need to fully disarm. As chief weapons inspector Blix reported to the United Nations in January:

quote.para: Iraq appears not to have come to a genuine acceptance—not even today—of the disarmament, which was demanded of it and which it needs to carry out to win the confidence of the world and to live in peace.

speech.para: In recent months the limited success that the weapons inspectors who have re-entered Iraq have had is not due to any sudden Iraqi conversion. As Dr Blix said in his March report:

quote.para: It is obvious that, while the numerous initiatives, which are now taken by the Iraqi side with a view to resolving some long-standing open disarmament issues, can be seen as `active' or even `proactive', these initiatives 3-4 months into the new resolution cannot be said to constitute `immediate' cooperation.

speech.para: It is a cause of great regret that the commitment to forcibly disarm Iraq has been made without a further resolution in the Security Council. This further resolution is something that I, and a large number of others, believed to be desirable and that could contribute to Iraq's peaceful disarmament. But, although united on the need to disarm Iraq, the Security Council was unable to agree on a further resolution. There will be a variety of explanations for this manifest breakdown in diplomacy, and some have expressed the fear that this spells the end of the United Nations' relevance. But the United Nations is a complex and robust institution with enormous capacities. It is in all our interests that it be sustained and strengthened. The role of the United Nations in the reconstruction of Iraq has been foreshadowed, and the fact is that the authority for the use of force does rest on existing United Nations Security Council resolutions.

The legal basis for the authority to forcibly disarm Iraq is succinctly set out in the UK Attorney-General's statement, and at rather greater length in the joint advice to the Australian government by the Attorney-General's Department and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. Resolution 678 of 1990 authorised member states `to use all necessary means to uphold' the demand that Iraq quit Kuwait `and all subsequent relevant resolutions and to restore international peace and security in the area'. The cease-fire conditions embodied in resolution 687 of 1991 bound Iraq to disarm itself of weapons of mass destruction. Resolution 1441 of 2002 found Iraq to be in material breach of its disarmament obligations but gave Iraq a final opportunity to comply with those obligations. Continuing noncompliance has reactivated the authorisation contained in resolution 678 for member states to use all necessary means to achieve Iraq's compliance.

On the issue of unilateral action, it is important to put on the record the judgment of Dr Michael Costello, an incisive critic of American doctrines of unilateralism and pre-emptive war. Dr Costello has said:

quote.para: ... it's action that's authorised by the resolution of 1990, ... so in that sense it's not unilateral action ... ... ...
... if we support the multilateral system, we should urge the UN to do this and even if they don't vote there's legal authority to do it and we should insist that its decisions are implemented.

speech.para: Iraq, under its leader Saddam Hussein, maintains an abhorrent system that represses, murders and persecutes its population. There are many such regimes and rulers throughout the world. But, as I have said previously, there is no prerogative under international law to remove such governments at will. There are arguments that Iraq should have been given more time to comply with the United Nations, and some have argued that, even without compliance with United Nations resolutions, the containment of Iraq could continue indefinitely. But the reality that is now transparent is that the Iraqi leadership will not disarm peacefully. Iraq has displayed no intention of doing this—not in the face of 17 Security Council resolutions, not in the face of international sanctions, not in the face of international condemnation, and not in the face of the threat of force. Resiling now in the face of enduring Iraqi intransigence would undermine international stability and embolden terrorists and extremists. And, as the Prime Minister has said, if we do not deal with rogue states acquiring weapons of mass destruction, the chances of such weapons falling into the hands of terrorists and being used by them against us inevitably increases.

As I have said, disarming Iraq of weapons of mass destruction is the cause for military action against Iraq. I deeply regret that, inevitably, military action to achieve this risks bringing suffering to innocent people. I sincerely hope that this will be limited. But so appalling is the character of the Iraqi government, and its repression and murder of the people of Iraq, that the use of force to disarm Iraq carries with it the prospect that in the future the suffering of the Iraqi people will be greatly relieved and their human rights secured.

I know that, just as there is not consensus in the international community about action on Iraq, neither is there unanimity in the Australian community. This reflects the very difficult nature of this problem. There is disagreement between the parties. But despite these differences on policy, we do need to unite and I believe we are all uniting in support of the Australian troops who are deployed in the Persian Gulf. I voice the sentiments of countless others in wishing our forces a safe, short and successful mission. Our thoughts are with them and their families.

I want to acknowledge the concerns that have been expressed to me by constituents of the Kooyong electorate and others. Inevitably, they will not all agree with what I have said on this subject, but I would like them to know that I have taken their concerns into account and I have not come to my position lightly.

Many commentators anticipate that any armed conflict will be brief. I hope that these anticipations prove correct. Rebuilding and stabilising Iraq, however, will be a burden that the international community will have to carry in the longer term. The people of Iraq will need not just immediate and wide-ranging humanitarian aid, but also substantial support and assistance in the years to come. The rebuilding of Iraq will be a responsibility that the international community should not shirk. I commend the motion to the House.

talk.start.para: —We are now in the final countdown to war. In a few hours the clock will tick down on George Bush's ultimatum. Shortly thereafter, the killing will begin. We will see the beginning of an overwhelming military offensive. This will be the most intense and ferocious bombing campaign in history, designed in the words of the US military to shock and awe Iraq into submission.

speech.para: Much has been made of the advances in military technology since the 1991 Gulf War. The US military certainly have many more so-called smart bombs—weapons that will supposedly focus the attack on the Iraqi military and Saddam Hussein's regime. As in 1991, we will see selected video images of the attacks, but this time they will be displayed at the US Central Command headquarters on the very latest plasma TV screens on a set designed by a leading Hollywood producer. As in 1991, the US will make a big effort to sanitise the conflict, to make it clean and presentable on prime time television news bulletins, but on the ground it will be the same story—the same horror of countless wars and conflicts through history. Many people will die. They will die horribly, ripped apart by high explosives, crushed by debris, burnt to death or killed in countless other ways. In the aftermath of war, there will be many more casualties—deaths caused by the breakdown of Iraq's medical, sanitation and food distribution systems.

None of us can predict the death toll of civilians from the forthcoming bombardment of Iraq. But the warning of a bombing campaign that will shock and awe makes it likely that direct casualties will be numbered at least in the thousands. The US and UK ground forces committed to this campaign are comparatively modest, and there will be a very heavy reliance on air power. If the Iraq military, especially Saddam Hussein's Republican Guard, manage to make a stand in the urban areas of Baghdad, the US will face a choice between the risk of high casualties among their own troops or applying massive firepower from a distance with the certainty of heavy civilian casualties. Given the US determination to minimise their own casualties, innocent Iraqi civilians, themselves the victims of Hussein's brutal dictatorship, may well pay a terrible price.

As I have said, no-one knows what the final toll will be but some indication of the potential humanitarian crisis is given by a strictly confidential United Nations planning document, first reported in the London Times newspaper on 23 December last year. This document has since become publicly available on the Internet but has received surprisingly little publicity. Dated 10 December 2002, the UN analysis of likely humanitarian scenarios was written to assist UN contingency planning for the event of an attack on Iraq. The document focuses on the humanitarian consequences of a range of anticipated military scenarios. Based on World Health Organisation estimates, it forecasts that as many as half a million people could require medical treatment to a greater or lesser degree as a result of direct injuries or indirect effects, including the spread of disease. The UN assessment forecasts that Iraqi medical supplies will be completely inadequate and that casualties will be exacerbated by the likely absence of a functioning primary health care system in a post-conflict situation.

The UN analysis points out that the damage to Iraq's electricity network will severely reduce water and sanitation services and that nearly 40 per cent of Iraq's highly urbanised population will need to be provided with potable water. Also, a potentially high number of indirect casualties may arise from the assessment that `the outbreak of disease in epidemic if not pandemic proportions is very likely'. The UN further warns that the nutritional status of some 3.03 million people countrywide will be dire and that they will require therapeutic feeding, according to UNICEF estimates. The UN estimates that there will eventually be some 900,000 Iraqi refugees requiring assistance, of which 100,000 will be in need of immediate assistance. An estimated two million people will require some assistance with shelter. It is anticipated that the UN High Commissioner for Refugees will initially be unable to provide required support for the 130,000 refugees already in Iraq.

Significantly, the UN assessment also rejects comparisons with the comparatively positive humanitarian outcome of the 2001 Afghanistan attack, given Iraq's high level of urbanisation and the fact that international sanctions over the past decade have produced a situation in which 60 per cent of Iraq's 16 million people have no other means with which to provide for essential requirements other than monthly government food rations. One can only hope that these grim assessments prove to be overly pessimistic. I hope so, for tragically the die is now cast.

When I spoke in the last debate on this matter I argued that an attack on Iraq without the explicit authorisation of the United Nations Security Council would be contrary to international law. Nothing the government have said since has changed my view. Their arguments for the legality of what is about to happen have been quite unconvincing. Moreover, they have conspicuously failed to explain why a continuation of UN inspections could not achieve the objective of verifying the elimination of Iraqi weapons of mass destruction capabilities. There was another path to be taken today: the path of diplomacy, backed by a unanimous Security Council. That could have secured a peaceful outcome. Instead, for their own reasons, George Bush, Tony Blair and our own little Prime Minister, John Howard, have chosen the path of war.

The Prime Minister has committed Australia to an unnecessary war. He has committed our nation to a war contrary to international law. He has committed us to a war of aggression. The Prime Minister has committed us to a war that may well result in the slaughter of many thousands of innocent Iraqi civilians. When the bombing begins in a few hours, the early images will be sanitised. We will probably not see much of what is happening on the ground, but terrible things will be happening. Maybe, down the track, we will see some of that horror. When we do, no-one should forget our Prime Minister's personal responsibility. The Prime Minister will have blood on his hands, and no amount of public relations spin will ever wash it off.

I am of Lebanese descent. Through the seventies, eighties and early nineties I watched the television images coming out of Lebanon as it was ravaged by civil war. Hundreds of thousands of people were killed during that civil war. Lebanon is rebuilding today. What shocks me is the arrogance of the American President, the British Prime Minister and the Australian Prime Minister, and their simplistic, Anglophile view of the world. This war they have committed us to will do nothing to defeat terrorism. It will engender resentment in the Arab world—not because of support for Saddam Hussein but because of the way this war has been engineered. This Prime Minister and the American President have walked to the beat of the drums of war from the very beginning. This is the outcome they have sought from the beginning. Quite frankly, there is only one way to prosecute the removal of Saddam, and that is through the international community and the United Nations. That should have been the way we went. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Twelve years have passed since Iraq agreed to accept unconditionally, under international supervision, the destruction, removal or rendering harmless of its weapons of mass destruction, ballistic missiles with a range of over 150 kilometres, and related production facilities and equipment. The agreement provided for the establishment of a system of ongoing monitoring and verification of Iraq's compliance with the ban on these weapons and missiles. Iraq had to make a declaration, within 15 days, of the locations, amounts and types of all such items. They were the terms of Security Council resolution 687 of 3 April 1991. Twelve years later we are still trying to ascertain just how little of that commitment has been fulfilled.

speech.para: Resolution 1441 said that, if Iraq did not comply as it was required to do previously, action could be taken to make sure it did. So there is no question about the legality of the action that is going to be taken by the so-called coalition of the willing. The fact of the matter is that Saddam Hussein's regime poses a threat to international peace. It poses a threat in terms of terrorism. It has in its possession weapons of mass destruction, a fact which has been clearly evidenced by the inspectors who have gone into Iraq over the past few weeks. They have shown that the resolution Iraq accepted all those years ago has still not been fulfilled. I am sure that those people—and there are some—who write to me and demonstrate to say that they do not wish action to be taken, and who use the word `peace', have good hearts and speak with sincerity. But we have to learn from the lessons of history. We have to learn from what happened when people said that we did not want to take action, because we wanted peace—peace at any price.

We learnt from World War II what happened when the opportunity was there in 1936 for Baldwin and the Allies to go in after Hitler went into the Rhineland. That opportunity was not taken. There was an attempt then at appeasement. There were the famous words of Neville Chamberlain, who came back to London a hero: that war had been averted. It was only the condemnation of history that showed him to be the ultimate sell-out. He ceded the Sudetenland and then saw Hitler take the whole of Czechoslovakia, followed pretty rapidly by Austria. The world said, `Well, the Austrians agreed to it.' It then escalated, and country after country fell. Six million Jews were put to death in concentration camps. Hundreds of thousands of Allied troops laid down their lives to fight for freedom. Untold millions of lives were destroyed. That could have been averted if action had been taken sooner. About Cambodia the world said, `We want peace; we do not want to intervene,' and Pol Pot murdered three million people.

So there are lessons of history to be learned and they tell us that it is necessary to take this action now. I believe President Bush has shown great courage. It is written that action was not taken in 1936 because public opinion in the countries concerned wanted peace and would not have been with their leaders. Strong leadership at that stage was just not there. It was not there until Mr Churchill finally came to the fore. It has not been easy to make these difficult decisions. It has not been easy for our Prime Minister. It has not been easy for members of the government to come to the conclusion that this is a necessary thing.

Those people who talk about what war will bring—the death of millions—forget that death is the instrument of rule used by Saddam Hussein now. People who say, `Let's not go to war,' forget that thousands and thousands of Iraqis have already been killed by Saddam Hussein. Are their lives to count for nothing? The fact of the matter is that death is happening in Iraq now. This is the man, Saddam Hussein, who used mustard gas—the gas that many countries abhorred and refused to use in World War I because it was just so dreadful. This is the man who used it in the Iraq-Iran war, and 20,000 casualties resulted when a combination of mustard and sarin gases was used. This is the man who gassed 5,000 Kurdish people within Iraq, using gases and weapons of mass destruction. This is the man who would use a murderer's intimidation against individuals to make them toe the line. It is not a question of there being no killing. It is not a question of the people of Iraq being free from what flows from war. Already there is death, suffering and torture under the hands of the man against whom this war will be prosecuted.

I hear it often said, and I will join with those who say it: `War is not something anyone looks forward to. It is used when there is no other alternative available.' I have heard people on the other side of the chamber argue that there is an alternative available—that there should be more diplomatic exchanges. But those diplomatic exchanges have not worked. We have heard the words of France. I am very pleased to say that France does not speak with a single voice. Chirac does not speak for all Frenchmen. It was with a sense of pride that I read the words of my friend Pierre Lelouche, who was a former adviser to Chirac and who himself is now a deputy in the French parliament. He is a member of the centre-right party, the UMP. He is reported to have said:

quote.para: The US is already legally empowered to go to war against Iraq because of Resolution 1441.

speech.para: He went on to say:

quote.para: Here is a world where terrorists can get hideous weapons—it is up to the leaders of the West to protect their people.

speech.para: Bernard Kouchner, the founder and president of Medecins sans Frontieres and a former leader of the interim UN administration in Kosovo, said:

quote.para: The removal of Hussein is the primary concern ... What is worse ... is leaving in place a dictator who massacres his people. I wish people would actually listen more to the ones most threatened by all this, the Iraqi people who are subjugated by this dictatorship.

speech.para: So the words do come from a wide range of people. The support is there, but it is the strength of leadership that is needed at this time. It is not easy to make a decision when there are many people who express and legitimately use their freedom of speech in this country. If they tried to do a similar thing in Iraq they would certainly be imprisoned or worse. In this country you are free to make your point of view heard, but it takes the strength of leadership to determine that it is in the national interest to take a particular course of action when there is a loud voice expressing a contrary view.

In supporting the motion as moved by the Prime Minister, I do so knowing that the coming times are going to be difficult and that there will be voices raised against the action that we are taking, but hopefully not against our troops who will be serving in those lands—our splendid troops, who will fight valiantly in the name of Australia. For those people who say we should have an independent foreign policy, I say we do have one. Australia has always been fiercely independent but she has always been a nation who has chosen to take part when the international community is at risk—as well as taking part in our own interests. We will always do that, because that is the nature of the Australian people. Peace at any price was proven in World War II to be too great a price to pay. By taking action now I believe that the world will be spared seeing terrorists being supplied with weapons of mass destruction from Iraq and that we will see a greater degree of peace possible in the world—real peace, and not peace at any price.

talk.start.para: —I cannot start my comments without making one remark in relation to the contribution by the member for Mackellar. She is pleased that the French President apparently does not speak for all of France. I am pleased that the Australian Prime Minister does not speak for all of Australia.

speech.para: The time is 10 o'clock. All over Australia children are in playgrounds, classrooms, child-care centres or happily playing in their homes. Iraqi children will not have that same chance for that same experience today, and we are part of the reason that they will not. In Iraq it is about 3 a.m. It is predicted that the invasion of Iraq will commence in the next few hours. Some 41.1 per cent of the Iraqi population is under the age of 14; five million young boys and 4.8 million young girls will no doubt have learned by now that Australia is just one of a handful of nations prepared to drop bombs on them. Today we make war on children.

This government would have you believe that we make war to improve the lives of Iraqis. We bomb them, apparently, in order to protect them. Let us look for a moment at the raft of excuses this government would give us in order to justify this action. It talks about regime change—that we must protect the Iraqi population from the terror of Saddam Hussein. The foreign minister has questioned this side's level of condemnation of Saddam Hussein. My view, and that of those on this side, is abundantly clear. Saddam Hussein's disregard for human rights stands condemned, as does his use of chemical weapons and torture against his own people. There are currently 800,000 displaced people within Iraq and 750,000 living in neighbouring countries. We abhor what this appalling dictator stands for, just as we abhor the actions of those who created and armed him. But this government cannot have it both ways. It cannot claim to be supportive of Iraqi people who are victims of cruel and violent oppression on one hand and then deny them refugee status on the other. The thing that appals me the most is that members of the government actually believe that the casualties that will occur over the next few days will be worthy sacrifices. Whether you die at the hands of a dictator or at the hands of an invader, you are still dead.

The Prime Minister would have us believe that he is acting in accordance with United Nations wishes. If that is the case, call a vote; get a directive, because there is not one in existence now. Resolution 1441 does not contain an automatic trigger for war. A single nation should not take on the role of the world's policeman. How long will it be now before another nation believes it has the right to play that role? The authority of the United Nations must be upheld. The two world wars of the last century were tragic conflicts. The Second World War, in particular, eventuated in part because the nations of the world did not allow the League of Nations to be effective. Since 1945 the United Nations has been allowed to play a significant role not only in ensuring world peace but also in calling rogue nations and leaders to account. As a result, we enjoyed in the second half of the last century a relatively strong period of peace. Australia ought not to be a country that is leading the charge to diminish the authority of the United Nations. In doing so, we diminish only ourselves.

The Prime Minister and his government would have us believe that Iraq is responsible for the threat of terrorism that we now face. In fact, the Special Minister of State, on ABC radio this week, claimed that `there are a lot of indications' linking the 11 September terrorist attacks with Iraq. That is not true. There is no evidence of such a link. Al-Qaeda has stated its opposition to Arab states such as Iraq. Lord Douglas Hurd, former British Conservative Foreign Secretary, has posed the following questions:

quote.para: Do we help or hinder this essential struggle against terrorism by attacking Iraq ... Would we thus turn the Middle East into a set of friendly democratic capitalist societies ready to make peace with Israel, or into a region of sullen humiliation, a fertile and almost inexhaustible recruiting ground for further terrorists ...

speech.para: Robert Higgs of the US Independent Institute has noted such simplistic interpretations of the ease of changing the nature of governments in the region, saying:

quote.para: The sheer preposterousness of this expectation suggests that it is fueled more by quasi-religious zealotry than by logic and evidence.

speech.para: We cannot, however, now underestimate the risk of terrorism on our own shores as a result of our aggressive action. This threat to Australia is one of the justifications given by the government for our involvement, yet the Prime Minister is unwilling to fess up to the Australian people about whether there is in fact any increased threat to our national security. There is probably little doubt that our actions in joining this unjust war will have that effect. An increased threat to our national security may thus be an outcome of our involvement, but not necessarily a reason for it.

The Prime Minister has often relied on the disarmament of Iraq's weapons of mass destruction as justification for this invasion. I support this disarmament but I firmly believe, as does the United Nations, that there are still peaceful mechanisms available to bring this about. The Prime Minister has focused his most recent remarks on an attempt to convince our nation that the opposition do not care for our troops. I am offended and outraged that he would make such an allegation and play such filthy politics with the families of our service people. I, like all members, have a very special respect for our service personnel. We support our troops. We do not believe they should be there but we know who is responsible for this terrible decision. It is not them; it is the leader of this nation. If Australian lives are lost, and I fervently hope that that will not be the case, how will this Prime Minister explain to the families—to the parents, children and partners—that their loved ones were injured or died in a war and in a country that they did not have to be in. There are consequences of committing our troops to war, and the Prime Minister must be held responsible for them. If the Prime Minister is so concerned about the welfare of our troops, he must release the results of the Gulf War veterans health study. He is sending these young men and women into an area without informing them what the health risks are. I understand that this report has been sent to him. He now has a duty to make this information public.

Let us now consider the role played in this conflict by the existence of oil. Some officials have argued that Iraqi oil should be considered spoils of war. The Council on Foreign Relations has counselled that oil revenues must be used for the Iraqi people, lest they believe that this action was taken for imperialist rather than disarmament reasons. One of the most telling comments comes from Rupert Murdoch, quoted in America's Fortune magazine:

quote.para: ... the whole world will benefit from cheaper oil which will be a bigger stimulus than anything else ...

speech.para: And he made this comment, quoted in the Bulletin magazine:

quote.para: The greatest thing to come out of this for the world economy, if you could put it that way, would be $[US]20 a barrel for oil. That's bigger than any tax cut in any country.

speech.para: Concern about government information provided on the justification for this war is not limited to the Australian people. Henry Waxman of the US Congress wrote to the President this week. He said:

quote.para: In the last ten days ... it has become incontrovertibly clear that a key piece of evidence you have cited regarding Iraq's efforts to obtain nuclear weapons is a hoax. What's more the CIA questioned the veracity of this evidence. This is a breach of the highest order and the American people are entitled to know how it happened.

speech.para: I also call upon our Prime Minister to be honest about the reasons for this war.

History has taught us that a combined and unified approach by the nations of the world is the best recipe for peace. That is why this aggressive action by a few nations is so dangerous. Our involvement speaks volumes about our place in the world. It speaks volumes about how our Prime Minister views our role. He has cast us as a vassal nation to the United States. We are not going to war because of the Prime Minister's concern about the humanitarian violations of the Iraqi government. We are not going to war because Iraq was responsible for September 11. We are not going to war for the purpose of disarmament. We are not going because we as a nation have been directly attacked or even threatened. We are going to war because our Prime Minister has neither the courage nor the conviction to say no. He cannot resist the call from Air Force One; he cannot resist his favoured friendship with the United States President. I ask the Prime Minister a question. When the president of another country rings him and asks him to jump to their needs, is his answer, `How high?' That is certainly how the Australian people feel now. This war is being cast not as an invasion but as some form of entertainment for the masses—some form of populist reaction.

talk.start.para: —That is disgraceful.

—Actually, Minister, I think you and your government are disgraceful and so do most of the Australian people. A White House official was quoted in the Daily Telegraph on Saturday. He spoke about the impending war with a sense of excitement. I hope you listen to this, Minister. I hope you read these things. The official said:

quote.para: Boom, we're going in hard and fast. This time next week, sit by your TV and watch the fireworks.

speech.para: I hope that members of this government who sit with their popcorn and their soft drink to watch the `fireworks' of the war on TV this afternoon will stop enjoying the entertainment long enough to picture exactly what the children of Iraq will be seeing and thinking—that is, if their televisions are still working. It is perhaps a faint hope that their world maps—like the US ones—won't have Australia on them. This is not entertainment for the masses; this is the invasion of a sovereign nation. This is where we kill children in order to protect them. This government stands condemned.

talk.start.para: —On Tuesday, 18 March the Prime Minister announced to the nation and to this parliament that the Australian government had authorised the defence forces of this country, currently deployed in the Persian Gulf, to contribute to any military campaign that might arise for the purpose of disarming Iraq of its weapons of mass destruction. As a member of the Australian parliament, I wish to place on record formally my support for the Prime Minister and the government in its decision to make available the armed services of our nation to join the coalition forces that are seeking to disarm Iraq.

speech.para: As the federal member for Ryan—where I have lived for over 22 years, and which I have the tremendous privilege of representing in this great democratic chamber—it is important that I explain the basis of my support for the government's decision. It is important I do this because I understand that many of my constituents do not agree with the government's policies on Iraq. It is all the more important I do this given that we live in a democracy and members of parliament are accountable to the people they represent.

In seeking to understand why Australia's defence forces today stand on the brink of military engagement in the gulf, it is essential to examine the dynamics of global politics two years into the 21st century. For almost half a century following the end of the Second World War the Cold War defined the conduct of almost every nation on earth and the boundaries of global politics. Countries and alliances existed according to whether they stood on the side of the Soviet-led communist bloc or the American-led Western alliance. Today, however, the Cold War is no more. The collapse of the Soviet Union, the fall of the Berlin Wall and the unification of Germany shattered the bipolar world order that emerged from the ashes of World War II.

Today the gravest threat to international stability in this post Cold War world is not the threat of nuclear confrontation between two superpowers but instead brutal, barbaric and indiscriminate acts of terrorism. Today the gravest threat to the communities, economies and values of pluralist nations and free peoples everywhere is the evil shadow of indiscriminate terrorism. We live in what might now be called the age of global terrorism. The almost unimaginable acts of terror that were committed on 11 September 2001, when two hijacked American passenger planes were forced to crash into the two World Trade Centre towers in New York, heralded a chilling new world order that few could have predicted in its true and deadly form. Closer to home, we are all familiar with the devastating and cowardly act of terrorism that was committed at the Sari nightclub in Bali in October 2002, which saw the tragic loss of hundreds of innocent lives. The devastating loss of life and the manner in which it took place has also dealt a shattering economic blow to the people of Bali and Indonesia.

The clear lesson for our country, and indeed for all nations, is that terrorism can strike at any time and in any place without warning. No longer are acts of terrorism merely evil acts that occur in remote and far off places. They are very real in both their evil purpose and close proximity. This is the new character and dynamics of international relations in the post Cold War world. Global and strategic politics in the 21st century is now defined in different and more frightening ways.

In this age of irrational and evil global terror that now prevails the possession of weapons of mass destruction by any rogue state or any despotic individual is clearly an unacceptable risk to the order and security of civilised countries. It is clearly a risk that is unacceptable to the future peace and prosperity of countries like Australia, Britain and the United States—and indeed to the entire free world. Where Iraq fits in is that under Saddam Hussein Iraq is one country that actually possesses these weapons of mass destruction together with biological and chemical weapons. Saddam Hussein also has a track record of using them. He will use them again. He must, therefore, be disarmed. It is worth quoting the words of the British Prime Minister, Tony Blair. He stated:

quote.para: I defy anyone to say that this cruel and sadistic dictator should be allowed any possibility of getting his hands on chemical, biological and nuclear weapons of mass destruction.

speech.para: These are the words of a very courageous Prime Minister. Those who continue to talk of giving peace and diplomacy a chance clearly do not understand the background and history of this issue. They also clearly do not understand the kind of man Saddam Hussein is or what he is capable of doing.

Saddam Hussein has a history—a track record—of using tools of terror against his own people and against sovereign neighbours. This is a brutal dictator who led his country in war for eight senseless years against Iran. This is a brutal dictator who systematically rapes, tortures and murders his own citizens. This is a brutal dictator who led his country, in August 1990, into a senseless and unprovoked invasion of Kuwait, which led to the international community's endorsement of resolution 678, passed on 28 November 1990, that authorised a UN-led military eviction of Iraqi forces from Kuwait. Following the successful eviction of Iraqi forces from Kuwait, the UN passed resolution 687 that provided the guidelines for a withdrawal of UN forces. A central feature of resolution 687 was that Iraq comply with the international community's demands that Iraq abandon its weapons of mass destruction. Resolution 687 also pointed very clearly to the fact that weapons of mass destruction posed a substantial and real threat to the region's peace and security. More than a decade later, together with resolution 1441, this still remains the legitimate foundation for any effort to disarm Iraq.

It is 12 years now since resolutions were passed at the UN in New York demanding Iraq's disarmament. Yet Iraq continues to possess those weapons of mass destruction and continues to flout the diplomatic goodwill and initiatives of the international community. It is 12 years since the world first offered Saddam Hussein's brutal regime the opportunity to turn its back on external aggression and violence. Every effort has been made through 17 UN resolutions, stretching over a decade, and countless diplomatic initiatives to disarm Iraq and embrace its people. Does anyone seriously believe that an 18th UN resolution and another week could make a difference? In short, diplomacy has been tried and it has failed. The time to use force is now. History has demonstrated that diplomacy alone does not achieve results against dictators where there is no credible threat to use military power.

Saddam Hussein is a brutal dictator who has already ignored over a decade of international diplomacy that strove to embrace Iraq and give its people hope of a better future. He is a leader who has totally ignored every act of goodwill and encouragement that has flowed from the corridors of the United Nations in New York and the foreign offices of many countries. Diplomacy has been given a chance. Indeed, diplomacy and statecraft have been given every chance to deliver results, and none have been forthcoming.

All Australians will appreciate that the decision to commit a nation's forces to military conflict is without doubt the most serious that any government can ever make. There must, therefore, be absolutely compelling and just reason for the calling of these armed services, especially where they are called to impending conflict in an overseas theatre. In my judgment there is compelling and just reason for Australia's participation in the coalition forces assembled to confront Iraq. There are other European countries involved—Denmark, Holland, Italy, Poland and Spain—as well as Asian powers such as Japan and Korea. There are some 30 countries in all that have signed up to the coalition determined to disarm Iraq.

In conclusion, I want to convey in this chamber to the soldiers, sailors and airmen of the Australian Defence Force serving in the gulf the very best wishes from the people of my electorate of Ryan. I know that the thoughts and prayers of all Australians will be with the young men and women of the Australian Defence Force serving in the gulf. Those who choose voluntarily to serve their country by wearing a military uniform are the very best our country has to offer. They are courageous in character, generous in substance and patriotic in spirit. They are the keepers of our democracy and the guardians of our prosperity and the precious freedoms we enjoy in this country but all too often take for granted. Our Defence Force personnel in the gulf deserve our admiration, our gratitude and our respect in the immensely dangerous task they face. May your mission be speedy and successful, and may you be kept safe for your loved ones as you do your duty for the worthy and noble cause of enhancing peace and security both in Iraq and in our world.

Finally, I want to state very clearly in this parliament that I understand the strong views held by those who disagree with me. I also respect your right to hold those views. In particular, I respect your right to convey peacefully those opinions to me and, for those residents of Ryan, to convey those views peacefully to me as your elected representative in our nation's parliament. That is the strength of our country. That is the majesty of our democracy. That is what inspires me, as a member of the nation's parliament, and that is what makes me proud to be an Australian.

talk.start.para: —As I stand here now, not only does the clock run down on my contribution to this debate but it also runs down to the deadline set down by USA President George Bush. Today, war in Iraq becomes a reality. The United Nations Secretary-General, Kofi Annan, said this morning:

quote.para: Whatever our differing views on this complex issue may be, we must all feel that this is a sad day for the United Nations and the international community.
I know that millions of people around the world share this sense of disappointment and are deeply alarmed by the prospect of imminent war.

speech.para: How right he is. This government, in the name of the Australian people, has committed us to be an integral part of an invasion force that will unleash great violence, the consequences of which are now unforeseeable and uncontrollable. That is a mighty arrogant decision.

I am deeply concerned about some of the possible ramifications of this action, many of which have already been canvassed by previous speakers in this House. Not only are there moral and ethical implications but also what does this mean for Australia's strategic relations with our neighbours? Does the government have any concern or regard that two of our closest neighbours—Indonesia and New Zealand—have roundly condemned this action? And what about the increased risk of terrorism and where we are in the region? How can anybody believe that our involvement and participation in this invasion force will not increase the likelihood of terrorism on the shores of Australia?

This is not the first time I have had the opportunity to speak in this parliament concerning what was previously the threat of—and now is the reality of—war in Iraq. I do not resile from any of my former comments in this debate. But today I want to speak directly to my constituents in the electorate of Hasluck, and I want to make sure that they know where I stand and how I feel about this issue. Many constituents—those who have stopped me in the streets of my electorate, or have phoned, written or emailed me over recent months—have echoed my own feelings on the possibility of war in Iraq and Australia's involvement. They also demanded two things of their elected representatives. Firstly, that we do everything within our power to find a peaceful solution to the current crisis and, secondly, that we do not support Australia being involved in a US-led war with Iraq without the broad endorsement of the world community—preferably through the processes of the United Nations. I join my Labor colleagues in raising my voice in continuing to oppose this war. I believe it is a sad day when this parliament has failed its constituents and certainly my constituents in Hasluck. I believe that the Prime Minister has failed the Australian people in the way in which he has conducted himself on our behalf throughout this debate.

At this stage, it is appropriate for me to record my personal support for the members of the Defence Force who have been deployed and their families, as well as the best wishes of the electors of Hasluck. Western Australia's involvement has been quite significant in the forces that have been predeployed or are currently in the gulf. In Western Australia there are many families and friends of those servicemen and servicewomen who are on active duty. In particular, I acknowledge the Western Australian based frigates—the Anzac and the Darwin—that have both been deployed to the gulf along with a Navy diving team from HMAS Stirling. Of course the Special Air Service Regiment, which is based in my home state of Western Australia, is set to play, as it always does, a critical and possibly dangerous role once war breaks out. I want to use this occasion to convey my sincerest best wishes and support to those service personnel, who are on what appears to be the verge of the great unknown, and to their families and loved ones. Our thoughts are with them and I extend the best wishes of the electors of Hasluck. I note the comments that were made by the member for Cowan yesterday in the chamber concerning the defence forces and hoping that appropriate support is put in place to assist them and their families.

It was the predeployment of those troops that really brought home to me the true nature of this debate. The decision to commit to war puts on the line the lives of not only those troops but also ordinary Iraqi families who will suffer the horrors of war. I, along with most Australians, was devastated by the impact of the Bali bombings that occurred last year, particularly on innocent Australians and their families. We know just how devastating that impact was. As a nation, we were shocked and we were appalled at how quickly and destructively so many young lives could be taken.
