It has been, I think, somewhat ironic that the Prime Minister has sought to use this tragedy as a justification in part for his support of unilateral action against Iraq. I think that link is wrong. Indeed, the only comparative link that I can make between the appalling events in Bali and the current situation in Iraq is my fear that thousands of Iraqi families will be subjected to similar devastation in the coming weeks as they live with the consequence of bombs. You really have to wonder whether the reasons for the coalition of the willing having decided to drop those bombs make a difference to those Iraqi families and whether those arguments will matter when their loved ones have been lost. One of the great advocates of nonviolence, Mahatma Gandhi, said:

quote.para: What difference does it make to the dead, the orphans and the homeless, whether the mad destruction is wrought under the name of totalitarianism or the holy name of liberty or democracy?

speech.para: His comments remain valid today.

I went to find out what the situation might be for many of the families in Iraq. I was appalled to discover that of the Iraqi population of some 24.5 million: half are under 18; one in eight children die before the age of five; 294 women die per 100,000 births; over five million people currently have no access to clean water; and increasingly children are staying away from school and working to help supplement their family's income. Devastation has really been wrought in Iraq over the last two decades. The country has gone from being in the mid-seventies a prosperous economy, fuelled by the sales of its huge oil reserves, to a situation now where much of the country's infrastructure has been devastated and 12 years of international sanctions have limited the people's ability to rebuild and invest in social systems, such as health care. All of these things have had a significant impact on the children in Iraq. So I spare a thought for them today. As I have said previously, I sometimes wish it were the leaders of countries who had to take to the battlefield to sort out these resolutions. I suspect in those circumstances that armed conflicts would be far less likely and I am certain that a much greater effort would be directed to alternatives to military action.

I have said that I want to touch on the role of the Prime Minister in this debate as the days have unfolded. The other day in this House, when the Leader of the Opposition was making a reply to the Prime Minister's motion, we saw the Prime Minister turn his back on him. I say to the Prime Minister that that is not first time he has done that. He turned his back on Australia's important international relations, including with countries in our immediate region such as Indonesia. In recent weeks he has turned his back on the majority of Australians opposed to this war by dismissing their protests as `mob action'. On Tuesday he turned his back on the United Nations process by committing troops to war instead of pursuing a diplomatic resolution to the crisis. And on Wednesday he turned his back on the parliament when he cancelled question time and refused to answer questions about the most serious decision a government can make: committing our troops to war. I just want to ask him, perhaps rhetorically: when, Prime Minister, will you have the courage to turn your back on the demands of President Bush when they are not in Australia's national interest? (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —One of the hardest decisions a government can make is to commit its nation's forces to military action. This has been a very tough decision undertaken by the Prime Minister, and it is one of the most historic decisions that any Prime Minister has to make for any country. Nobody wants war. I do not, and I know that many of my friends and family members agree with me on that particular issue. War is the last resort and it is regrettable. But the fact is that the United Nations Security Council has failed to disarm Iraq of its weapons of mass destruction. In the past I have been supportive of no action without UN backing. Although I would have liked to have had UN backing, I realise that the failure of the Security Council to act on the intent of its resolutions has left us with no choice. The decision by the Prime Minister to commit troops to the situation in Iraq has been done in a framework that is both moral and legal.

speech.para: In an ideal world, the UN Security Council would ensure complicity from rogue states. But that has not been the case. If we wait and do nothing, we risk the escalation of situations in North Korea, Zimbabwe, the former Soviet states and between Israel and Palestine. Have we forgotten how UN indecisiveness resulted in crises such as Kosovo, Rwanda and Bosnia? It is hard to imagine a world without checks and balances, a world with no sense of integrity, no justice. Such an amoral world would permit constant human rights violations and place in turmoil the ability of countries to guarantee the security of their own people. It would proliferate the use of weapons of mass destruction and permit terrorism to reign supreme.

This is not a world that I want to be a part of. It is a world that is increasingly likely if we permit terrorism to reign supreme and do not disarm Iraq. We are not alone in thinking this. Some 30 countries have agreed to join Australia, the United Kingdom and the US as part of the coalition for the immediate disarmament of Iraq. They include Afghanistan, Albania, Azerbaijan, Colombia, the Czech Republic, Denmark, El Salvador, Eritrea, Estonia, Ethiopia, Georgia, Hungary, Iceland, Italy, Japan, Korea, Latvia, Lithuania, Macedonia, the Netherlands, Nicaragua, the Philippines, Poland, Romania, Slovenia, Spain, Turkey and Uzbekistan. In addition, approximately 15 other countries have offered defensive assets.

As Australians, we have freedoms, rights and a democracy that permits debate on such sensitive issues as this. From my electorate of Petrie, I have received many letters of support and also letters opposing the war with Iraq. I thank all of my constituents for their efforts to write to me. I have read and listened to their arguments, and I understand their concerns. Nobody wants war, but the alternative presents us with a situation that would be adverse not just for the Iraqi people but for us all. The consistent action by Iraq to defy consecutive United Nations Security Council resolutions over the past 12 years has demonstrated that Saddam Hussein does not hold the UN, or the very principles by which we live and abide, as worthy. He shows the same contempt for the United Nations and international calls for him to disarm as he shows for his own people.

According to Amnesty International, the Iraqi people have experienced disappearances, systematic torture, extrajudicial executions, arbitrary detention and unfair trials. The Iraqi government manifests its own political agenda at the expense of the Iraqi people. Since the 1990s, sanctions against Iraq have jeopardised the rights of people to access food, health and education. Each year that sanctions remain in place, roughly 60,000 Iraqi children under the age of five will die. These sanctions only exist because Saddam Hussein has failed to honour a cease-fire agreement that he signed 12 years ago. There is broad international agreement for Iraq to disarm and for an improvement in the conditions of the Iraqi people, as demanded by both common decency and the Iraqi people themselves.
When Hans Blix, the United Nations weapons inspector presented his report in January this year, he stated:

quote.para: ... Iraq appears not to have come to a genuine acceptance—not even today—of the disarmament, which was demanded of it ...

speech.para: This was reiterated in Dr Blix's most recent report on 7 March, in which he was still unable to report that Iraq had cooperated fully with United Nations inspectors. Resolution 1441 was the last in a series of UN Security Council resolutions that called on Iraq to disarm fully. It gave Iraq that final opportunity to comply with its breaches of previous resolutions and was drafted in a manner that meant that, by failing to comply, Iraq would face serious consequences. It recalled previous resolution 678 from 1990 and resolution 687 from 1991. Resolution 678 authorised all necessary means to implement subsequent resolutions that would restore peace and security to the region.

Iraq's continual defiance of the original intention of the cease-fire agreement it signed in 1991 and the subsequent UN Security Council resolutions sets a precarious agenda for like-minded rogue states to proliferate their weapons of mass destruction and engender a world devoid of rights and liberties. The message from the International Crisis Group is very clear on this issue:

quote.para: There are situations, and this may be one of them, where there is no alternative but to resort to war to achieve legitimate international objectives.
What can be stated unequivocally is that the alternative to war, if there is one, is not to do nothing.

speech.para: The decision to commit our troops to military action against Iraq has been taken in the best interests of what is right for Australia and in the long-term interests of national and international security.

Australia is a multicultural, democratic nation and one that honours and respects other cultures and beliefs and the rights of all to equality of opportunity. At this time in history, it is important that people should be judged for who they are and not for their race, colour or creed. The issue lies with Saddam Hussein and the Iraqi government, not with Islam. We are a multicultural nation, and as a first generation Australian I am proud to be an Australian. The coming days and weeks will write a very important chapter in the history of this nation, and racism should not feature in it.

The situation at home in our cities and towns will be just as important as what is unfolding half a world away. My electorate of Petrie is home to many defence families, particularly in the southern end of the electorate. We commend the men and women of our Australian Defence Force and their commitment to serve their country both at home and, as always, abroad. As a nation, we reflect on the job they undertake with courage and conviction. We admire them, and our thoughts go out to them, their families and their loved ones. On behalf of the people of the Petrie electorate, I offer them our thoughts and prayers for a very safe journey back to Australia.

We have never been a country to shy away from a duty we see to others or to our own people. We hold fast to the belief in democracy and freedom. At the start of this speech, I spoke of the difficulty of committing troops to military action, but a world of terrorism and sedition is a greater threat than military action now. Military action is obliged by the UN resolutions and honours the sentiment of the vast majority of Iraqi people, who desire regime change and the opportunity for a better life for themselves and future generations. The decision to commit our forces may not be an easy decision to make, but it is the right decision.

talk.start.para: —Never is there a more critical passage for a nation than when its leaders make a decision to go to war. In our case, the Prime Minister has committed us to a war which the international community and public sentiment here at home, including the federal opposition, consider to be illegal and morally wrong—illegal because it is set to take place without the sanction of the UN Security Council and morally wrong because it is the result of a unilateral action based on a new and dangerous concept of pre-emptive strike.

speech.para: At about 12 o'clock today, Australia will begin its passage from a well-respected global citizen, a defender of international law and supporter of the authority of the United Nations, a country not generally known for conducting a belligerent or aggressive foreign policy and one that does not prey on its neighbours, to a country that, by rushing to be at the forefront of the coalition of the willing, has placed itself in very precarious and uncharted waters. It is this loss of our innocence that grieves me the most, and I know that it grieves and bewilders the people of Australia. I know many have argued that the world has changed dramatically since September 11. Indeed, it has changed; we cannot deny that. But it is precisely because of these changed circumstances that now, more than ever, we need to pursue resolution and action within the processes of the United Nations. Now is not the time to throw caution to the wind, to sidestep international law and participate in an action that, far from protecting our national interests, exposes our country and our citizens to the harm of potential retribution.

Try as I might, I cannot see how participation in an American-led war on Iraq can serve our national interests. How is it in our national interests to be party to a war which, in the words of the United Nations Secretary-General, Kofi Annan, lacks legitimacy? At 12 noon today, we begin to gamble with the future of our national interests and security. Australia cannot afford to place itself outside the UN processes. We cannot afford to be marked as a crusader nation—especially given our geographic location. Whether we like it or not, our neighbourhood is Asia and many of our neighbours are of the Muslim faith. It is in this neighbourhood that we trade and conduct business activities that have significant impact on our economy. This is the message that has resonated loud and clear in my own electorate of Calwell but also in the broader Australian community, and this is the message that the Prime Minister has chosen to ignore.

Over the course of the past few months I, like many of my colleagues, have sought and obtained the views of residents of my electorate. I can tell you that opposition by the residents in the electorate of Calwell to action without United Nations support was as high as 83 per cent in survey returns. No doubt members opposite, if they were able to speak openly and honestly, would report similar attitudes and feelings in their own electorates. My constituents, like a great many other Australians, are deeply concerned about the anticipated deaths of innocent civilians during the execution of this enormous military action against Iraq, but they are also concerned about the impact of this unilateral war closer to home.

We have a very large Muslim community living here in Australia; in fact, we have a very large Arabic community. Australians of Muslim and Middle Eastern appearance have endured vilification and abuse since September 11, and the Prime Minister has done nothing but pay lip-service to their predicament. Australians of Arabic and Muslim background can find no comfort in the Prime Minister's reassurances because there is none. His actions constantly contradict his words. In fact, Australians across the board can take no comfort in the Prime Minister's reassurances because he is, unfortunately, driven and swayed by the ideological agenda and military timetable of a foreign President, the President of the United States. Our Prime Minister has forgone his duty to the Australian people by involving us in a war that is not directly our business, leaving us highly exposed subscribers to a doctrine of pre-emptive strikes which will strain the future of international cooperation and security.

Today is a sad day for Australians but also for the people of Iraq. I have no doubt that many of them want to see the back of Saddam Hussein, but I am certain that they were hoping and praying that this crisis would be resolved by diplomacy and not war. Instead, sometime within the next few hours the might of the American military machine will darken their skies. Only time will tell whether this military assault will become their liberator, but what is certain is that death, displacement and destruction will be visited upon the people of Iraq today.

Disarmament through diplomacy was not given a chance to fully exhaust its processes because it fell victim to the neo-conservative ideologues that run the Bush administration. Our Prime Minister must be condemned; for, in his own moment of truth, he has finally shown how much he and his government have fallen for the appeal of the White House hawks. He has shown how much he is prepared to make Australia—for the first time ever—an aggressor nation willing to defy international law and world public opinion. What concerns me is the lack of foresight the government is showing in relation to our neighbourhood. Is it really in our national interest to be encouraging the view that we are white colonialists, or white crusaders, as put to me recently by a visiting Malaysian academic? Did the Prime Minister, or indeed the foreign minister, at any stage consult with any of our regional neighbours before embarking on this strategy of pre-emptive strike?

At a time when the Asia-Pacific region is at the crossroads, with rising tensions in the Korean peninsula, the government does not appear to be too concerned about the possibility that its actions could isolate us and thus leave us vulnerable. What contingency plans, if any, does the government have in this scenario? Can the Prime Minister assure us that, in the event of trouble in the region where Australian national interests and security are at stake, our American ally will come to our aid? Many people fear that, if the US had to make such a determination, it would be done on the exclusive basis of its own national interests. If those interests should be inconsistent with Australia's then the answer is, perhaps, don't hold your breath.

Never has a script for war been written with so much hypocrisy and posturing. We do not know what will happen from this point onwards because we cannot totally predict the outcome of a pre-emptive strike policy engineered by a superpower that has treated the UN with nothing but contempt and disdain. We are concerned that the Prime Minister of Australia has indulged in the President of the United States' deception, sharing in his vanity and recklessness and in his phoney diplomacy to justify a manufactured war. As such, John Howard has let the people of Australia down. He stands condemned for discarding the diplomatic process in favour of unilateral military action. He stands condemned for seriously and dangerously compromising Australia's national security, he stands condemned for unnecessarily endangering the lives of Australian service men and women, he stands condemned for placing in serious danger the lives of Australian citizens, and he stands condemned for allowing the reputation of this great country to be tarnished and perhaps irreversibly damaged through his commitment to the coalition of the willing. Finally, he stands condemned for aiding and abetting one country's determination to preserve its economic, military and political supremacy over all others at the expense of Australia's national interest.

talk.start.para: —I come to this debate on Iraq today after giving deep consideration to all sides of the debate. It is an issue that has weighed heavily on my mind both as a freedom-loving Australian and as a representative of the people of Deakin in this parliament. It is an issue that also weighs heavily on the minds of many in my electorate. I want to assure the people of Deakin that I have listened to the sincerity and the conviction with which they have expressed their thoughts. I would also like to assure them that their views have been conveyed to the government. I respect their concerns and points of view. Like many in this House, I have also received hundreds of vitriolic emails from outside my electorate. These messages have done nothing to advance that side of the argument.

speech.para: Broadly, there are two common themes on this issue. Some have argued that there should be no action taken against Iraq without Security Council backing. Others argue that Iraq does not currently pose a threat to Australia but that we may become a target if we join in the coalition of the willing. I am not so presumptuous to assert that my conscience is superior to theirs. To paraphrase the words of Jack Straw, British Foreign Secretary, `No person has a mortgage on morality or a monopoly on wisdom.'

Let me be clear: I would have felt a greater degree of comfort if the permanent members of the Security Council had rallied together—if they had spoken with one voice to support the immediate removal of the threat that the Iraqi regime poses. Some members of the UN were all too prepared to play Saddam Hussein's cat and mouse game with the weapons inspectors indefinitely. I find it almost abhorrent to ask the Iraqi people to put up with a couple more months of torture, persecution, rape and executions to allow weapons inspectors more time. More time after 12 years is certainly not the answer; it is pure naivety to presume it is.

This is about the denial of Saddam Hussein to comply with 17 clear and unambiguous resolutions of the UN Security Council. By Saddam's noncompliance with the resolutions to immediately and absolutely disarm, the world community is left with no choice but to end his despotic regime and to rid it of its weapons of mass destruction and its ability to sell weaponry to borderless terrorist groups.

At the end of the day, I am swayed by the notion that to do nothing is to deny the very freedoms and liberties that we enjoy here in Australia being available to the people of Iraq—a people long oppressed, abused, tortured and murdered by one of the world's most despotic regimes. I am swayed to support this motion by the necessity to send a clear and unambiguous message to those borderless terrorists: that one more regime from which they enjoy succour will be removed and that the likelihood of them getting their hands on weapons of mass destruction from this regime for their murderous intentions on the Western world will be lessened. Action taken against Iraq is in the name of freedom and in the name of ending the humanitarian abuses inflicted by Saddam Hussein and the more than one million Iraqis on the payroll of the Iraqi Secret Service.

If free nations around the world sit idly by at a distance, claiming geographic detachment as a defence, then we undermine our democratic foundations. This is not the Australia that I love. This is not the Australia that we have all come to cherish and respect for the values that it holds, particularly its humanitarian values. Whilst it troubles me to think we are actively commissioning our young service personnel, it also plays on my mind to think that such oppression, devastation and barbarism is taking place as we speak.

The very institution that claims to protect human beings from such acts as a facilitator of peace has faltered. This fact is undeniable. History will note forevermore that, when it came to the crunch, the UN buckled and some of the permanent members of the Security Council shirked their responsibilities as nations claiming to support liberty and the principles of freedom. Regrettably, this is not the first time the United Nations has been noticeably absent when it was needed most. The United Nations was reluctant to be involved in intervening in the atrocities taking place in Kosovo, it was quiet when it came to Africa, it cannot be found in Zimbabwe and who knows where it will be on North Korea. Its capacity to credibly and effectively deal with threats that will surface in the future is now, as a result of its inaction, severely compromised.

Those claiming to have another answer to this issue refer to the containment of Iraq. Containment has been tried and tested in Iraq. It was tried and failed in 1998 when the weapons inspectors were forced out. That forceful removal continued and, time after time, containment failed. Other commentators propose ridiculous arguments about our foreign policy being beholden to the United States. The United States is an important ally in our regional security, but our foreign policy has been dictated based, first and foremost, on our national security, not on short-term populist appeal. It takes into account our regional position.

I had the good fortune to visit Jakarta last week, where I met with a number of Christian-minded Indonesian MPs as well as members of the Islamic parliamentary hierarchy. The clear message I got from the meetings we had was that Australia's position is understood. To the Indonesian MPs, it is clear that our motivations are not anti-Islam but rather antiterrorist. The distinction is there and well understood. In return, I understand that the action by the US led coalition may give courage to some extremist Islamic elements within Indonesia. However, at the end of the day, we need to take action for the medium- and long-term interests of Australia and the values and freedoms we hold dear.

In the lead-up to this debate, I had reservations on three fronts: first, the humanitarian considerations; second, the legal arguments for war; and, third, the precedent set by engaging in pre-emptive military action. I have already covered the first and most important of these issues, the humanitarian considerations. As to the legal argument, I am now satisfied that the government has received adequate advice through the Attorney-General's Department and the International Law Division of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade that the use of force in this instance does not transcend international law. I am advised, and therefore confident, that there exists sufficient legal foundation for this action. Furthermore, a group of international law experts from around the world wrote an article in the Australian on 18 March lending their support. They were responding to a joint letter published in the Age and the Sydney Morning Herald on 26 February 2003. In offering their expert legal opinion, the group stated:

quote.para: Twelve years of resolutions and sanctions, and promising dire consequences, have not brought Iraq into compliance. When a policeman refuses to enforce the law, and gives a series of hollow “last chances”, there comes a point when citizens and criminals alike lose respect for both police and the law.

speech.para: I regretfully believe that this action is warranted and justified—not only justified in law but also, more significantly, morally justifiable on humanitarian grounds.

On the more perplexing issue of the precedent set by the pre-emptive action, I am confident, having been assured that the action is legal, that the uncertainty of engaging in pre-emptive action is lessened. The risk in engaging in pre-emptive action is that it may send a message to nations seeking an excuse to put their finger on the trigger in attacking neighbouring countries. However, what distinguishes this action from those some have cited as possible theatres of conflict— namely, Pakistan, Indonesia and India—is that the action has legal authority and, more importantly, in this case we are dealing with a despotic regime that has thumbed its nose at the world community. In any future attempt at pre-emptive action, each case will have to be judged on its own individual merits.

I doubt that any other despotic regime in the world could take much comfort from this precedence, knowing that they too could receive the full retribution of the world community if they enter into pre-emptive action without moral and legal foundation. But in saying this I recognise that we are opening up a new geopolitical-military paradigm which remains to be tested and will pose a challenge to the legitimacy of any future Western opposition.

In the days to come our decision in this parliament will be judged. To those who claim an electoral backlash against members who support the government's motion, my answer is simple: what happens at the next election is not my concern today. It would be morally reprehensible for anyone to be making such grave decisions on possible electoral support at the next election.

Finally, I pray for the men and women of the ADF who are in the gulf region doing their duty. May you come back to your families safe and well and may you come back to a grateful nation, one that has learned its lesson from scorning its service men and women. We owe you our thanks and support.

talk.start.para: —In just over one hour's time, the greatest military onslaught in the history of this planet will take place. We have come to this point because of a series of failures—almost, one could say, on all sides. There was certainly failure in terms of the diplomatic process at the UN. But the core diplomatic failure is the failure of the United States, Britain and Australia, the three countries that are committing troops to this action, to convince their fellows in the United Nations—and, in the case of the first two, in the UN Security Council—that it is justifiable to go to war against Iraq because of Iraq's shortcomings, great, significant and deep as they are. We know the history. The history has been paraded by members of the government about what the problem is in relation to Iraq. But we also know something else: in just over an hour's time we will have a fracture point and a fault line between the past and the future.

speech.para: The most significant international entity we have had, the United Nations, which was developed after the Second World War, has succeeded beyond measure compared to the League of Nations, which utterly failed after the First World War. What the League of Nations lacked more than anything else was some kind of peacekeeping force and an ability for the league to enforce decisions of the whole body. That was remedied through the UN Security Council. Throughout the history of the Cold War, the capacity of the United Nations to deal with crises was completely blocked because of the political and ideological divide between the East and the West. The power of veto was exercised time after time from both the communist side and the Western allied side, so that there could not be a fundamental resolution of the wars, the problems or the crises that faced the United Nations.

But we are living in a post Cold War period. We are not living in a bipolar period, where it is just those with black hats and those with white hats; we are living in a multipolar period and a period of enormous change. But we are also living in an increasingly democratic period, where the fundamental tenets that were the basis of the formation of the United Nations—that all of the nations of the earth should come together in a council, in an assembly, to determine their fate, and that the great lack that there was in the League of Nations, that of enforcing decisions and resolutions, should be addressed—are met in this United Nations. We saw in resolutions 678, 687 and 1441 the capacity of the United Nations with regard to those countries that are at its core, the five permanent powers in the Security Council, which were the key powers in 1945. This is an aged institution which is not contemporary—and that is one of the problems it faces—but when they set their minds to looking for a majority decision and a decision reached without veto, it was possible to come to that.

What we have here is a fracture line of immense importance. Here we have three countries, three members of the United Nations, which could be depicted as a triumvirate or a troika or, as I suggested yesterday in the House, as the new Holy Trinity—the United States, the only superpower on this planet at present; Great Britain, a former superpower but a faded diplomatic force and one that is allied directly to the United States in this conflict; and Australia, under this coalition government—being led by people who are utterly convinced in their Christian right to go to war with other countries. And there could be a string of other countries, not just Iraq, because of the President of the United States, a Christian fundamentalist—and we know that we have had attacks by Islamic fundamentalists.

If we go past this fracture point to create a world in which the religious wars of past centuries between the Catholics and the Protestants, which ran for about 300 years, are to be revisited upon us because of the fundamentalist approach taken by our great powers, we are in great peril. We know for a certainty that we are involved in a real war against terror—not just against al-Qaeda but against a series of other organisations, such as Jemaah Islamiah and others in South-East Asia. We also know that there are states that back terror. Neither President Bush nor Prime Minister Blair, nor Prime Minister Howard, has made a cogent, coherent, concise, contemporary case for war that could convince the United Nations Security Council, the members of their parliaments—save for the United States; their congress was locked in early—or the majority of people within their constituencies.

This war does not have the backing of the majority of the people in the United States, Britain and Australia. We know there has been no clear-cut case that could convince the Security Council—as it was convinced with resolutions 678, 687 and 1441—that it is right and proper and just and legal and moral to go to war with full UN sanction against a member state because of what it had perpetrated against another. That was the case in relation to Iraq and Kuwait. It is the case now with resolution 1441 if Iraq had not satisfied what was demanded there. But there was no automaticity in relation to 1441. The United States and Britain, with Australia as an outrider, had to convince nine out of 15 members of the Security Council with no veto—not just one, two or the seven members that they seem to have—as they did with 1441, for this to be a completely justified war.

So this is a major fault line. This is three countries determining, by their very wish and choice, that they could go to war on the basis of whatever pre-existing United Nations resolutions there were. If this is sanctioned, surely it gives sanction to any other member state of the United Nations to say: `There are other resolutions that have not been lived up to by member countries in the past—we know them they are littered throughout the history of the United Nations—they have not been acted upon. It is our choice to operate in a fashion where we will say that the resolutions have not been satisfied. We will pre-emptively take action because that is justified by the United States.' No person in this country could believe that it would be right and just for any member states to simply decide that they are going to go to war because there have been past resolutions; but that is what we are being asked to believe, and asked to sanction, by our Prime Minister, the Prime Minister of Britain and the President of the United States.

It is not right, or proper for action to be taken—as it will be in just under an hour's time—against Iraq without full UN sanction. If there are those who think that the United Nations needs to be brought completely up to date, that it needs to be reconstructed, let it be done in the future, and let those governments and those leaders who argue that there are deficiencies resolve those deficiencies. But we now have to deal with the current situation.

No-one can truly believe that the great problem the world faces is Saddam Hussein and his regime in Iraq when we know that the war on terror has visited New York, Washington and Bali. We know that the war on terror is inexorably moving—because of the decision taken by this Prime Minister and this government—closer to the very doorstep of Australia, into our suburbs and across our land. We know that we need multilateralism and the rule of law to defeat those terrorists who would seek to wipe out Western civilisation and Western secular democracies. The way to defeat them is not by trampling upon the agreed processes we have had in the past to resolve war and conflict. It is not to fracture what was there, but to support the United Nations and to resolve our problems with these people as quickly as we can by certain and definite action from the United Nations as a whole.

talker.name: Hardgrave, Gary, MP
Mr HARDGRAVE
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs

talk.start.para: —This is an important debate. It is one that I am sure all Australians wish we were not having to have. There are many different views, but it is extraordinary that those opposite are promoting division rather than unity at this important time in the world's history and in our nation's history. Those opposite say there is no link between the agents of terror and Saddam Hussein, yet they keep evoking the consequence of terror that will result from Australia standing strongly with some 30 other nations at this time to deal with these issues.

speech.para: Australia must stand up for human rights. For a dozen years the world has allowed Saddam Hussein to continue down the path of violating basic human rights. It has not been possible for those within his nation to have a contrary view to him. Those who have a different religious background have not been able to express their view. Those who have come from a different ethnic background have not been able to survive. They have been the victims of torture, institutional rape, the gouging out of children's eyes—all of these horrors have occurred. These are facts.

I respect strongly the views and concerns of those who have different approaches to that of the government. Everyone needs to understand that no-one wants war. The Prime Minister has said this on many occasions, and I totally agree. While I share the genuine ambitions of those who say no to war, sadly it seems that nothing anybody says is going to stop Saddam Hussein from continuing to ignore countless United Nations directives over the last dozen years. He has said no so many times and shows no interest whatsoever in abiding by the world's directives to disarm.

It is worth noting that there are only six countries in the world that for the past 100 years have maintained democratic traditions. Australia is proudly one of those six. New Zealand, the United Kingdom, Canada, the United States and Switzerland are the other five. We are one of those nations which can rightly say that we have respect for people of all backgrounds to ably contribute to society. That is the way we organise ourselves, so we are in a position to judge a regime that is doing the exact opposite.

There are those who are saying that it is not our fight, that it is not relevant. It will only become relevant when it is too late. As the Prime Minister has suggested, does it take an attack onshore to make it relevant to Australia and its people? No, it does not. We must stand for something. Moreover, we must ensure that we fight this fight offshore, not onshore. It is critical at this time that, when we talk about national security, we know we cannot maintain it unless there is a sense of support for all in our communities. Without community harmony in our multicultural society there can be no national security.

It is important that all in this place show leadership, support and a sense of unity—but we are not seeing it from the Australian Labor Party at this critical time. For people who come from a variety of backgrounds whom we see in our communities, in our streets, in our neighbourhoods and in my own electorate this is certainly very relevant. Kurdish people who have fled Iraq, who have fled the Saddam regime, understand only too well the hurt that has been inflicted upon their families by this evil man. I have been meeting with them, and I understand their concerns. As the Prime Minister said on 4 February, while they want to see the end of Saddam, they are worried that the first people Saddam will pick on—in the way that he has always picked on them and victimised them—will be the Kurds.

We must spend time thinking about the feelings of those 15,000 Iraqis who are part of Australian society today. They are here for the best of reasons. We must not allow any of them to be targeted or to be made to feel fearful in our society during this time. The 280,000 people who are respectful followers of Islamic traditions, the Australian Muslim community, have risen to the occasion in the way that they have expressed their sense of Australianness, especially since Bali but most profoundly since the September 11 horror. That sort of Australian conduct needs to be rewarded with our support as Australians of all backgrounds, particularly at this time.

As a minister in the government, I am doing my bit—along with the Prime Minister, the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and, indeed, all government members—to try to provide strength and support to members of our local communities. The Australian National Dialogue of Christians, Muslims and Jews was launched last week in Sydney. Members of each of those three faiths are sitting down and talking to each other about how they share a common destiny in this country and how they lament the fact that in other parts of the world there is no opportunity to realise any ambition like that, with Iraq being the worst example of that lack of opportunity.

It is important that we are all in the business of promoting a sense of unity and not using rhetoric or what is occurring elsewhere in the world to drive a wedge in our communities. It is shocking to think that, in the nexus of the political cycle we are in, with an impending war, you have weak opposition leadership. The Leader of the Opposition's concern for keeping the Left behind his fragile leadership seems to be his motivation for opposition to what the government is doing. If the member for Brand were the leader, I believe things would have been different. In this nexus is a New South Wales election where the Australian Labor Party know that their do-nothing state government has let down people in Western Sydney where a lot of Muslims live. This also seems to be a powerful motivator for the sort of hysteria that they have been trying to promote in that part of Australia in the weeks leading up to this. Of course, many opposite are facing their own preselections and, as we know, they owe their support, their position in this place, to outside forces.

These sorts of issues are real in this debate. They are real because the member for Reid, the shadow minister for multicultural affairs, has been driving his own wedge. He has been trying to suggest to the Arabic community ethnic broadcasters in this country that the government is trying to shut them down or to control what they have to say. Yet we know it is not true; it is a total fabrication. According to his web site, in a speech on 17 November to the ethnic community broadcasters' National Ethnic Media And Multicultural Broadcasters' Council in Adelaide, the member for Reid said:

quote.para: I also told the conference that I am concerned about the increasing ability of overseas media to easily penetrate niche ethnic and religious markets in Australia. It is clear that some of these media sources are hostile to cooperation and to ethnic, political and religious conciliation. They reflect tendencies and values that are contrary to Australia's commitment to multiculturalism.

speech.para: The member for Reid was right in that speech of 17 November, but how does he reconcile that with his outrageous conduct over the last couple of weeks in trying to create fear in the hearts and minds of people who are feeling very vulnerable right at this time? It is a disgraceful course of conduct by the member for Reid and by others opposite who have been silent on the issue and who have not pulled him into line. There is a lack of leadership in the Australian Labor Party.

By contrast, this Prime Minister has shown strength and a sense of purpose. He has been willing to present himself as the person ultimately responsible for the decisions that have been made on behalf of the people of Australia. These sorts of decisions are never easy, but when you stand for something you know what you have to do and when you have to do it. As the Prime Minister said on 4 February:

quote.para: Australia is home to several hundred thousand people of Middle Eastern background ... Many of them could be torn between seeing Saddam brought to account and the possible dangers facing their families back in Iraq. During this time, they will need our compassion and our support. All Australians should ensure that this is offered.

speech.para: That is a reasonable message that again shows strong leadership from this Prime Minister, yet those opposite simply want to do the exact opposite and create a sense of fear and uncertainty amongst people who are already feeling vulnerable.

It is critical that Australians of all backgrounds get behind Harmony Day tomorrow, 21 March. There are 474 events and some 2,700 community organisations around Australia will be involved. By wearing the colour orange, Australians can say no to racism and yes to what brings us together—yes to support for our Australian friends of all backgrounds who are part of our community. Australians are united to defend our liberty, our free speech, our way of life and our values. That is what leadership is all about. When you take on a regime that those opposite in their contribution to this debate seem all too willing to try to excuse, it is one of those examples of just how hard strong leadership can sometimes prove to be. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I oppose Australia's involvement in a war as proposed by Prime Minister Howard this week. As I have said in previous contributions to the debate on the situation in Iraq, the military solution is the wrong solution. It is 11.15 a.m. Eastern Summer Time. The countdown to an invasion is now not measured in weeks, days or even hours; it is perhaps measured in minutes. Signals will commence to bounce off satellites and earth based communication centres. Jets and other aircraft will take off from carriers in the several air bases in the region. Bombing will commence. Missiles will be launched from land and sea. Subsequently, troops will be deployed—dropping from the air, moving in armed vehicles or moving on foot. Special forces will leave their secret bases. At the end of the day great destruction will occur. There are still many in the Australian community who, quite rightly and justifiably, ask why.

speech.para: Over the past several months the Prime Minister and other members of this Australian government have had the opportunity to explain to the Australian public why such action is necessary. Why is it that Australia should act on the call of the leader of another country—the United States? Many opposite have said that it is not only the United States that supports the action but also the United Kingdom. The call to our Prime Minister was not from Tony Blair; it was from George W. Bush. So that we get across the issue of our position on where the British Labour Party finds itself, I quite happily indicate that I am with the 139 members of the British Labour caucus who voted against the decision made by their leader, the Prime Minister. I think that goes to the need to understand that there is great debate about the actions that are about to occur. This should not simply be a matter of sloganeering and name-calling. There is still a chance to go through the issues as presented and try to achieve a way out that is much more peaceful in nature.

Right from the outset the opposition has taken the position that the way to go forward with the issues that surround Iraq—their weapons of mass destruction, the removal of those weapons and the modification of the behaviour of the regime that has led Iraq for several decades—is through the United Nations. It has become clear over the last few months and weeks that the only way there would be a peaceful resolution was through the United Nations. Each of the reports of the bodies that were given carriage of the most recent resolution, 1441—they being UNMOVIC and the International Atomic Energy Agency—has held out hope of successful achievement of the goal of removing Saddam Hussein's weapons of mass destruction. It has to be acknowledged that Hans Blix, on behalf of UNMOVIC, and Mohamed ElBaradei, on behalf of the IAEA, have indicated that. It has to be asked why this week—why today, why perhaps this hour—an action has to be embarked upon when progress was being made.

We have heard, through this debate and over the last few weeks, that the government is now pushing the barrow that there needs to be regime change because of the appalling behaviour of Saddam Hussein. The abuse of human rights in Iraq is a question that needs to be dealt with. But let us look at the time frame under which that has developed and at the way Saddam Hussein has been given succour. When those abuses of the human rights of individuals are highlighted and mention is made of Iraq's incursions into neighbouring countries—such as Kuwait and, further back, Iran—do we learn the lesson of history? Do we learn the lesson of history about the incursion into Iran? Do we hear mention of who gave support to Saddam Hussein at that stage back in the late 1970s and early 1980s? No; because it is convenient to gloss over the changes of world opinion and the changes of backing.

At the end of the day these are central questions concerning what we confront now. Even if there is to be regime change, even if there is actually a plan post the devastation of Iraq about the way in which we put in place a new regime that will protect the minorities of Iraq—and will be able to guarantee that minorities such as the Kurds in northern Iraq will then be able to see this change—how will we ensure that in several years we have not created yet another monster? The only way we can protect ourselves in a new, developing global world order is through collective action at an international level and through making sure that the United Nations is given every opportunity to work.

We have not seen a proper discussion of the way in which the action that is about to commence will cause further instability in the Middle East region. What is going to be the effect of the action when neighbouring nations are dragged into the vortex that will be formed? Will it indeed lead to a more stable Middle East? I am of the opinion that it will not. Often I hope that many of the conclusions that I have come to are wrong.

What of the effect of Australia's involvement as one of only three nations that are committing defence forces to this action? What of the effect on our standing in our own region when our major neighbours are against the action? Even if we live in hope that the present Indonesian leadership is able to convince the populace of Indonesia that this is not a war against Islam, that perception will exist. In a nation like Indonesia, with a population of 230 million people, you do not need to expect a large percentage of people to come to that conclusion to know that we will have a continuing problem. The other aspect of the action is that it sends the wrong signals to a country like Indonesia, which is developing a democratic framework, about the way in which great democracies operate—that great democracies would take pre-emptive action against a sovereign state. Whether or not Iraq is described as a rogue state, it is action against a sovereign state.

There was time to get a peaceful outcome. There was time to ensure that Saddam Hussein changed his ways. I regret that the actions that are about to commence will lead to a bloody end to this affair. Like my colleagues, I wish our troops all the best for their safe return. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The previous speaker had doubt after doubt—doubt about stability in the Middle East, doubt about Indonesian attitudes and doubt about almost everything that was going on with this action. Can I suggest that, if he has any doubts about stability, he should have a look at the existing situation in the Middle East. We surely could not get less stability there than we have now.

speech.para: In the weeks of debates that we have heard in this chamber there is one very clear message: the coalition on this side of the chamber is clear in its resolve to be part of a willing coalition and the Labor Party are not. The Labor Party are so split on this issue that they would be hopeless in government, as they are in opposition. They are split three ways. There are actually several members of the opposition who believe that we are doing the right thing but publicly have not got the guts to say so. Then there is the group that slavishly follows the line of the opposition leader—that force should be used only if there is yet another resolution from the UN. Then there is the group of opposition MPs who do not even agree with that line and who oppose the use of any such force under any circumstances. The Labor Party are actually split three ways whereas we on this side of the chamber are not.

The members for Watson, Franklin and Sydney cannot even support their own leader on this issue. What would they be like in government? If you cannot govern your own party, as the line goes, you cannot govern Australia. Then we had the member for Stirling saying with such solemnity that this all amounts to an invasion. Talk about the bleeding obvious! What did she think it was—a Sunday school picnic? What was Saddam's invasion into Kuwait—another school picnic?

The Labor Party opposition is the most disgraceful opposition in living memory. It is not content to throw bipartisanship out the window. Every Labor speaker that I have heard, as if under their own marching orders, has tried to terrify the Australian population by saying that this action means that we are now real targets for terrorists. Isn't it ironic that only a matter of weeks ago they denigrated this government for a householder mail-out to warn of the need for vigilance and said how unnecessary it was? Now they try to tell us that we are targets so we had better look out. Talk about sitting on both sides of the fence. Here we have an opposition that cannot make up its mind about which side of the fence to sit on but opportunistically and disgustingly tries to terrify the Australian population.

The idea that somehow we can make ourselves less vulnerable to being targets for terrorist attacks by shutting up and doing nothing is not backed up by experience or the facts. The French, Kenyans and Germans have suffered from terrorist attacks; their appeasing ways have not worked. French President Chirac has not achieved anything with his appeasement either. In fact, I believe he has actually done great damage to the cause of the United Nations, because he has led the charge for inaction—as only the French can do. I fear that his actions will lead the United Nations down the same path as the old League of Nations, with no authority and no unity. We had unity with 17 or so resolutions of the Security Council of the United Nations and we had unity with the last resolution, 1441, which gave Saddam one last chance. He did not take it. That was over four months ago. How long does anyone want to give this horrible dictator?

Let us look at some of the untruths being spread by the Labor Party—first of all, that this is somehow an illegal action. The fact remains that the independent experts in international law in both the Attorney-General's Department and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade are unequivocal in saying that our actions are not illegal. This is also confirmed by the British Attorney-General. The second furphy is that this is a unilateral action. The fact is that 30 nations have agreed to be part of this coalition of the willing for the immediate disarmament of Iraq and at least another 15 countries are cooperating. Let us look at some of those 30 countries.

talk.start.para: —That's more than three.

—Much more than three. Besides Australia, Britain and the United States we have Middle Eastern countries like Afghanistan, Kuwait, Turkey and Bahrain. We have European countries like Albania, the Czech Republic, Denmark, Georgia, Estonia, Hungary, Iceland, Italy, Latvia, Lithuania, Macedonia, the Netherlands, Poland, Romania, Slovakia and Spain. We have Asian countries like Japan, South Korea and the Philippines, and the list goes on. So for anyone to suggest that this action is somehow unilateral is sheer nonsense. We heard the member for Banks, amongst others, disgracefully saying that the blood of the innocent victims in Iraq will be on our hands and on the hands of the Prime Minister. Inaction has already caused the death and suffering of over a million innocent Iraqis. How many more does he want before he acts?

speech.para: Then there is the furphy that we should not act without the say-so of the United Nations through yet another resolution. The United Nations was not there in Kosovo, and the world got the right result; the United Nations was not there for the Cuban missile crisis, and we got the right result; and it is a pity that the United Nations was not there to avert the crisis in Rwanda to save millions of lives. To say that we must act through the United Nations ignores history and the judgment of all those nations that are willing, and have been willing, to take the necessary actions.

Like all representatives in this House, I have received a flood of emails and correspondence on this matter, ranging from the supportive to the abusive. I have taken the time to read much of this, especially if it is from my electorate of Barker. I have made a point of talking to my constituents, whether they agree or disagree with my stance on, and support for, this action. I am accused of not listening by some because I do not agree with their views. Either way, I have listened and I have sought their views—and they do vary, quite considerably. I have read numerous articles, both for and against, but in the end, even though there are always doubts in your mind when you look at all of the different reasons for and against the action, I keep coming back to the need to disarm Saddam Hussein in the only way he knows. We all hate war. We would all prefer to avoid it. But Saddam has left the world with no option. He alone can now avert this action.

I send our brave troops my thoughts and prayers for their safe return. I wish well the parents, families and friends of our troops, who I know will be supporting them. I have spoken in my electorate to parents of people in the Air Force, on the ground and in the Navy. There are a few in my electorate who will have a certain unease. There is no doubt that there is some unease out there, because nobody likes war. There is concern about what is going to happen. You can never predict what happens in a war. But, in the end, I support this motion. I hope for a speedy result in the form of the liberation of Iraq from the control of this awful dictator.

talk.start.para: —Nearly 33 years ago the future Deputy Prime Minister of Australia Jim Cairns wrote the book Silence Kills, which dealt with a previous deception of the Australian people by a coalition Prime Minister. It is interesting to note, when we see the massive demonstrations around this country and particularly in rural and regional areas, and when we see the John Valders and Peter Baumes of this world going public at such an early stage in the lead-up to this conflict, that the numbers of those who demonstrated in May 1970, the demonstrations about which that book was written, were very small— 8,000 in Brisbane, 25,000 in Sydney and 70,000 to 100,000 in Melbourne. Clearly, in the context of the recent outpouring of opposition to this war in Australia, the eventual opposition by the Australian people to our involvement in Vietnam looks very paltry.

speech.para: I speak of misleading the Australian people because the then Prime Minister, Sir Robert Menzies, misled the Australian people as to why we were in Vietnam. He stated that we were asked by South Vietnam. History has shown that the actual request came from the United States of America. In this conflict we again have an obsequious government which is essentially following US dictates and which has misled the Australian people and the troops going to the Middle East, insofar as this undertaking was made many months ago. It was not made after the phone call last week; it was made in far earlier discussions with the American administration.

Throughout this debate we have been regaled with a nauseating list of guilty actions by the Iraqi regime—gouging out the eyes of four-year-old children, putting people in acid baths et cetera. But these are not new facts. I have been interested to note that the people who seem to get most emotional about these outrages in Iraq are the people who tend to take the least interest in human rights around the world. In 1982 when Ronald Reagan took Iraq off the list of supporters of terrorism around the world, in December 1983 when Rumsfeld went to have a few cups of coffee with Tariq Aziz and in November 1984 when the United States restored diplomatic ties with Iraq, these events were already occurring. It is quite interesting that the main basis on which coalition members are defending our involvement in this war is human rights abuses in Iraq, because these are not new—they are decades old and, quite frankly, they were condoned by the American administration because Iraq at that stage was regarded as a reliable ally.

We have heard other speakers tell us about the dreadful actions of the Iraqis in using gases on Kurds and in Iran. It is interesting to note that in regard to the invasion of Iran, which is now criticised by coalition members, the United States provided air strike suggestions to the Iraqi government and supplied their reconnaissance information to the Iraqi regime. This invasion, which is used today as such a dreadful thing and a reason for our action now, was condoned and abetted by the United States administration. Between 1985 and 1990 they issued 77 licences for biological products to Iraq.

When we look at the lone three sponsors of this resolution at the UN, which failed to get support, we see that Spain is one of them. Prime Minister Aznar was virtually pleading to the cortes the other day, `We won't send any troops. We know public opinion is totally against us. We know we have cosigned this resolution but we will definitely not be sending any troops.'

We have dealt with the US long-term relationship with Iraq. There was a very interesting article in the Guardian Weekly last week in regards to the United Kingdom, the other co-sponsor. That article revealed that under the Thatcher government, Paul Channon, the minister for trade, hid from the American administration, the complicity of the UK administration in helping Iraq to build Falluja 2—which is regarded as one of the main possibilities for the production of mustard gas. Not only that, but Britain provided export credits. They provided export credits behind the backs of the American administration to facilitate this program which is now so dreadful. It is interesting to note that the Ministry of Defence in Britain weighed in, warning that it could be used to make chemical weapons. So we have a situation where one of the co-sponsors aided—in a period when even the United States was starting to have doubts about Iraq—the build-up of these weapons which we are now so embarrassed by and so critical of.

The government is so desperate to raise the issue human rights abuses because other arguments have disappeared. On the question of legality, Professor Andrew Byrnes, a Canberra based legal scholar, said:

quote.para: ... it is the only a vaguely respectable argument but it is based on very weak legal grounds.

speech.para: We all know they did not have the effrontery or the hide to attempt to put a resolution through the UN Security Council last week because of a lack of support. The Prime Minister can argue until the cows come home that they did not do it because the French would veto it. We all know, despite all the wire taps on diplomats at the United Nations, despite the spying on Chile and despite all the US heavying of other delegations, they could not get a majority because the rest of the world does not agree with them.

It is interesting to note in all of this reliance, supposedly, on resolutions 678 and 1441 that paragraph 14 of resolution 1441 requires that the Security Council be kept seized of detail—a clear message that there was not an automatic endorsement of unilateral action by a few countries. Similarly, it is interesting that, if there is support for this in previous UN resolutions, the original draft of 1441 included a specific clause to allow this. It was deleted because it could not get support at the UN. So this argument that we can rely on resolutions years ago, when they failed to get endorsement in this last fortnight, is an extremely weak argument.

I will move now to al-Qaeda. When this started there was great endorsement of the US and its war against terrorism, as there still is, but Thomas Friedman, a noted authority in the Middle East—and many members might have read some of his books—said that the US has been `big on attitude, weak on strategy and terrible on diplomacy'. The former National Security Adviser Brzezinski said:

quote.para: The concern I have is that our single-minded and, unfortunately, rather demagogic fixation on Iraq is undermining the credibility as well as the legitimacy of US leadership.

speech.para: They had international support in dealing with al-Qaeda and Afghanistan but the world has little faith in the US argument that al-Qaeda is somehow aligned with Iraq. The United States have even dropped that off in the last few months. Instead of this supposed connection that they were going to establish and prove to the world, they are now saying, `They are not really connected, but they have these weapons that might get into the hands of terrorists.'

Quite frankly, if you look at the state of Russia these days and the kinds of people who are getting 10c a week for work in former laboratories there and the evidence we have of materials being smuggled into Europe illegally and the situation in Pakistan, this argument that we had better knock them over before they provide weapons to terrorists is condoning American policy of world hegemony where they act against anyone and everyone.
In regards to the way in which the US has handled this, it is interesting to note the comments of Robin Cook, in his speech in the House of Commons this week. He said:

quote.para: The reality is that Britain is being asked to embark on a war without agreement in any of the international bodies of which we are a leading partner—not NATO, not the European Union and, now, not the Security Council.

To end up in such diplomatic weakness is a serous reverse. Only a year ago, we and the United States were part of a coalition against terrorism that was wider and more diverse than I would ever have imagined possible. History will be astonished at the diplomatic miscalculations that led so quickly to the disintegration of that powerful coalition.

speech.para: He is saying that the US has squandered international sympathy in regard to its action against Islamic fundamentalism because it has become so single-mindedly obsessed with Iraq, a country which historically has been among the most secular, if dictatorial, in the Middle East. It is a country that has been condemned by bin Laden because of its lack of religious beliefs. Now we are going to move in there supposedly because of an alleged adherence.
In the journal Arms Control Today, January/February 2003, John Steinbruner said:

quote.para: Under prevailing circumstances of access, it would be impossible to identify and disable all dedicated terrorists and rogues before they have accomplished nefarious deeds, and it would be foolish to attempt to do so by national military operations. A campaign of that sort conducted by the United States under the doctrine of coercive pre-emption is more likely to stimulate the destructive application of biotechnology than to prevent it.

speech.para: Furthermore, he said:

quote.para: ... the central contention—that pre-emptive attack can prevent the acquisition of mass destruction technology—is not realistic and does not provide a responsible basis for protecting the United States or anyone else. Preventive action against potentially unmanageable threats is indeed an increasingly vital security interest, but that cannot be accomplished by coercive methods. It will require the systematic exchange of sensitive monitoring information for mutual protection, and arrangements of that sort cannot be established while one party is wielding a confrontational threat against the others. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise today to speak on this very important matter of Iraq and Australia's involvement in a coalition force to disarm Iraq. From the outset, let me state that I am uncomfortable in going to war. However, let me also state that I am even more uncomfortable in allowing a regime like that of Saddam Hussein to have control of weapons of mass destruction. Over 12 years and through 17 United Nations resolutions, Saddam Hussein has failed to rid himself of these weapons. The Labor Party condemns the Howard government for deploying troops to the gulf, but the reality is that, if it was not for the deployment of our troops to stand alongside those of the USA and the United Kingdom drawing a line in the sand, weapons inspectors would never have been allowed back into Iraq in the first place. It has also been extremely disappointing to hear comments from opposition members on this matter that must be giving Saddam Hussein and his regime great satisfaction. They are trying to convince Australians that continuing on the process of warnings for Iraq to disarm will in fact lead to disarmament. But after 12 years, why would Iraq disarm now if there were no threat of military action? After 12 years of Iraq's non-compliance with the United Nations, and after exhausting all diplomatic measures possible, the world is left with no choice but to undertake action.

speech.para: The British Labour Prime Minister, Tony Blair, summed up this point well in his speech this week when he talked about the fact that the world can no longer play the waiting game. He said:

quote.para: What would any tyrannical regime possessing WMD think viewing the history of the world's diplomatic dance with Saddam? That our capacity to pass firm resolutions is only matched by our feebleness in implementing them.

That is why this indulgence has to stop. Because it is dangerous ... if such regimes disbelieve us. Dangerous if they think they can use our weakness, our hesitation, even the natural urges of our democracy towards peace, against us. Dangerous because one day they will mistake our innate revulsion against war for permanent incapacity; when in fact, pushed to the limit, we will act. But then when we act, after years of pretence, the action will have to be harder, bigger, more total in its impact. Iraq is not the only regime with WMD. But back away now from this confrontation and future conflicts will be infinitely worse and more devastating.

speech.para: Unfortunately members opposite are backing away; it is as if the ALP were apologists for Saddam Hussein. If we do not stand up now and confront the problem directly, we are giving Saddam more time to develop weapons of mass destruction. If we do not stand up now, we are sending the message to terrorists across the world that resolutions are not backed up by action.

United Nations resolutions 678, 687 and 1441 were given legal authority to use force to disarm Iraq of weapons of mass destruction. All of these resolutions were passed under chapter VII of the Charter of the United Nations. In resolution 678, the Security Council authorised United Nations member states with all necessary means to liberate Kuwait and restore international peace and security to the area. Resolution 687 imposed a conditional cease-fire on Iraq following the liberation of Kuwait based on Iraqi compliance with obligations to disarm its weapons of mass destruction. It also reaffirms the authority of resolution 678 and refers to the threat to peace and security in the area posed by weapons of mass destruction. In resolution 1441, the Security Council recalls resolution 678 as a relevant resolution to Iraq's weapons of mass destruction disarmament, recalls further that the cease-fire in 687 was conditional upon Iraqi compliance with Iraq's obligation to disarm and decides that Iraq has been and remains in material breach of this obligation. It also gave Iraq one final opportunity to comply, deciding at the time that any Iraqi false statements, omissions in its declarations or other than full cooperation with weapons inspectors would be a further material breach of its obligation.

It is abundantly clear that Saddam Hussein runs perhaps one of the most oppressive regimes in the world, and the oppression of the Iraqi people is something that we have all heard stories about in the past few months in particular. In addressing the threats Saddam's pursuit of weapons of mass destruction poses, it is impossible to ignore his record on human rights. Indeed, his treatment of his own people underlines why he poses such a threat to his neighbours and to the broader international community. Members opposite have been completely silent on these atrocities, but many Australians heard this week a broadcast on the John Laws program when he read a report that was published in Britain by a group called Indict. Indict were recent observers in Iraq and their report details some of the most abhorrent abuses of humans known to man. One example is of opponents of the Iraqi regime being placed alive, head first or feet first, into a shredding machine and the remains of bodies later being used as fish food. Not only is it terrifying that a regime could subject its own people to this sort of treatment, but it is also terrifying to think that a regime like this has weapons of mass destruction.
Human rights advocates such as Amnesty International have also given examples of the atrocities that have occurred. According to Amnesty International:

quote.para: Victims of torture in Iraq have been subjected to a wide range of forms of torture. The bodies of many of those executed had evident signs of torture, including the gouging out of the eyes, marks of severe beatings and electric shocks to various parts of the body, when returned to their families. Some detainees died as a result of torture. Many torture victims now live with permanent physical or psychological damage.

In the mid-1990s Iraq introduced judicial punishments such as amputation of hand and foot, branding of forehead and cutting off of the ears, and many people have been left with permanently mutilated bodies as a result of such punishments.

speech.para: We can also not forget the deadly weaponry and weapons of mass destruction that remained unaccounted for when inspectors left Iraq in 1998. This included 10,000 litres of anthrax, the VX nerve agent program, up to 6,500 chemical munitions, at least 80 tonnes of mustard gas and biological poisons including sarin and botulinum toxin. More recently, Dr Hans Blix said:

quote.para: There is a discrepancy of 6,500 bombs. The amount of chemical agents in these bombs would be in the order of about 1,000 tonnes. In the absence of evidence to the contrary, we must assume that these quantities are now unaccounted for.

speech.para: We cannot turn a blind eye to these unaccounted for weapons, including biological and chemical weapons. We cannot turn a blind eye to the al-Samoud missiles or the drone aircraft that have been recently found by inspectors. The dangers that a regime such as Iraq poses with these unaccounted weapons is frightening, but there are many countries across the world that recognise the need to stand strong and united on this matter. There are now 30 countries that have agreed to be part of the coalition for disarming Iraq. In addition, there are another 15 countries that are cooperating with the coalition and are offering defensive assets should Saddam Hussein use weapons of mass destruction.
What would the Labor Party say to the Kurdish Prime Minister, Dr Barham Salih? This is what Dr Salih said to 60 Minutes reporter Richard Carleton on 16 February:

quote.para: This is not an academic exercise for people here. We have been through this before. People here do not await the outcome of inspections in Baghdad and do not have to wait for the verdict of Dr Blix about whether Iraq has weapons of mass destruction or not. We have come to expect the worst of this regime and people are concerned.

speech.para: When asked about his feelings about American, British and Australian soldiers coming to Iraq to fight a war, the Kurdish Prime Minister said:

quote.para: ... I can understand the sensitivities. I mean, war is not an easy option for people. This should be about freedom, liberation. This is not too different from what happened in Germany and Italy and other parts of the world that were gripped by fascism and dictatorships. I wish we could do it on our own and we did not have to burden other countries to come to our assistance, but we are helpless in the face of tyranny. You cannot be for peace without doing something decisive about this tyranny in Baghdad ...

speech.para: I will conclude today by quoting comments from Elie Wiesel, a Nobel Peace laureate and a Holocaust survivor. He said:

quote.para: The nightmarish question of what such a man might do with his arsenal of unconventional weaponry is why, more than ever, some of us believe in intervention. We must deal sooner rather than later with this madman whose possession of weapons of mass destruction threatens to provoke an ever-widening conflagration. What it comes down to is this: we have a moral obligation to intervene where evil is in control. Today, that place is Iraq.

speech.para: As I said at the start, I am uncomfortable in going to war—but let me also state that I am more uncomfortable in allowing a regime like that of Saddam Hussein to have control of weapons of mass destruction. May the Lord protect the innocent and provide godspeed to an end to this war and the safe return of our troops.

talk.start.para: —First, I present to the House a petition of 619 signatures forwarded to me by Mercy College Captain, Amanda Reckerman, and Deputy Captain, Margaret Costanzo.
(Mr Lindsay)—Member for Wills, under standing orders it is not possible to present a petition in the context of a general debate.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I am happy to provide to the House the text of this petition.
—Thank you.
—The petition states:

quote.para: In the spirit of Catherine McAuley, Foundress of the Mercy Sisters, we value our human family. We are committed to peace on the local, national and global level, and would oppose any course of action that impinges on the rights and freedom of any of our human family. We strive for JUSTICE to all, COMPASSION and MERCY for each individual, and FREEDOM for all of God's people.

We the undersigned strongly oppose declaring war on the Iraqi people.
