We ask the Australian Government to resist the temptation to join this war, to listen to the wishes of the Australian people, to engage in open dialogue with people representing a cross-section of the Australian population, and to explore all other possible course of action so that we can avoid engaging in war. We do not want to see the maiming or death of any of the world's citizens.
We want a peaceful resolution to this current situation, which we believe can be achieved by a patient process of negotiation.

speech.para: As the storm clouds of war gather on our horizon, I welcome this opportunity to expose the perverse and perverted logic that has been the trademark of this government's approach to Iraq. We are told that we are going in there to uphold UN resolution 1441 and other UN resolutions which Saddam Hussein has violated. We are told that he has been flouting UN resolutions for 12 years. If this is so important, why is action only being taken now? Why not in year 1, year 2, year 3, year 4, year 5, year 6, year 7, year 8, year 9, year 10 or year 11? Why now? And why is the UN itself not authorising this action to enforce its resolutions?

If someone breaks the law, we are not allowed to take the law into our own hands and administer punishment ourselves. Without a UN resolution, the coalition of the willing is merely a vigilante gang. One day there will be a motorbike gang with `coalition of the willing' emblazoned on its leather jackets, as `coalition of the willing' becomes a byword for reckless indifference to the rule of law, reckless indifference to proper process and reckless indifference to the suffering of innocent men, women and children that their activities may cause.

We are told that we are going in there to give democracy and human rights to the Iraqi people—but to do this we ignore the democracy of the United Nations. Let us bury the spin of the US and Australian governments that there is no UN resolution because of the French veto. That resolution was withdrawn because it could not get majority support on the UN Security Council. That resolution was withdrawn because it did not have the support of the international community. As of today just five countries, a handful, have committed forces to the invasion.

I heard the Liberal member for Lindsay, Jackie Kelly, referring in her remarks to the German veto. Let me inform the member for Lindsay that Germany is not a permanent member of the UN Security Council, so Germany has no veto. They are not members of the UN Security Council because they were defeated in World War II. It is disconcerting that Liberal members of parliament who are voting today for this war know so little of history.

If it is our duty to bring democracy and freedom to Iraq, are we to stop there? Will the US continue on into Iran? Just last week I had constituents bringing to me heart-rending tales complete with bloody photographs of human rights abuses in Iran. Will the US get the Syrians out of Lebanon? Will the US bring democracy to Saudi Arabia? I suspect not.

We are told that we are going in to fight terrorism, to help secure Australia from terrorism. But the Leader of the House admits that our invasion of Iraq increases the risk of terrorist attack in Australia—and surely he is right. Instead of using all their resources and energies in the fight to capture Osama bin Laden and round up al-Qaeda, the US and Australia are distracted in Iraq. This attack itself will produce more Osama bin Ladens. Deny it as much as you like: this will be seen by some Islamic fundamentalists as an act of religious aggression. Osama bin Laden and al-Qaeda will not be hurt by this; they will profit from it.

I pause momentarily to acknowledge that it is now 12 o'clock—high noon. The deadline set by George Bush for Saddam Hussein has just passed and, from this moment on, the world that we have come to know will change. I want to use the words of freelance journalist Peter Freundlich, who I think summed up the idiocy of the logic of this very well. He says:

quote.para: All right, let me see if I understand the logic of this correctly. We are going to ignore the United Nations in order to make clear to Saddam Hussein that the United Nations cannot be ignored. We're going to wage war to preserve the UN's ability to avert war. The paramount principle is that the UN's word must be taken seriously, and if we have to subvert its word to guarantee that it is, then by gum, we will. Am I getting this right?

Further, if the only way to bring democracy to Iraq is to vitiate the democracy of the Security Council, then we are honour-bound to do that too, because democracy, as we define it, is too important to be stopped by a little thing like democracy as they define it.

Also, in dealing with a man who brooks no dissension at home, we cannot afford dissension among ourselves. We must speak with one voice against Saddam Hussein's failure to allow opposing voices to be heard. We are sending our gathered might to the Persian Gulf to make the point that might does not make right, as Saddam Hussein seems to think it does. And we are twisting the arms of the opposition until it agrees to let us oust a regime that twists the arms of the opposition. We cannot leave in power a dictator who ignores his own people. And if our people, and people elsewhere in the world, fail to understand that, then we have no choice but to ignore them.

Listen. Don't misunderstand. I think it is a good thing that the members of the Bush administration seem to have been reading Lewis Carroll. I only wish someone had pointed out that “Alice in Wonderland” and “Through the Looking Glass” are meditations on paradox and puzzle and illogic and on the strangeness of things, not templates for foreign policy.

speech.para: As shadow minister for the environment, I feel a responsibility to mention to the House some of the environmental impacts of the proposed war. As it happens, millions of birds are making their way across Iraq on their annual spring migration to northern breeding grounds. At this time of year, March-April, you have the greatest number of birds in Iraq and, from a biodiversity point of view, this is the worst possible time of year to have a war. Iraq is on a key migration route for many birds that winter in Africa and breed in Europe and Western Russia in the summer. Iraq's two major rivers, the Tigris and the Euphrates, are an important part of the route for many long distance migrants, including pelicans, storks and the shore birds that breed along the Caspian Sea and in central Asia. It is estimated that, when we had the first Gulf War, tens of thousands of waders were killed on the Northern Arabian Gulf coast. There was approximately a 97 per cent reduction in the number of coastal waders present compared to a previous baseline study. The number of waders remaining in the impacted zone in March to May 1991 suffered an enormous decline, from an estimated 130,000 to approximately 4,000 or less. There are many other environmental issues as well, such as the prospect of acid rain, damage from oil slicks and the like.

When Prime Minister Howard came to power in 1996, he came to power on the back of a memorable promise to make Australians feel relaxed and comfortable. It was a very good line. I felt myself being drawn to it, and I was then a Labor candidate. But seven years later, the Australians I talk to do not feel relaxed and comfortable. They feel tense and frightened, and the Prime Minister's actions in committing Australian troops to invade another country have ensured that Australians will go on feeling tense and frightened for many years to come. Today is a sorry day for Australia and the world. I seek leave to table the text of the petition.
Leave not granted.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on the PM's motion. For the last two days in this place, I have witnessed the concerns and awareness of responsibility all members carry in their role as elected representatives. I watched the Prime Minister's face as he courageously presented his decision to the people of Australia. I commend the Hon. John Howard on his courage when he was faced with such a difficult decision in his elected position as Prime Minister. Many words have been spoken by many for a variety of reasons on this difficult issue and, overall, there has been real concern and real commitment to this country and its people. The time had come for the hard decisions to be confronted and made. We cannot wait for another 12 years or another 17 resolutions while Saddam Hussein continues to rape, abuse, torture and kill more of his own people. World peace will always come at a price. It will always require strong leadership and commitment.

speech.para: As Australians, we must stand together in the face of adversity, stand united as one of the great democracies of the world and accept the majority view. Over and over again in this place, I have heard only three countries mentioned: America, the United Kingdom and Australia. But there is more to this story. There are 30 countries—I repeat, 30 other countries—which have agreed to be part of the coalition for the disarmament of Iraq, and each of these countries is contributing in its way what it deems appropriate to the disarmament of Iraq and the destruction of its weapons of mass destruction. In addition to these 30 countries, 15 or so countries are cooperating with the coalition. Let us now look at the major players who have chosen to ignore UN resolutions 678, 687 and 1441. I will go back in history a little.

As a member of the New South Wales Parliament, I joined a group of parliamentarians in a protest against the French nuclear testing in the Pacific. It took the wrath and commitment of many countries to force France to stop the testing. And this is the country that would not assist the many people who are suffering under Saddam's regime. And what of the hypocrisy of Germany? That country would not support the disarmament of Iraq, whose list of chemical suppliers, dated from 1998 to today, contains 31 major suppliers and 14 of them are from Germany. The nuclear suppliers list, dated from 1996 to today, has 62 company names on it and 33 of them are from Germany. What makes this even more disturbing is that Germany is a signatory to the chemical weapons convention, the European convention on the prohibition of chemical weapons and the UN sanctions on Iraq. This is hypocrisy at its worst.

No sane person wants or agrees with war, but this government believes that the decision it has taken is not only right but also legal, despite the endless debate from the `legal beagles'. Since September 11 we have all faced a different world: a world that is scary, where people have become unsure and afraid of the terrorist culture which followed that terrible attack in New York. The whole world's security is threatened by Saddam Hussein's regime—a brutal, cruel dictatorship. It may not be a direct threat to Australia, but it is a grave threat that Iraq is led by a mad dictator who is in possession of chemical and biological weapons. Despite the UN calling 17 times by resolution for him to disarm, he has continually refused to do so. We must keep in mind that he has used these weapons against his country's own men, women and children.

In the electorate of Hume, which I represent, I have faced a vigorous and sometimes vicious and threatening campaign by a vocal minority, but many constituents have quietly told me that they agree totally with John Howard's decision. Most of them are well informed with facts and have indicated that Saddam Hussein must be stopped and that the suffering of his people must end. This demonstrates what I have always known: Australians are well-informed, fair-minded citizens of the world. They are not influenced by the spin doctors and they are prepared to make sacrifices to liberate the Iraqi people from a bestial tyrant. Hume constituents are aware that the end of Saddam's regime will diminish the number of Middle East states which sponsor terrorism. We must send a very clear and concise message to other countries that such behaviour, such defiance of the UN, cannot be tolerated. It will also mean the end to Saddam's dictatorship, the end of his role as a sponsor of terrorism and the end to his menacing nuclear weapons program.

I take a moment now to acknowledge the professional dedication of the men and women of the Australian Defence Force who are proudly serving their country away from their families and friends. I salute each and every one of them. I pray for their safe return and remind them that they have the support of the majority of their fellow Australians. Godspeed to all of you. I have heard some people complain that the credibility of the US has been damaged by war without the approval of the Security Council. I remind all of them that a US coalition intervened in Bosnia and Kosovo in the 1990s to stop ethnic cleansing and genocide while the United Nations stood by, wringing its hands and doing nothing.

Enough is enough. Saddam Hussein must be disarmed and his people freed of this brutal regime. As I said at the beginning of my contribution to this debate: the decision that has been taken by the Prime Minister was not taken lightly. It was a decision that needed to be taken in the interests of world security and any future threat that may occur as a result of the sponsoring of terrorism by dictators such as Saddam Hussein. It was a decision that needed to be taken to ensure that the long-term security of this country is protected. More importantly, it was a decision that had to be taken by a Prime Minister who is willing to put himself before the people—as he has done in the past—to make very difficult decisions that many Australians may not like. I am sure the bulk of Australians will applaud and congratulate the Prime Minister on these decisions.

In closing, as I said earlier, none of us likes war. None of us likes to see our children, our friends and our relatives going to war. War is the most horrific thing that can happen to the population of this world, and I am sure that there is not one person in this place or, indeed, in this country, who would openly say that they support war of any kind. I will just make some brief comments on the point that I made about visiting Mururoa Atoll during the 1990s, when the French were arrogantly testing nuclear weapons. I went to that place in the company of people who have a different ideology to me—people who are very strong on human rights. I want to place on record here today that many of those people who are sanctimoniously criticising the government and the Prime Minister for making this decision are the very same people who went to protest against France's contribution to the arrogant testing of atomic bombs in the Pacific.

In closing I want to say, as have many of my parliamentary colleagues, that I totally support this motion and that I am totally behind and supportive of the Prime Minister and his cabinet for the very difficult decision that they have made in committing Australia to the US-led coalition.

talk.start.para: —I wish to add my voice to those who oppose this unjust war. This morning the Secretary-General of the United Nations, Kofi Annan, said:

quote.para: Whatever our differing views on this complex issue, we must all feel that this is a sad day for the United Nations and the international community.
I know that millions of people around the world share this sense of disappointment, and are deeply alarmed by the prospect of imminent war.
... in the short term, the conflict that is now clearly about to start can only make things worse—perhaps much worse.
I am sure all members of this Council will agree that we must do everything we can to mitigate this imminent disaster, which could easily lead to epidemics and starvation.

speech.para: When the Prime Minister spoke in Denpasar at the memorial service for the victims of the Bali bombing, I think he represented this country well. He spoke of the tremendous, easygoing, adventurous spirit of young Australians travelling the world, being open to other cultures and meeting everyone as friends and of how he was sure that that would continue. But how will the rest of the world view Australian travellers now? Will they see us as representatives of an egalitarian people from a diverse and tolerant society or will they see us as warmongers?

In World War I, Australia fought as part of the British Empire—that was who we were—but the experience at Gallipoli helped forge our own separate national identity. In World War II, we fought a just war against fascism. In Korea, we were part of a force with UN backing against aggression. In Vietnam, the coalition government of the day lied to the Australian people by telling this parliament that South Vietnam had requested our assistance. In the first Gulf War, we were part of a UN force, as we were in East Timor. There is no UN mandate here. We are not bringing peace; we are invading a sovereign country and making war. This is an unjust war without UN backing.

The comments of the Prime Minister and those in the government in trying to justify our involvement have been nothing short of disgraceful. We have heard a lot about the evils of Saddam Hussein. There is no doubt that it is correct that he is an evil tyrant who has oppressed his own people. But, in the Gaza Strip this week, six Palestinians in a refugee camp were killed by the Israeli army, including a toddler shot in the head. What is the government saying about that? What is our government saying about the death of an American peace activist—23-year-old Rachel Corrie—crushed by an Israeli army bulldozer? Ariel Sharon has already ruled out any so-called `roadmap for Middle East peace' proposed by the Americans. He has declared that Israel will continue its occupation of Palestine in defiance of UN resolutions. What is the government saying about that?

Our government is about to redefine us in the eyes of the world as willing backers of US militarism. We had three nations meet in the Azores: the United States, the United Kingdom and Spain. We were not even invited to the meeting which determined that there would be war! The Prime Minister took a phone call and immediately said yes to President Bush, because we all know that that decision was made many months ago, before the predeployment of troops. We were not even at the meeting where the decision was made, and yet one of the nations which was at the meeting—Spain—is not sending troops to this war. Just three nations are sending troops: the United States, the United Kingdom and Australia. What does that say about the sort of nation that we are? We are a multicultural nation, and yet here we are sending a message, particularly to the Islamic world, that we are a part of the old, white, Anglo-Christian order—and we have the President of the United States who invokes God in defending his government's actions. I say that Islamic fundamentalism is a danger and a threat, but I also say that Christian fundamentalism is a danger and a threat. We should not be revisiting the Crusades, because that is how this war is being perceived by the international community.

We have heard a lot of criticism of France and its statement that it might use its veto, and yet it indicated very clearly that, if we were to wait just one month, it would take the veto off the table. But let us have a look at the record of vetoes. The United States has used the veto 76 times—35 of them on resolutions on Israel. During the 1980s, the United Nations was concerned with Saddam Hussein's use of chemical weapons—provided by US corporations with the backing and sanction of the US government. On 21 March 1986 the Security Council President, speaking on behalf of the Security Council, stated that the council members were:

quote.para: ... profoundly concerned by the unanimous conclusion of the specialists that chemical weapons on many occasions have been used by the Iraqi forces against Iranian troops ... [and] the members of the Council strongly condemn this continued use of chemical weapons in clear violation of the Geneva Protocol of 1925 which prohibits the use in war of chemical weapons.

speech.para: The United States voted against the issuing of this statement. What hypocrisy! The United States was then supporting Iraq against Iran, because it knew that Iraq—whatever the criticisms of Saddam Hussein—was, and remains, a secular nation. It has no connections with al-Qaeda or with Islamic fundamentalism. Indeed, Osama bin Laden will be very happy with the decision of the so-called coalition of the willing to go to war.

Iraq does not represent a threat to Australia. We are, with this decision, supporting a pre-emptive strike, which changes forever the way that international politics works. The United Nations has been extremely damaged, not by its own actions but by the actions of the United States, the UK and Australia. There are alternatives to war. The UN weapons inspectors were doing their job, and we should have allowed them to finish that job. The great contradiction was pointed out by Robin Cook, in his courageous speech, when he said:

quote.para: Ironically, it is only because Iraq's military forces are so weak that we can even contemplate its invasion. Some advocates of conflict claim that Saddam's forces are so weak, so demoralised and so badly equipped that the war will be over in a few days.
We cannot base our military strategy on the assumption that Saddam is weak and at the same time justify pre-emptive action on the claim that he is a threat.

speech.para: That contradiction is very stark, as is the contradiction when you open up the Daily Telegraph of last week and see `the mother of all bombs'. Here we are talking about weapons of mass destruction, but the Western powers are proudly saying, `We've got a bomb which is the most powerful non-nuclear weapon ever produced.' Do you think that is not going to kill civilians? This is an outrage, and we should not be a part of it.

In conclusion, the argument that we have on this side is very much with the government's decision; it is not with our forces in the Australian Defence Force. We hope that each and every one of them is able to return safely to Australia. But it is our argument that they should not be there. The best way to keep those forces safe is for them to return as soon as possible. We do need regime change in some places of the world—it would certainly be a good thing in Iraq—but it should be brought about peacefully, just as we should bring about a peaceful regime change against this warmongering government. (Time expired)

talker.name: Hockey, Joe, MP
Mr HOCKEY
talker.role: Minister for Small Business and Tourism

talk.start.para: —I say at the outset that I fully understand the anxiety and concern of the people of my electorate who have expressed to me a view that they obviously would prefer that there be no war with Iraq. I share their view. I would prefer, as I think all Australians would prefer, that there be no war with Iraq. War can inflict horrific pain on fellow human beings, it creates economic devastation and it can have flow-on effects that we could never possibly foresee at the time that we are in a position to have to send our troops into battle.

speech.para: We are undertaking this partnership with 30 other nations. We have committed our troops, with the leadership of the United States and with Great Britain, on the basis that we see Iraq's behaviour as a material threat to the safety of our nation and our people. There are two tests. The first is: does Iraq have weapons of mass destruction? Even the shadow foreign affairs minister, the Labor Party spokesman, Kevin Rudd, has publicly accepted, as have numerous members of the Labor Party, in agreement with us, that Iraq does possess weapons of mass destruction. There are 10,000 litres of concentrated anthrax that are as yet unaccounted for in Iraq. The fundamental point is: if you can get heroin from Afghanistan onto the streets of Sydney and Melbourne today, you can get anthrax from Iraq onto the streets of Sydney and Melbourne. We cannot wrap ourselves in a cocoon and pretend that we are isolated from the world.

The second point is: does Iraq support terrorism? There is irrefutable evidence that Iraq supports terrorist activities, and there is no more irrefutable evidence than Saddam Hussein publicly and openly, on television broadcasts around the world, presenting cheques for $US10,000 to the families of Hamas suicide bombers—rewarding their families for, in their view, the ultimate act of sacrifice.

The war with Iraq is going to be a long war. It will be a short battle—at least we all hope that will be the case—but the war involving Iraq will be long because it is one part of the broader war against terrorism. Laurie Oakes reported in yesterday's Bulletin a speech by James Woolsey, the head of the CIA during the Clinton administration, in which he quite properly enunciated the argument that we are now in the middle of the fourth world war. The First World War was, of course, triggered with the assassination of Archduke Ferdinand. The Second World War was triggered by the invasion of Poland. The third world war, if you like, was triggered by Winston Churchill's `Iron Curtain' speech on 5 March 1946. That war—the Cold War—ended in 1989 with the pulling down of the Berlin Wall.

The fourth world war started on 11 September 2001, when nearly 3,000 people from about 40 different countries died in the World Trade Centre at the hands of a terrorist attack. Four Australians died in the World Trade Centre attack. That war began because we in the Western world have taken for granted the fundamental principle that you are better off if you aspire to certain levels of success. We take it for granted that the world wants to be democratic and we take it for granted that so many impoverished people across the world have access to the material pleasures that we have.

What convinced me in this debate and about this debate is the link between Iraq and terrorism and the fact that we are in a war against terrorism that will be solved perhaps 20 per cent or 30 per cent by military action. But making up the other 70 per cent must involve addressing the fundamental core reasons for terrorist activity. We must have such a remedy.

Nothing I have seen has been more distressing than Palestinian refugee camps in Lebanon, in Jordan and on the Gaza Strip. You can meet third generation Palestinians who have no sewerage and no water, and up to eight people can be living in a small room. Each night the consistent factor across all the refugee camps is their access to television. Every day and every night they watch TV and they see beautiful people in beautiful cars and in beautiful houses, people with wonderful education attending wonderful restaurants that provide beautiful food and they say, `I can never have that.' And increasingly a younger generation, at times up to a third generation, are discovering that they can find more hope in death than in life. As access to information becomes more prevalent across the world, as more people have access to information, we in the West are going to have to deal with the fact that the aspirations that we hold dear and the fundamental rights and entitlements that we take for granted are not going to be the same for all people across the world.

The war with Iraq of course does involve military action, and it must, for all the reasons the Prime Minister outlined. But the challenge for Australians—every Australian—is to understand that we must be part of an overall response to the war on terror not just by sending our military to do the job but through our own financial commitment. We need a worldwide, modern equivalent of the Marshall Plan. In June 1947 George C. Marshall proposed that there must be both an economic response and a political response to the problems of Europe.

More than 16 countries were liberated in Europe by the United States. But that was political liberation. If we are going to liberate nations from the threat of terrorism, we need to have a similar plan now that involves all the Western nations putting their hands out to support those countries that might need the same basic infrastructure that Europe needed after World War II—the health plans, the education plans and the basic infrastructure that is going to rescue the aspirations of millions of people who at this time have no hope for the future.

This is the challenge. It will not be politically popular in Australia. It is a challenge for the Labor Party and it is a challenge for us to make sure that this war against terror does not end when the final bullet is fired in Iraq. The war against terrorism is a war against poverty and the world must move and plan right now.

talk.start.para: —It is quite eerie to be speaking in this debate right on the deadline that the US has set—the 48-hour deadline for Saddam Hussein to get out of Iraq—to be in a country many thousands of kilometres away debating whether or not we should be participating in military action against Iraq and to be fearful that bombs could be falling as we speak. There is some sense of devastation already for those of us who are very unhappy with the decision that Australia is participating in this military action.

speech.para: I find it depressing to be standing here today. Like many other people in this House on both sides, I find it very upsetting and quite devastating. I, like many other members of the community, feel sick about what will happen to so many people in our community but also in Iraq as a result of this action being taken. In fact, it is hard really to even comprehend the cost and devastation that will be caused by this war and to see if there will really be any winners.

I fear for our soldiers—our service men and women—and for their anxious families. Labor do not agree with the government's decision to send our troops to war but we are proud of our troops. We are proud of you and the efforts that you will make on behalf of our country. We support you, although we do not support the government's decision. We know that you have no choice and will do your duty to the best of your abilities. We trust that our services have trained you well for that. We wish you a speedy and safe return and offer all of our support.

I fear also for the impact on our children and young people in Australia—the anxiety attacks and other behavioural problems—that will inevitably result from the extensive exposure they will have to the images of war in the media. In fact, Young Media Australia has already warned that primary school children are the most at risk, being old enough to understand some of the images that they are seeing and to fear what will happen to them. Young Media Australia urges, as do I, that parents and care givers take extra care at this time to reassure their children that they will be safe. Hugs, cuddles or any other type of reassurance, as well as keeping an eye out for signs of anxiety, are particularly important at this time.

I also fear for our children who are a little older than this because our decision to participate in this action is teaching our children and young people something which will cause great problems in the future. They will get the wrong message about the appropriate way to deal with conflict. We are not teaching our children that violence is the answer to any sort of conflict. I also fear for the Iraqi civilians, especially the women and children, who will inevitably be victims in this war. There are 13 million children in Iraq, and it is estimated that of those some 500,000 are already malnourished and that tens of thousands are likely to die either directly from the military action or from the chaos that will result in the weeks and months following the bombing of Iraq. We also know that the general effects of war are always horrific on women and children. The use of health care services during and after war shows the disproportionate effect on women. We see the economic impact of war treating women much more severely. We know that the militarisation of economies moves funding away from health and education budgets. In some recent conflicts, we have seen sexual crimes used as a deliberate strategy as part of war.

My major concern about Australia participating in this war is the human cost. It seems startling that, as we begin the 21st century with military conflicts such as this one, we have basically shown that we have learnt nothing from the tragedies of war in the 20th century. Not only do I personally share the fears of so many in our community about our nation going to war but also I feel the frustration of standing here in this parliament and not being able to stop what I believe is wrong for our country. It is a key concern for me that this decision will be very damaging to Australia's future as a small to middle sized power and as part of the Asian region. If we abandon our international forums and collective decision making, how will we ever resolve future disputes in this region? What message are we sending to our neighbours? Is it that, if you are big enough or strong enough, you can afford to ignore any of the rules? How can this be right, let alone help our long-term interests as a small to middling sized power? I believe that the international environment as a whole is affected by the approach that has been taken.

What power—moral or otherwise—will we have in the future when North Korea, Sudan, Burma, Syria or any other country decides to flout international law or UN decisions? I, as much as anyone, am disgusted at the brutality of Saddam Hussein and the way he has used his regime against his own people. Like the Kurds and Iraqis who have fled to Australia and who have settled in my electorate, I would like to see their homeland freed and a representative government in place. But is this the way for us to achieve it? And will it actually work? That is a question that no-one seems to be answering at the moment. There is something very unsettling and odd about our seeking to establish democracy in a country by taking military action that did not get the majority support of the UN Security Council. If this were really the concern—the welfare of the Iraqi people—why haven't we talked more about committing to the vital restructure and rebuilding of Iraq that will inevitably be needed after this action has taken place? If we believe our course of action is right, why aren't we talking about committing ourselves to the huge humanitarian effort that will be required and to taking more refugees into this country? The government has been silent on this and, despite the previous speaker, the member for North Sydney, talking very passionately about it, he has not been able to ensure that his government is making those commitments at this time, as it should be.

But I also want to ask: what about all the people who have fled to Australia, escaping the other brutal dictatorships of the world? For example, where is Burma on the US radar of concern to free the world from brutal dictatorships or despots? Furthermore, where is Burma on our government's radar? They may not be amassing military weapons of mass destruction, but their military regime is ensuring that the heroin that they grow and supply around the world is still killing thousands of young people every week—many of them in our country. Why is this abusive, repressive military regime not of more immediate concern to Australia? This is just one example that I have chosen. My electorate is full of people having fled violent, racist, repressive, brutal regimes, and not one of us here in this parliament wants to lend any support to any of those regimes. But I think it emphasises that we must have a policy that looks at our national and regional interests and is consistent on who we go after and why. It must be part of our long-term goals and interests—ours, not just America's. This is where I think the purpose of participating in this war and Australia's involvement in it unravels. Along with the general public, I am really at the point where I am uncomprehending of why we have made a decision at this stage to take this action, without the support of the United Nations.

We teach our young people all the time that they should respect the umpire's decision. Children across the country are being taught that, if there is a disagreement— whether in sport, in the schoolyard or anywhere—the umpire makes the final decision. When we talk about this conflict, the umpire is the United Nations. When it comes to sport, industrial relations or international relations, Labor believes in respecting the umpire, because the bottom line is that it is all that we have to give us consistency, some sense of respecting the rule of law and some sense of legitimacy. I am sad to be standing here today and saying that, when it comes to settling the current crisis, our Prime Minister, who is such a keen cricket enthusiast—in fact, I think he has described himself as a cricket tragic—and who admires these sportsmen who always abide by the umpire's decision, did not like the umpire's decision and decided to play his own game. He has made a bad call in doing this and set a bad example. I fear for this country that we will be much the worse for it in the long term.

talk.start.para: —Forty-five minutes have passed since the deadline, and Saddam has chosen not to take the peace option. In the handful of hours before more than 30 countries join to enforce the internationally agreed conditions of the negotiated peace that followed the 1991 Gulf War, we condemn Saddam's regime for refusing over more than 12 years to abide by the 17 resolutions of the United Nations Security Council regarding the threat it poses to international peace and security. One of the greatest sins I can imagine is to give away a peace previously secured at great human and material cost. It is wrong to turn our backs on what has passed—the purpose and price of previous military engagement. We will remember.

speech.para: I often say that it is the duty of all of us in public life to honour and uphold the freedoms, peace and prosperity that our service personnel, along with our allies, have delivered to all Australians. Our military embodies the finest traditions of service, dedication and professionalism, and has done what has been asked of it by the civilian led governments of the day. The ADF personnel and the veterans before them are all heroes to me, and I add my heartfelt expression of unequivocal support for the Australian service men and women and other personnel serving with the international coalition. Our full confidence is in them, and we hope all will return safely to their homes. In this context I want to make my remarks today about the government's deployment of ADF elements in the region to the international coalition of military forces prepared to enforce Iraq's compliance with its international obligations under successive resolutions of the United Nations Security Council, with a view to restoring international peace and security in the Middle East region.

Opponents of the government's decision, a number of whom have contacted me to convey their views, seek to characterise this action as a unilateral and unjustified attack on Iraq—something new; free of context; a debate that starts with a fresh slate. I have listened carefully to these views—and I have at least tried to listen when they are delivered as interjections at peace rallies—and have considered them against my own thinking. In fact, I have thought very deeply about this issue and have canvassed new aspects of how this debate should proceed, such as challenges of succession in Iraq, diplomatic momentum and inertia, and the parallels with the domestic guns buyback reforms and the liberation of East Timor.

Like many of my colleagues, I am subjected to claims that I am merely parroting government propaganda and personal attacks about lacking courage and guts. Let me assure all concerned that I have mixed feelings about the course of action we are debating here today and have arrived at an on balance view after careful assessment of information, convictions and arguments that all form part of the debate. It has hardly been a journey to exercise machismo. I have asked myself the following three central questions in forming this view on Iraq and weapons of mass destruction. Does Iraq possess weapons of mass destruction? Do these weapons represent a threat to Australia's interests? If so, should we do anything about it?

When Iraq was repelled from Kuwait, military action was ended on the condition that Iraq's weapons of mass destruction capability be disarmed. When UN weapons inspectors were forced out in 1998, many questions remained unanswered about Iraq's arsenal. Saddam's son-in-law subsequently revealed the extent of Iraq's anthrax program and was killed for telling the truth. Saddam has used these weapons before—even in humanitarian atrocities on his own people, which many before me have described. He has displayed a contempt for human life such that innocent people are frequently used as the disposable tools of his totalitarian regime. His regime has invaded two neighbouring countries and bombed five.

As 17 UN Security Council resolutions testify, the existence of these weapons in the hands of a regime with form of this kind in using them threatens global security and the peaceful existence of countless millions of people. The rise in terrorist activity, including senseless attacks on innocent people, adds to the urgency to remove the threat of these weapons and disarm Iraq, as has been insisted on by the UN for more than a decade. As recognised by Hans Blix, military build-up and the credible threat of armed intervention were the only things that achieved a change in Saddam's behaviour and secured the re-entry of weapons inspectors.

I want to thank the governments and taxpayers of the United States of America, the United Kingdom and Australia as the only ones prepared to amass the will, resources and diplomatic momentum to genuinely give peaceful resolution a chance. This coalition put the lead in the diplomatic pencil. While others demanded the right to pontificate and parade around claiming virtue for the limited progress this achieved while contributing precisely nothing to its momentum, they were in fact actively blunting the diplomatic pencil by their actions and statements. I particularly want to pay my respects to the five US service personnel killed in the Black Hawk helicopter accident on 25 February, when their helicopter crashed in a sandstorm during night-time training exercises in Kuwait. Believe me, they have paid a price for the military build-up that has delivered the diplomatic option so many others wish to talk about and build upon.

The `let's have more diplomacy' advocates who are critical of the military build-up ignore the reality that it has only been the military build-up that has produced diplomatic possibilities. To still claim that diplomacy alone will achieve the disarmament of Iraq is to let blind hope triumph over more than a decade of experience. Many people have talked about condemning one, condemning another and condemning governments. They have talked about shame and about who should have the finger pointed at them over this difficult time. The biggest sin we can commit is to ignore the work and sacrifice of those who have come before us. In 1991 thousands of troops paid a price for disarming Iraq and repelling them out of Kuwait. Humanitarian atrocities have been talked about in here. They were added to by that military conflict. The biggest crime is that we need to revisit those things.

Those who should be condemned are those who have allowed us to let go of the peace and the opportunity for stability that the 1991 intervention delivered to us. We have given that away. That is a crime that the international community, including us, should stand condemned for. There was that effort, that sacrifice and that loss of life to secure the repelling of Iraq out of Kuwait and to provide the foundations for the disarmament of this horrendous regime. We have given that away. That is where the condemnation should lie. I wish to return to where I began: it is a great sin to not uphold the work and the achievements of the military personnel who have gone before us. The ADF personnel who were part of the coalition in 1991 did their duty and got so close to the outcome, but the world community dropped the ball on them. They had achieved the repulsion of Iraq out of Kuwait. They had secured a peace plan to see Saddam disarmed of his weapons of mass destruction capability, and we stand condemned for not enforcing it at that time.

This is not a fresh action; this is the enforcement of a peace agreement—an agreement won at great cost to life, to infrastructure and to opportunities, an agreement won at great expense. And we have given it away. We all stand condemned for that. We are debating a motion today about whether to enforce a peace that so many had fought so hard to secure and that we simply did not conclude. It is not a new action. It is not an attack. It is enforcement of a peace plan.

I listen to people condemning the government for not doing anything about humanitarian atrocities in Iraq. The case has been laid out particularly well by those before me—far more eloquently than I have done. But let us not forget why we are here: we dropped the ball. We paid the price to secure a peace and a plan that would ensure ongoing peace in the Middle East and we did not see it through. We all stand condemned for that. I support the government's measures to enforce the peace that those before us had secured. Somehow, we looked the other way and lost what they had worked so hard to deliver to us. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Douglas Hurd was Britain's Foreign Secretary during the 1991 Gulf War. If Douglas Hurd were a member of the Australian parliament instead of the British parliament, he would be a pretty unusual character, because he is actually an intelligent, thoughtful Tory—an intelligent, thoughtful conservative. In the February edition of the Royal United Services Institute for Defence Studies journal, he produced an article entitled `Between peace and war'. In that article he poses two questions. His first question relates to security in the Middle East:

quote.para: Would it be a safer and better place—

speech.para: that is, the Middle East—

quote.para: after a successful attack to overthrow Saddam Hussein?

speech.para: His second question relates to security in the Western world and asks, `What is the effect of the attack on our own safety?' Towards the end of his article, Douglas Hurd indicates that he is somewhat pessimistic in terms of the answers to those two questions. In relation to the question about the Middle East being a safer and better place, he says:

quote.para: A genuinely democratic Iraq might well act as a fresh spur.

speech.para: He is talking about a democratic Iraq in the context of it perhaps being an important initiator of that process elsewhere in the Middle East. He goes on:

quote.para: But everything would depend on the circumstances. At one end of the range of possibilities a new Iraqi government installed by British and American military force and sustained by our occupying troops for months or years after a war in which many Iraqis were killed, could have the opposite effect. The reaction against what would appear as imperialism rather than liberation could be destructive. We might win the war in six days, and then lose it in six months.

speech.para: I think those words are quite instructive—`We might win the war in six days and then lose it in six months.' As I said, Douglas Hurd does indicate that he is somewhat pessimistic in the answers he expects to emerge from his questions. In relation to his question about the effect on the security of the West, he says:

quote.para: It was essentially for self-defence that we went to war in Afghanistan ... We freed the Afghan people from the Taliban, but after Bali, Mombasa and the alarms which sound around us every day, who can say that he or she feels safer now than before the Afghan campaign? We kicked the hornets' nest to pieces, and the hornets buzz more angrily around us. It seems certain that we are now faced with a ruthless long-lasting struggle against growing numbers of Muslim fundamentalists and extreme nationalists through Asia and North Africa who do not hesitate to use violence against the West.

speech.para: He goes on in his article:

quote.para: Do we help or hinder this essential struggle against terrorism by attacking Iraq? Do we increase or diminish the numbers and determination of those enemies? Would we thus turn the Middle East into a set of friendly democratic capitalist societies ready to make peace with Israel, or into a region of sullen humiliation, a fertile and almost inexhaustible recruiting ground for further terrorists for whom Britain is a main target?

speech.para: One might add `and for whom Australia is a main target'. As I said, an intelligent, thoughtful Conservative, Douglas Hurd, the former British Foreign Secretary, indicates that his responses to those questions are pessimistic.

I want to pose a third question: how does this course of action relate to Australian security more directly and to the priority that Australia needs to place on security issues? On previous occasions in this parliament, I have spoken particularly about Indonesia. I notice that as recently as yesterday the Australian Financial Review had an article entitled `US attack may ignite Indonesian anger'. The article says:

quote.para: Muslim leaders in Indonesia reacted angrily yesterday to US President George Bush's ultimatum on Iraq, repeating their strong warning that a unilateral attack could spark violence by Islamic radicals in Indonesia.

speech.para: The story goes on:

quote.para: Indonesia, the world's largest Muslim nation, is strongly opposed to an attack on Iraq without the backing of the UN.

speech.para: I would simply add in this context that there are very few countries more fundamental to Australia's security than Indonesia, and that any serious consideration of Australia's security needs to take account of their views. We need to take account not only of the Muslim world in our own region but of the heavy commitment that Australia is making to the Middle East when, I would strongly argue, we have much more pressing priorities somewhat closer to home.

Earlier this month, the Centre for Independent Studies produced an Issues Analysis paper called `Papua New Guinea on the brink', written by Mike Manning and Susan Windybank. This analysis has been quite controversial in Papua New Guinea, but as a member of an Australian parliamentary delegation to PNG last year I would say that some of the points that are made in the paper really resonate. The paper commences:

quote.para: Papua New Guinea (PNG) shows every sign of following its Melanesian neighbour, the Solomon Islands, down the path to economic paralysis, government collapse and social despair.

speech.para: The paper discusses secessionist movements, particularly those in resource rich parts of Papua New Guinea, such as Bougainville, and says:

quote.para: The government appears to have lost control of parts of the oil-rich Southern Highlands, which are contested by strong men and criminals.

speech.para: It goes on:

quote.para: History has demonstrated that the security of PNG and Australia are inextricably linked. The 60th anniversary of the Kokoda Trail battles last year commemorating the defeat of Japanese invasion forces in PNG ... is a reminder that its territorial integrity is directly related to the defence of continental Australia.

speech.para: The large amounts of aid that successive Australian governments have poured into PNG are evidence of that. The article goes on:

quote.para: It is not necessary, however, for a state to threaten Australia militarily (as in 1942) to cause serious security problems. Should PNG's downward spiral continue so that it unarguably becomes a `failed state', it could attract transnational criminals, people smugglers, drug and arms traffickers—and terrorists. PNG can neither effectively monitor its land and sea borders nor control parts of its territory, making it relatively easy for such groups to slip in undetected and use the country as a base for operations or point of entry into Australia.

speech.para: The article talks about PNG's `porous land border' with the Indonesian province of West Papua in that context and says:

quote.para: The risk that Islamist terrorists may use PNG as a haven cannot be dismissed in light of last year's Bali bombing. PNG's strategic backwater status and institutional instability could provide new opportunities to exploit the weakest link. Terrorists could pay PNG's criminal gangs to assist them with preparations for attacks on Australian soil or against Australian civilians and assets ...

speech.para: Further on, it continues:

quote.para: The ability of Australian authorities and their PNG counterparts to work together effectively on these issues is limited while the central government is unstable and weak, and security forces are rundown and demoralised. Australia has spent over a half a billion dollars since independence on assistance to the PNGDF ... while an AusAID project to strengthen the police force has been running for over a decade. Yet these key state institutions remain under-resourced, poorly equipped and ill-disciplined.
Until recently, there had not been any PNGDF patrols of its land border with the Indonesian province of West Papua in a decade because of resource shortages.

speech.para: The research piece also talks about the risk being high of PNG descending into anarchy. Those are indeed alarming views, but they are put forward by people who are specialists in Papua New Guinea. Mike Manning is an Australian who is now a PNG citizen and is well known, I am sure, to many members of this House. He is a man with impeccable credentials for speaking about PNG. So these are not ill-considered views; they are very serious views—and they are views that are reflected in our discussion about other parts of our immediate region.

For our government to be giving the overwhelming strategic priority it is presently to issues a considerable distance from our shores, when there are extraordinarily important areas within our own backyard that we need to be attending to, strikes me as being extraordinarily negligent. This commitment of forces to Iraq and the unilateral action—or the trilateral action—that appears to be unfolding in Iraq have very serious and damaging long-term consequences for Australia, for the reasons that Douglas Hurd gave in the British context. In the Australian context in particular, this action very directly results in attention being drawn from much more fundamentally important issues that go to the heart of Australia's security. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise today to support the Prime Minister's motion on Iraq. I believe this action is in Australia's best interests and will give the Iraqi people a chance to live peacefully, free from the brutality and lunacy of a tyrant. We can no longer allow Iraq to maintain and build weapons of mass destruction. Saddam Hussein has used these weapons on his neighbours and on his own people. He promotes terrorism, he harbours terrorists and he trains Iraqi children to become terrorists. After 12 years and 17 UN resolutions, diplomatic efforts to free Saddam Hussein of his weapons of mass destruction without a fight have come to an end. We now realise that force is the only way he will be brought to account.

speech.para: The response from my constituents has been very supportive, for the most part. The display of emotion by Dobell community members—their tears and kind words for the brave Australian troops, their concern for innocent Iraqi civilians and their deep-rooted respect for John Howard for making a wise and most difficult decision—has been heart wrenching. Dobell's large veteran population also understands and respects the necessity of the coalition's stance. I salute our Australian Defence Force personnel and wish them a speedy and safe engagement. Last August I had the privilege of working with the RAAF Air Lift Group at Richmond. I was able to see their dedication and the professional way that training and other activities were carried out. They will no doubt carry out their duties with distinction, just as older Australians did in earlier conflicts. I look forward to welcoming them all home, safe and sound.

Australians have never shirked their duty and their sense of responsibility when it comes to international events that may well have had a profound effect on our nation. Iraq is no different a case. The world changed forever on September 11, 2001. Terrorism knows no bounds. Are we to take no action—sit on the fence—and wait for yet another UN resolution in the full knowledge that its 18th resolution on Iraq will be vetoed? Unfortunately, Labor have taken the soft option. They believe the noisy minority and subsequent polls.

Perhaps this matter could have been resolved peacefully if every country had supported a new resolution demanding that Iraq disarm immediately or face the consequences. Saddam Hussein saw that the world was diplomatically divided. He knew that there was little resolve behind another UN resolution and he was therefore smug that no action would be taken to disarm him. The opposition has persistently and blatantly argued for a UN resolution, but the UN lost its force and credibility the moment the French declared that they would veto any resolution that called for the removal of Saddam Hussein's weapons by force.

In this parliament, the member for Indi spoke of France's self-interest and greed behind its peacekeeping stance. This also applies to Germany and Russia, who in their defiance of any resolution to disarm Iraq with force have, ironically enough, ruined any chance for a peaceful outcome. In fact, the prime concern of France, Germany and Russia is neither for the innocent Iraqi civilians nor that a war will promote further terrorism. Their stance has everything to do with their domestic and international self-interests.

Germany's Chancellor, Gerhard Schroeder, won his election narrowly last year due to his anti-war stance on Iraq. He has since stated, in a February speech to the German parliament, that this was the mandate on which he was re-elected and has described his main international orientation as being to prevent wars. For the first time since the Second World War, Germany has formally announced a policy based on openly opposing the United States and seeking to thwart it by building alliances with other states. Mr Schroeder has clearly indicated that Germany's future lies in cooperating with France and the European Union, rather than the United States. In a recent BBC news article, Schroeder said unity with France was indispensable.

Both countries are key members of the European Union and they would most likely wish to see the EU develop as a counterbalance to the unipolar US. Yet Germany, like France, supports the war against terrorism. There are 900 German peacekeepers and 92 special forces personnel operating alongside US and UK troops hunting for al-Qaeda fighters in Afghanistan. Germany and the Netherlands were in command of the International Security Assistance Force in Afghanistan in February to maintain the security of Kabul.

Of 82 million Germans, 3.4 per cent are Muslim, though these are mostly Turkish who are generally less supportive of Islamic radicals. While Germany may have considered the potential for increased terrorist acts within Germany in its decision not to support unilateral action against Iraq, this is in no way the driving force behind their standpoint. German companies have been important suppliers of arms to Iraq since the mid-1970s. This included a deal to build a supergun, for which some German businessmen have been charged. According to a German newspaper, in Iraq's weapons report to the UN, over 80 German companies are listed as dealing with Iraq as late as 2001.

Russia's opposition to war in Iraq is more ambivalent than France and Germany's. Its economy is dependent on oil exports for 40 per cent of its revenue. The cost of producing Russian oil is high and any fall in price below $US25—currently it is $US32—per barrel would affect its economy adversely. In contrast, Iraqi oil is very cheap to produce and Russia fears that any massive increase in the production of Iraqi oil, post Saddam Hussein, would depress oil prices. Russia has been protecting itself in the case of a regime change in Iraq by having discreet talks with the exiled Iraqi opposition regarding future oil contracts. To show his displeasure, Saddam Hussein has suspended the contracts of one of the largest Russian oil companies, Lukoil, to develop its West Kurna oilfield.

Russia is a major buyer of Iraqi oil under the UN oil for food program. Russia is therefore under pressure to assume an anti-war stance on Iraq in return for preferential treatment by the current Iraqi government. Russia is also indebted to Iraq for its support of Russia's campaign in Chechnya and its urging of Muslims within the Russian Federation to not hinder or obstruct Russian activities in any way. Furthermore, Iraq owes $US8 billion to Russia inherited from the Soviet Union days. A US led war against Iraq would dwindle Russia's chances of ever being repaid.

Russia's foreign minister and the German government have cited the threat of increased terrorism as the reason for their stance on Iraq. Australia's opposition leader has also argued that our involvement in this war will generate and encourage terrorism and, as a result, Labor argues that Australia will become more of a target. Would it be safer for Australia to sit on the sidelines while the rest of the world goes and fights for an international cause? Is that the Australian way? I think not.

Terrorism has already occurred on Australia's doorstep. If we do not stop Saddam Hussein from maintaining and using his weapons of mass destruction, these mass weapons will spread among other rogue states and the future of Australia and the rest of the world will be in jeopardy. Our Prime Minister understands that scenario only too well. John Howard has thought long and hard about all the ramifications of the government's decision. He is a man who will make the right decision for the national interest irrespective of popularity. My wish for the people of Iraq is for them to have what we Australians have: freedom, democracy and the right to live in peace.

talk.start.para: —I want to pick up on some of the disgraceful comments made by the member for Dobell before getting to the substance of my speech. He says in this place that Labor has taken the soft option. What a cheek to say that Labor has taken the soft option when we have been advocating that we in Australia take a position which is in Australia's national interest. If you want to talk about soft options, how soft an option was it when your Prime Minister did not do the hard thing on behalf of the men and women of Australia who would have to go and serve and on behalf of the people of this nation when he got the telephone call and say no but did something that was in the interests of the United States of America. You want to talk about taking the soft option: the Prime Minister of this country stopped acting in Australia's national interest and has been acting in the interests of a foreign country. If you want to talk about soft options, talk about that.

speech.para: What has been missing in this debate is any discussion at all about acting in Australia's national interest. It seems to me that the Liberal and National parties cannot understand and have no comprehension of the fact that Australia's national interest could be different from America's national interest. It is amazing that all of these people on the other side in the Liberal and National parties make out they are educated and can understand a few things, yet none of them can grasp this essential difference. We have a Prime Minister who promised us the world, that he would be a hard man for Australia and stand up for Australia's national interest.

I remember very well the advertisements before the 2001 election campaign where we saw the Prime Minister of Australia bang the podium and say, `We will decide. We will make the decision in relation to asylum seekers.' He was prepared to prove that he was pretty tough when he was dealing with a few rickety boats bringing people in need to Australian shores. He was going to be a big, strong man; he was going to be the person who acted in Australia's national interests. That is what he promised us. He said, `We will decide.' Now here we are in a situation where, more than ever, we need an Australian Prime Minister who will decide what is right based on what is in Australia's national interests, not based on what is decided anywhere else.

The Prime Minister has proved that he is not a strong, tough man at all. He is not someone who can take tough decisions. He just goes along with what other people decide. He is so besotted with the American President that whatever George W. Bush asks of him he will do—whatever the price, whatever the cost. What he is interested in is his relationship with George W. Bush. He wants to be George W. Bush's favourite. The price that we pay for his obsession with being George W. Bush's favourite is the damage to our reputation in our region and the risk to the lives of 2,000 Australian personnel who are now deployed as a part of this operation—not to mention the increased risk to Australia's security, which is a logical consequence of Australia's involvement in this very small coalition which is about to invade Iraq.

I heard the member for Dobell say earlier that the opposition have been going around saying that there will be an increased risk of terrorism in Australia. He was making the political point that this was something that only we were saying. I think he has to better acquaint himself with this issue, because a statement was made yesterday by the Director of Homeland Security in the United States that the US and its allies—which includes Australia—would be at greater risk of terrorism as a result of participating in this small coalition of countries that is about to invade Iraq. I say to the member for Dobell: please inform yourself better in relation to this debate, because that statement was made not by the opposition but by the Director of Homeland Security in the United States administration and was repeated in this House yesterday by no less a figure in the government than the Leader of the House and Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, Mr Tony Abbott. So it is not just the Labor Party saying these things; these are well-accepted realities that will be a consequence of Australia's involvement in this military effort in Iraq.

As a proud Australian, as someone who believes in Australia and who understands what this country is capable of, I want to say how disappointed I am to see a Prime Minister who does not share that vision. The Prime Minister does not believe in Australia; he does not believe that we are good enough to make our own way in the world or that we are big enough, strong enough and smart enough to decide things for ourselves. He believes that all we have to contribute is to just go along with the United States. Recently, I said that Bob Menzies had a view of Australia as being just a colony. He used to go to London to get his riding instructions. He was besotted by the British royal family; he had a drooling obsession with them. He used to get his instructions from London, the centre of the empire, and that is how he viewed Australia. Decades on, we have a Prime Minister who still has the same view. The empire might have changed but it is still the same idea: Australia is just an appendage, not a country that can make up its own mind about international affairs or choose its own future and confidently pursue its own national interests. We now have a Prime Minister who only views Australia as being a country which says yes every time to great foreign interests. That is not the vision I have for the future of Australia. That is not the hope that Australians have for what this nation should be. How embarrassing and humiliating for Australia that a decision was made to go to war—Australia included—yet Australia did not participate in that decision.

An important meeting took place in the Azores between the United States President, the British Prime Minister and the Prime Minister of Spain—it was chaired by the Prime Minister of Portugal—where a decision was made to go to war and essentially to deploy Australian troops. And where was our Prime Minister? He was not there. He did not make the decision. We now have a situation where they are running Australia's foreign policy and our defence priorities by remote control. They make a telephone call and our Prime Minister says: `When do you want them? Where do you want them? We'll do whatever you want.' These are not the actions of a Prime Minister who is acting in Australia's national interests.

I want our Prime Minister to be a proud Australian. I want our Prime Minister to stand up for Australia's national interests. I want our Prime Minister to be a strong man—strong enough to stand up for Australia's national interests—not a weak man who just says yes and does whatever other great nations decide would be in Australia's national interests. I want a Prime Minister who can stand up and articulate what Australia's national interests should be. I want a Prime Minister who can confidently pursue Australia's own national interests and develop our own foreign policy agenda that is based on our national interests. We have seen from the Australian Prime Minister disgraceful, weak behaviour at a time when we needed him to be strong on behalf of the Australian nation and strong on behalf of the 2,000 men and women who have been deployed to serve in this conflict. He has taken the weak option and has not acted in Australia's national interests.

talk.start.para: —I listened with some curiosity to the member for McMillan. All you could really say about his little contribution is that it contained some tedious repetition, crossed with a liberal dose of what George Orwell labelled `newspeak'—there really was no substance there. It was a bit disappointing. I would like to support the eight-point motion moved by the Prime Minister on Tuesday. As the Prime Minister pointed out, this is a very difficult decision he has taken, which is supported by the government. It is a difficult decision for Australians and it is a difficult decision for our service men and women who are in the Gulf.

speech.para: I believe it was the correct decision, and a number of reasons have been extensively elaborated by the Prime Minister and other government members on why we should be involved. There are many reasons why we should proceed with this course of action. The Iraqi regime has had 12 years to comply with the cease-fire agreement of 1991. Since that cease-fire, it has continued to refuse to get rid of its weapons of mass destruction and we have had 17 resolutions of the United Nations to try to get it to comply. Over 30 official letters have been sent by the Secretary-General of the United Nations, trying to get some sense out of Saddam Hussein. During all that time he has thumbed his nose at the UN and at world opinion, and he continues to ignore those requests that he agreed to in 1991.

The question we should all be asking is why Saddam continues to manufacture these weapons of mass destruction. These chemical and biological weapons have horrific consequences; we saw that when he used them. I think the reason we should move now was made quite clearly and eloquently by the British Prime Minister when he said that we have Saddam Hussein on one path, making his weapons of mass destruction, and terrorists on a parallel path, and that it is only a matter of time before the two get together. The consequences are quite terrifying. Clearly, if we sit back and do nothing, as the world did in the 1930s—and if I have time I will come back to that—the consequences will be quite terrifying.

I think it is important to note that Australians have seen the tragedy of Bali and know that this terrorism is not something that happens just in New York, or something that happens only to Germans in North Africa—as has been pointed out—or to the French in some other places. It something that is happening right on our doorstep. If anyone is in any doubt about that fact, at least one terrorist organisation—and remember that there are several that we know of—al-Qaeda, has made it clear that since East Timor we are already on the list. So any suggestion that our involvement now in this action will change that is just spurious.

The next point I would like to make relates to the suggestion that not many countries are involved. It is quite clear that speakers who have said that have not really done their homework. As pointed out by Mr Richard Boucher, a spokesman from the US Department of State, 30 countries have agreed to be part of the coalition for the immediate disarmament of Iraq. Amongst those countries are quite a few from Europe and some from the Middle East and from Asia; there are some from our region—for example, the Philippines, Korea and Japan. As pointed out by Mr Boucher, in addition to these 30 countries there are another 15 or so, probably more, that are cooperating with the coalition. So, in fact, a sizeable number of countries in this world share a view about what needs to be done. They certainly support this difficult decision that has been taken, a decision I believe is the correct one.

It has also been pointed out quite clearly that earlier United Nations resolutions authorise this action. The Prime Minister in his speech, and indeed in the motion, made that quite clear when he listed resolutions 678, 687 and 1441 as a clear authorisation by the United Nations for this action. It is also interesting to look at the argument mounted against this action by members of the opposition. I noted with interest an article by Paul Kelly in yesterday's Australian. He said in part:

quote.para: The Labor position has a distinctly French look. ... Australian forces should be returned from their Gulf deployment. But the 225,000 US forces threatening Iraq must remain in place to encourage Saddam Hussein to co-operate with the weapons inspectors. The objective remains the disarmament of Iraq's WMD capacity. Crean, like Chirac, insists this can be achieved by peaceful means but, like Chirac, he won't accept any responsibility for its enforcement.

speech.para: As Paul Kelly says:

quote.para: This is a popular but bankrupt stance.

speech.para: It is also interesting to go back a bit and have a look at the transcript of a BBC program broadcast at the beginning of February which was presented by Alistair Cooke, whom I think most people would know of. He is a rather wise person. In this particular letter he made some very chilling points. He said:

quote.para: ... throughout the past fortnight I've listened to everybody involved in or looking on to a monotonous din of words, like a tide crashing and receding on a beach—making a great noise and saying the same thing over and over.
And this ordeal triggered a nightmare—a day-mare, if you like.
Through the ceaseless tide I heard a voice, a very English voice of an old man—Prime Minister Chamberlain saying: “I believe it is peace for our time” — ...

speech.para: A sentence the context of which I am sure all honourable members will recall. He went on to point out:

quote.para: ... a sentence that prompted a huge cheer, first from a listening street crowd and then from the House of Commons and next day from every newspaper in the land. There was a move to urge that Mr Chamberlain should receive the Nobel Peace Prize.

speech.para: We all recall what happened after that. Alistair Cooke went on to say:

quote.para: I bring up Munich—

speech.para: he then goes into quite a lot of detail about what happened—

quote.para: and the mid-1930s, because I was fully grown, on the verge of 30, and knew we were indeed living in the age of anxiety.
And so many of the arguments mounted against each other today, in the last fortnight, are exactly what we heard in the House of Commons debates and read in the French press.
The French especially urged, after every Hitler invasion, “negotiation, negotiation”.
They negotiated so successfully as to have their whole country defeated and occupied.

speech.para: He goes on:

quote.para: In Britain, the general response to every Hitler advance was disarmament and collective security.
Collective security meant to leave every crisis to the League of Nations. It would put down aggressors, even though, like the United Nations, it had no army, navy or air force.

speech.para: Those are very chilling words. It is a warning, if ever there were one, that it is a question not of just being popular but of taking responsible action at a time when you can take it, before it is too late and before, inevitably, weapons of mass destruction get into the hands of terrorists and appear anywhere in the world—heaven forbid, even in Australia. That is why the Prime Minister is to be congratulated on his courageous decision. His decision is fully supported by the government and, interestingly, it is now quite strongly supported by the general public in Australia.

A couple of straw polls have been in the wind in the last couple of days. In the Herald Sun today, the following question was put: Now Australian troops are committed, are you in favour of war in Iraq? `Yes', said 75.4 per cent. On the John Laws program two days ago, John Laws said:

quote.para: We've had very close to 9,500 telephone calls in less than 2½ hours, which is extraordinary.

speech.para: He asked:

quote.para: Is John Howard right to commit Australian troops to war in Iraq?

speech.para: The result was that 86.39 per cent said, `Yes, he is right.' It may not be conclusive, but it is quite significant and it is quite a strong indication that the people of Australia do realise that the Prime Minister is making a courageous decision—the right decision—and it is one that they are getting behind.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on the Prime Minister's motion and to speak in support of the Leader of the Opposition's amendment to that motion. We are on the eve of a substantial conflict, but it is a conflict that the American administration came to through no easy step of its own. It is a conflict that has generated much debate within the American administration—indeed, much internal division. Our concern—and my concern—as Australians who are now committed to this particular conflict is the regional implications of what has transpired and the changing face of geopolitical realities as a consequence of the United States's commitment to pre-emptive action.

speech.para: This is not a commitment that the United States made lightly. I am a very strong supporter of the American alliance, as is the Labor Party.
