The same applies to the current situation in Iraq. France's determination to use its veto, for whatever political or commercial reasons, prevents a united approach. It does not make the need for action any less compelling. Last week, a last-ditch effort to secure a united front with a British compromise proposal to strengthen the inspections regime by laying down six very clear and tangible benchmarks for Iraq's compliance was rejected. Remarkably, France rejected those even before Iraq did. France had made it abundantly clear that they were not interested in supporting any further resolutions to apply increased pressure on Iraq. On the one hand they assert a desire to see Iraq disarm but on the other they reject any efforts to secure that compliance.

Tragically, there will be loss of life in Iraq. Yet just as tragic is the ongoing loss of life, the continuing suffering caused by Saddam Hussein's campaign of genocide and torture—a record that has cost hundreds of thousands of lives over the past decade or so, that has some four million Iraqis living in exile, that has caused Iraqi refugees in Australia and other countries to urge military action to free their country of this tyrant. In weighing the moral case for action, the cost of inaction must be considered.
I will quote a small part of a speech made last month by Jose Ramos Horta, the Nobel peace prize winner, called `Counting the cost of war', in which he said:

quote.para: It would certainly be a better world if war were not necessary. Yet I also remember the desperation and anger I felt when the rest of the world chose to ignore the tragedy that was drowning my people.
We begged a foreign power to free us from oppression, by force if necessary.

So I follow with some consternation the debate on Iraq in the United Nations Security Council and in NATO. I am unimpressed by the grandstanding of certain European leaders. Their actions undermine the only truly effective means of pressure on the Iraqi dictator: the threat of the use of force.

speech.para: He concluded:

quote.para: History has shown that the use of force is often the necessary price of liberation.
A respected Kosovar intellectual once told me how he felt when the world finally interceded in his country: “I am a pacifist. But I was happy, I felt liberated, when I saw NATO bombs falling.”

speech.para: Iraq must be disarmed. No-one but the most naive would deny that. The threat to world security posed by chemical and biological weapons being supplied to terrorist organisations is unthinkable. The mentality demonstrated on September 11, in Bali or in any number of other terrorists attacks—a mentality which deliberately inflicts maximum suffering on innocent civilians—will use the most potent weapons available. This, combined with a number of repressive and tyrannical regimes such as Iraq which either have or are developing such weapons, presents a frightening prospect to the world.

When weapons inspectors left Iraq in 1998, large quantities of these weapons materials were unaccounted for. In fact, in 1991 Iraq had been given 15 days to fully declare its stocks of weapons of mass destruction and 90 days to destroy them. After 12 years of defying 17 United Nations resolutions—some authorising the use of force in the event of non-compliance—which required Iraq's total disarmament of weapons of mass destruction, this has still not been achieved.

The other point which is so important is that the resolve of the world's free nations and the credibility of the United Nations are at stake here. If, after so many ultimatums, the United Nations and world leaders had simply walked away from this, their authority would have been greatly diminished. If they had failed to take action, no future ultimatum to Iraq or any other tyrannical regime would have been taken seriously.

I make two other points. Firstly, after this conflict is over we must make a serious commitment to addressing the humanitarian needs of the Iraqi people. I note that Australia has made an initial commitment of $10 million to international aid agencies for immediate contingency planning and preparedness. This will enable a start to be made with food, water, sanitation and health care. The government has made it clear that this is only the start and that more will be forthcoming.

Our support needs to be substantial and continuing. We must work with the United Nations and NGO aid agencies to provide further and ongoing financial, logistic and personnel support. We must also work with multilateral agencies where we can to assist with Iraq's reconstruction. These obligations will not be short lived. Australia, along with all UN members, must and will play its part in helping to rebuild Iraq and improve the life of its people. The recent pledge by Britain, the US, Spain and Portugal to protect Iraq's natural resources, particularly its oil, for the Iraqi people will certainly help. So too will the end of the regime of international sanctions.

The last point I make is that, regardless of our opinions on this war, we must give our utmost support to Australian Defence Force personnel serving in the gulf. These outstanding young men and women serve their country with distinction, regardless of the political debates that may rage around them. Their commitment to duty and to their country is pre-eminent, and we greatly admire them for that. We pray for a speedy and safe return for all.

talk.start.para: —I start by sending a message to our Defence Force service men and women who are now at war in Iraq and to their families back here in Australia, who are no doubt feeling increasingly anxious about the safety of their loved ones. The Australian Labor Party fully support our military personnel in the Middle East and pray for their safe and speedy return home.

speech.para: It is true that we do not believe the Prime Minister has made the right decision in committing our forces to a US led pre-emptive strike on Iraq, but we will never waver in our support for our troops. They are not asked their opinion on whether the government should commit to war; nor would they offer one. They have a legal and moral duty to act as the government of the day instructs them. In this they do not have a choice. I have every confidence that they will serve Australia with great courage, skill and honour. We also pledge our support to their families and their loved ones at this difficult time.

It is estimated that the war will cost Australia $900 million. Uniquely, those same troops who have been sent to the Middle East can be comforted in the knowledge that Defence will be paying for the war. There has been $660 million ripped out of Defence this year, and in total $900 million over the next two years. This is John Howard's L.J. Hooker war, which the proceeds of Defence land sales will fund.

Today we are debating a motion to send our troops to war. This motion reflects a decision by the Prime Minister that he took in July last year. We are stripping away the pretences of being or not being in the coalition of the willing. The only one left who denies or doubts that Australia always was in the coalition of the willing is the Prime Minister himself—the very person who perpetrated the canard in the first place. Howard government members say they are against the war but they willingly locked into the war months ago. Before a shot is fired, the first casualties are the small `l' liberals. Already vanquished, they have been totally neutered and muted.

The formal decision to go to war was taken in the Azores, where Spain and Portugal—which are not sending troops—made the formal decision that Australian troops should go to war. No-one disputes that war will have terrible consequences for Iraqis, but it is the consequences of war for Australia that are likely to impact most on Australians, for a long time. Even Minister Abbott agrees with that. A former secretary of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has said that this is the worst Australian blunder in 50 years. The Prime Minister says that this is not a war against Muslims but he fails to demonstrate how this perception will not grow amongst them.

Much has been said by coalition members about what a terrible tyrant Saddam Hussein has been, what a murderous dictator he is and how he persecutes his own people. No-one disputes that. What is disputed is why we should suddenly act now. Why is this humanitarian argument so forceful today? The very same argument does not apply to North Korea, does not apply to Syria and does not apply to Zimbabwe. What humanitarian action is the government proposing in those cases? Absolutely nothing.

There is no link between Saddam Hussein and September 11 or Bali. September 11 and Bali were terrible events. We should be embarrassed in no way, and on no account, in tracking down those who perpetrated September 11 or October 12; but no-one has been able to demonstrate that Saddam Hussein and the Iraqi regime are directly linked to al-Qaeda, Jemaah Islamiah or any other terrorist organisation. It is true that Saddam Hussein's regime has weapons of mass destruction—that it has awful chemical weapons—but no-one has established that they have been given to any terrorist organisation. That they should be eliminated is beyond question. That the regime should be changed is beyond question. But surely it behoves those who have now launched this war to establish the direct connection.

As much as we might like one, there is no direct connection between Saddam Hussein and terrorist organisations, or Saddam Hussein and the giving of weapons of mass destruction to terrorist organisations.

It is true to say that the Australian Labor Party are very proud of our relationship with America. After all, it was a Labor wartime government that made the critical decision to turn away from the UK for our own security and to look to the United States. In the Labor Party we have never had a craven attitude to the UK and we have never had a craven attitude to the United States of America. We have had a grateful attitude, we have welcomed their support and we have been very loyal and faithful allies but we are not subservient; we are not craven. We will occasionally disagree—and we need to disagree in this instance. Not one member country in our region is a member of the coalition of the willing. No member country in our region is committing troops to this war on Iraq.

We are urged all the time by those who are expert and by the Australian people to be self-reliant to the maximum extent possible. We need to try and protect Australians, Australia and our interests. Unlike America, we cannot stand alone. If we want to protect this country against terrorist attacks, we utterly and absolutely need the assistance and cooperation of people in our region. Has John Howard, at any time in this Iraqi crisis, led a mission through countries in our region to explain our position? Of course not. Not even the foreign minister has been sent on such a mission. In fact, we sent a civil servant to talk to our neighbours to explain our position.

I do not think it is fashionable these days to have doubts and uncertainties, but I have doubts and uncertainties about what has been embarked upon today. There can be certainties about the outcome of the war. There can be certainties about the impact and devastation on the Iraqi people but what will be the outcome? Are not people within Middle Eastern countries—whether they are Muslims, Copts, Christians, Jews or any other religion—entitled to go to bed at night safe? Are they not to enjoy having a home and work? Are they not to enjoy being able to live in peace? In this 21st century, is it impossible for us to say that we can have peace and cooperation in the Middle East? If just one half of all the determination and money that is going into the war in Iraq, went into peace, humanitarian aid and good governance, I am sure the people of the Middle East would be better off. And I am sure the world as a whole would be far better off.

talk.start.para: —I think I echo the view of all in this House when I say that nobody wants war. I stand today to place on the record my considered support for the government's commitment of Australian troops to disarm Iraq of its weapons of mass destruction and ensure compliance with all the UN resolutions made on the subject.

speech.para: It is fair to say that the people in the electorate of Forrest have mixed views on this issue. I want to place on the record my gratitude to all those who have made the effort to ring, write or email me to give me their views and opinions. I have spoken to many who have strongly supported the government's stance, as well as those who oppose war at all costs. That is the point, though. There will be costs if the world allows Saddam Hussein to continue to pursue and possess weapons of mass destruction; it sends a very serious message to other rogue states. It could also result in those weapons coming into the possession of those who seek to make fundamentalist religious points by wreaking violence on thousands of innocent people. It could result in a world where international lawlessness is rife, and where the international community is powerless to stop it.

The UN has been calling for Saddam Hussein to disarm for 12 years, passing no fewer than 18 resolutions. Where was the UN Security Council on Rwanda and where was it on Kosovo? Many of the atrocities that were committed in these countries could have been prevented had the Security Council faced up to its responsibilities. The French have largely been culpable in rendering the UN ineffective. Intent on throwing their own weight around, they seem to have forgotten that they have almost rendered the only institution in which they have any weight as ineffectual.

The Australian people should not forget that it was not that long ago that we were boycotting French goods because of France's nuclear testing in the South Pacific and their subsequent detestable actions in the Rainbow Warrior affair in Auckland Harbour, New Zealand. One of my own constituents in Forrest was caught up in this incident and rang to remind me of France's actions. Entertaining despots is a speciality of France, given Mugabe's recent visit there.

I have examined this issue and the evidence and arguments carefully, and I have come to the conclusion that Australia, the US and the UK are doing the right thing. In our post September 11 landscape we cannot afford to walk away from this issue. Merely wishing that weapons of mass destruction will not be used by rogue states like Iraq, or that they will not fall into terrorists hands, will not keep Australians safe. I remember the feelings of anger and helplessness at the time of the Bali bombings. I also remember thinking that we have a duty as parliamentarians—and as a government—to do all we can to protect Australians. We must be sure to act in the national interest. I can understand those who have come to different conclusions and I respect other opinions, but I abhor the way the opposition is playing politics with this issue.

My thoughts and support and those of my constituents are with the men and women of the Australian Defence Force and their families. I encourage my constituents to get behind the `Walk for our Troops' being organised by the Busselton RSL. It is the Busselton RSL's intention to make a show of support for our troops by walking the 250-odd kilometres from Busselton to Perth. The veterans leave Busselton at 7 a.m. on Saturday. I urge all Western Australians to get behind them and the cause of our troops. I am sure that when these proud veterans walk past Campbell Barracks it will be a powerful message to our soldiers. The walk is not meant to be a symbol of support for war but rather a statement for our troops that we understand they are doing a job; they are only playing their part and they take with them our prayers and our support. I trust that this necessary conflict will be short, that it will meet its objective of disarming Iraq and that all our soldiers will return home safe and have the support of all Australians.

talk.start.para: —Iraq: whether the argument comes from so-called doves or hawks I remain unconvinced by the many half-truths and half-debates from either which conveniently and deliberately leave out salient points inconvenient to their particular point of view. There is plenty of synthesis, precious little analysis. Right from the very beginning bipartisanship has not been possible. But it should have been. The only conclusion one can possibly reach by the decision to go to war is one of failure on all sides.

speech.para: Firstly, there is the monumental failure at an international level. The United Nations has failed not only in this debate but also in the previous debates, particularly those affecting the Middle East. The Arab world in particular is rightly offended by the failure of the international community to insist that Israel go back to its 1967 borders. I note there is precious little acknowledgment of the serious Arab world in its efforts to get Saddam Hussein to go into exile. It was, of course, the last shot in the locker but that last shot would have been more effective if the border issue concerning Israel and its neighbours was bedded down in agreement years before. Of course while discussing Saddam Hussein and his murderous elite regime, one can make the point that, if they had any love for their country and their people whatsoever, they would take the opportunity of exile offered by the Arab world. The United Nations, and particularly the Security Council, has been very badly damaged and that fact alone does not auger well for the future security of the world.

I take particular exception to the actions of the French government, supported by the German government, for largely domestic and investment reasons. Both of these countries have huge investments in Iraq. I read in a British publication that in recent months the French oil firm TotalFinaElf signed billions of dollars of oil contracts with Saddam Hussein. If that is true, if that is a significant factor in the French government's action, then not only is the Security Council of the United Nations compromised but so is the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation. Perhaps it is time for France to be replaced on the Security Council by a representative of the European Union. Flagging its intention to veto any second resolution whatever the content gave Bush, Blair and Howard the opportunity to rationalise the dismissal of the UN Security Council. Like Bush, Blair and Howard, Chirac is also flawed on this issue.

The current impotence of the United Nations and the disingenuous grandstanding by the French and German governments in particular have provided a rationale of sorts for the coalition of the willing, albeit flawed. But all the spokesmen for the coalition of the willing have failed too. Their expositions and their politics have faltered badly and failed to even convince citizens in their own lands. It is not only the mass rallies in each of these countries that have proved that. President Bush, Prime Ministers Blair and Howard, Vice-President Cheney, Secretary of Defense Rumsfeld, Foreign Minister Downer and others have all been guilty over the last 12 months of using language and tone that is punctured by threat, aggression, intimidation and heavying that has diminished the hope of a diplomatic solution.

Australians polled on this issue have been unequivocal in their responses. As a majority of nations in the democratic world have indicated, Australians would rest their support on a successful second resolution to resolution 1441. So did I. They did not want war but they indicated pretty clearly that up to 80 per cent would support a United Nations resolution to disarm Iraq by force if necessary. That has all gone. We are now a divided nation.

Although I appreciate the views of some of my colleagues of no war under any circumstances, I am not one of those people. The arguments of no war under any circumstance, including a United Nations resolution, did not convince me. Like the hawks, they too failed to identify all the elements in the debate, conveniently forgetting the plight of the Kurds, the Shiite Muslims, the Marsh Arabs, the educated Iraqi classes—some of whom are in exile—and the failure of 12 years of containment against Iraq. Nor was I convinced by the arguments that this was about American control of Iraqi oil—French or German maybe, but not American. That fails any rational analysis, as does the terrorist target argument. Australia was a terrorist target before and remains so now, admittedly at a much more heightened level. What has changed is more dangerous than that. We could now become the target of rogue states.

But what of the majority of Australian people like me and my constituents who have been dismissed out of hand by this government? They have been disenfranchised, as a citizen would be in a tyrannical state. The Howard government knew what Australians believed. The foreign minister knew. The frontbench knew. The backbench knew. They all knew. As with the Bush administration and the Blair government, the Howard government could not win the debate. That basic tenet is an absolute basis for democracy and dates back to the ancient Greek senate. This loss in the debate must be acknowledged. They lost the debate. That is the real failure. They were incapable of exhibiting the necessary intellect to convince the free world. But where does this leave the majority of Australians? For the first time in the history of this country we are expected to support pre-emptive strikes and be, in theory and practice, the aggressor.

There is a trinity that governs all human behaviour. It is driven by beliefs that it matters what you think, how you try, what you do and that all three are right. It matters that they are right and coherent. In the Iraq situation, I believe that on all sides of this House there is unanimity about the need to disarm and remove Saddam Hussein. That is the first part of the trinity. Get the idea, get the rationale right. But that is not the problem. The second part of the trinity is to get the process right. On this the coalition of the willing has demonstrably failed. It could not convince its own populations, let alone the governments of the unwilling. It could not win the debate, and that is the nub of the problem. Lazy intellect or plain wrong; it is either one or the other. If you cannot get right the second part of the trinity—that is, the process—the third part of the trinity, the outcome, is likely to be an unmitigated disaster, not only for the Iraq war but also for all future conflict. Pre-emptive attack has now been approved. The intensity of fear that that will generate is simply mind-boggling.

I have never believed that this country would take the role of aggressor. I have never believed that this country would support the principle of pre-emptive strike. I have always believed that that principle was evil and the province of rogue states. No more for Australia and Australians: we will be tarred with that label forever. That will be the legacy of the coalition of the willing. No longer will young Australians travel anywhere overseas confident that their accent will bring a friendly response. No longer will Australians have the honourable reputation of good world citizens. That reputation was precious and that reputation is now damaged—and for what? The inability of Bush, Blair and Howard to win the debate. That is the raw, unadulterated core of the problem. All these three once proud democracies are diminished in the eyes of the world, particularly for those despicable states who may just take the current example of the coalition of the willing as the pathway and the justification to do their own evil.

In conclusion, the recommendation put forward to this parliament by the Labor Party should challenge those fair-minded individuals on the government back bench. We know there are some; we just wonder whether they have the courage to take up the challenge. Eight backbenchers on the government side could change this course. Eight backbenchers on the government side with courage, conviction and a bit of ticker could change the course of history for all Australians. All of the coalition backbench know from contact with their electorates that what I have said in this address today is true: that up to 80 per cent of Australians do not and will not support a war against Iraq without the approval of the United Nations Security Council. That is true in the United States; that is true in Great Britain. Australians have been sending that message loud and clear to all coalition electorate offices; they are giving our electorate offices the same message.

This is a little challenge for the backbench over there. What about the member for Sturt, the member for Boothby, the member for Pearce, the member for Kooyong, the member for Adelaide, the member for Herbert, the member for La Trobe, the member for Hindmarsh, the member for Fairfax, the member for Murray, the member for Gilmore and the members for Hinkler, Wannon, Dunkley, Curtin, Makin, McPherson, Deakin, Eden-Monaro, Forde, Macquarie, Parramatta, Corangamite and Mallee? Get your heart pumping. Get your head in sync. Believe in your soul. Support the Labor amendments and make a change for the better for all time for the reputations of all Australians. Reject the pre-emptive strike. It needs but eight good men and women—that is all it needs—on the coalition back bench. Don't be like the party room this week where not one of you had the guts to stand up and even ask a question of your Prime Minister. How about getting in here when the vote is taken and using your conscience, your head, your heart and your soul? Are any of you up to it? (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise as the last person to speak in this debate. I did so purposely, because I do not think that anybody wants a nation to go to war. I believe that we should not be in this war against Iraq at the moment, and I believe that the amendment put forward by the Leader of the Opposition is quite correct. I support the amendment. I do not believe that we should have predeployed our troops. It is very obvious to me that the Prime Minister had in fact already agreed to do this some months ago. But I make this point: having said that I completely agree with the Labor party's position on this matter—and we are as one and singing completely from the one song sheet—I am like the previous speaker, the member for Port Adelaide: I am one who would have supported a United Nations resolution which stated that force needed to be used to disarm Iraq. I say that because Saddam Hussein is somebody who is evil. He is somebody who not only tortures his own people but even murders his own relatives. I remember distinctly, for instance, his enticing his daughters and sons-in-law back to Iraq only to kill both of his sons-in-law. This is a man who is more evil than evil. He is a man that in some shape or form needs to be brought to account.

speech.para: But I simply make the point that there are right ways of doing things and there are wrong ways. Unilateralism and pre-emptive strikes are the last resort. That is a resort that should not be used, particularly if we say to ourselves that we have an international order, that that is the United Nations and that they are the ones that police the international order. I fear now for what is going to happen in this world, given that the United Nations has been weakened as a result of what was started only a couple of hours ago.

I feel very much for our troops. I make this point: most of our troops over there are there because they have been ordered to be there. In most cases, I might say, they are probably relishing the thought. They are trained for that, and I am sure that they will look after themselves quite adequately. Australian troops have always been known as one of the best fighting forces in the world, and I have no doubt that they will acquit themselves well. I can tell you that the SAS squadron—and I have had the pleasure of meeting a number of its members—is very hard and very good at what it does. I say to them that we are proud of them. I certainly am proud of them. I think everybody on this side either is proud of them or should be proud of them, because they are simply doing what they were asked to do by the government of their country.

I was also in that Vietnam era, and I was balloted out. Those who were born on 12 June went to Vietnam. Those who were born on the 14th went. But I was born on the 13th and did not go. I am not saying that I was completely unhappy about that, because I was against that war at the time as well and I marched at one of the protest marches. But I remember the very many friends that I had at that time—many of whom are now deceased, some of them taking their own lives as a result of what happened in Vietnam. They came back here to a less than warm welcome. I would hate to think that that sort of action on the part of the Australian people could ever be repeated. For that reason, I make it very clear here today that, whilst I oppose the fact that we have gone to war and the way we have gone to war, I personally would have been completely in favour of it with a UN resolution. If we had waited a little longer we may have been able to get that UN resolution. I want to say something about the French involvement later on.

I am, have always been and will always be a very strong supporter of the US alliance. At the moment, I think the Americans are feeling a little different to everybody else in the world. How could you not feel that way after the events of September 11, when 3,000 people are killed in your country—not in the capital city, but in the largest city, arguably, in the United States and the Western world? I was there last year. As I said in a previous debate, I read some of the messages that were put on the fences opposite the World Trade Centre, and I could only cop about 20 yards of it because it moved me so much. There are about 200 yards of these messages. I can understand the frustration that the American people are feeling at the moment. However, there are a lot of people in the United States who are against this war, and some of them marching even now. I saw on the AAP that 300 people are marching down Rodeo Drive—or Wiltshire Boulevard, which is next to Rodeo Drive, for those who have been to Hollywood. There is a lot of antagonism even within their own country, as there is around the world. The fact is that nobody likes to think that there could be mass casualties, which there may well be—though God forbid there are.

I want to again make the point I made previously: we cannot be in a situation where we allow ourselves the luxury of being anti-American. We may not agree with what they are doing this time, but our alliance is such that, in my view, it will stand for a long time in the future. Sometimes there are some things you cannot agree on. Friends cannot agree with each other on everything. This is one such thing. We do not agree with the way this has happened. We would have preferred them to wait. We would have preferred them to have a UN-backed resolution that would have allowed them to go in. But we must not be anti-American. We must try to see if there is some way that we can feel what they are feeling, given the events of September 11. We should consider that while we are having these deliberations.

I want to say something about those people who, from time to time, try to equate the Iraq situation, in terms of the inaction of the United Nations, with the situation in Israel. All I can say is that the Israeli government do not murder their own people, they do not torture their own people and their president does not kill his sons-in-law. The reality is that it is nonsense to try to equate the inaction on UN resolutions in relation to Israel and the Palestinian question with what is happening in Iraq. The other point I want to bring up in this debate is the Zionism conspiracy theories that you hear all the time. I read a very good article by Gerard Henderson, who writes that the idea that conservative Jews are behind the Iraq push is as dodgy as French platitudes. He says:

quote.para: Correctly or incorrectly, the US considers not only that Americans face a real and present danger but that the US is at war. Bush said as much in his recent address to the American Enterprise Institute, declaring that after September 11, “we must look at security in a new way because our country is a battlefield in the first war of the 21st century”.

speech.para: Again I make the point: I completely support my party's position on this without question, but people should understand the frame of mind that the American people are in at the moment. Henderson goes on to say:

quote.para: The US policy is not driven by Zionism but rather by fear of homeland terrorist attack. And the French position is not motivated by a search for peace but rather by (traditional) French duplicity.

speech.para: I do not want to comment on that, except to say that when I consider the actions of the French with respect to this whole issue, where they did not play a very good diplomatic role, I sometimes wonder what the many tens of thousands, if indeed not hundreds of thousands, of British, American, Australian and other troops that are lying in graves on the battlefields of France would think about this. As I said, I simply wanted to speak at the end of this debate to make it very clear that I believe we should have waited a little longer. Having said that, I understand—I try to understand, anyway—that we need the US alliance, and that the reality is that, in some shape or form, we must be very careful not to be seen to be anti-American. I can certainly assure you that those on this side of the House are not against the American alliance, but we are against the way the decisions have been made with respect to this war.

talk.start.para: —I will very briefly make a few remarks to close this debate. Perhaps I could bounce off a comment made by the member for Bowman that I totally agree with. I agree with his remark that some of the conspiracy theories concerning the role of Israel in this are completely ill-founded. I am struck by two images of electoral processes in the Middle East in the last few months. I am struck by the image of the re-elected Prime Minister of Israel, Ariel Sharon, being pulled off television midway through an advertisement because, according to the Israeli Electoral Commission, the advertisement did not comply with the electoral laws of Israel. A few weeks earlier, I read that the President of Iraq had been elected with a vote of 100 per cent. I do not think the President of Iraq would be pulled off television by the independent electoral commission. It drives home the point—the very simple, but very relevant point—that the only truly democratic country in all of the Middle East is the state of Israel, and it is something that all of us should bear in mind.

speech.para: I want to thank everybody who has participated in this debate. As I said earlier, and I want to say again, I respect the fact that there is a range of views in the Australian community on this issue. I understand that, and it has been a difficult debate for the community; but it is a debate that nonetheless has had to be had. On occasions, governments are required to take decisions that are difficult and challenging but are, in their view, in the long-term national interest of the nation. I want to thank my colleagues for the immense thought, consideration, understanding and steadfastness that they have displayed on this issue. I thank them for that. It is very important to me, it is very important to the government, and it is very important to how we represent ourselves to the Australian community. We believe it is the right decision, we believe it is legally sound and we believe it is in the national interest.

I want to emphasise that, although Australia is participating as part of a US-led coalition, our operations as a military force will take place under a separate national command. We will have separate rules of engagement and separate targeting policies; and as recently as this morning it has been emphasised, in discussions with our military, that those separate targeting policies will be robustly interpreted and enforced. There are areas where we do have differences with the Americans in relation to this, and we will continue to pursue our different views regarding such things as cluster bombs and so forth in the various international fora. I know that a number of my colleagues have spoken about these issues during the debate.

What happens in Iraq when the conflict ends is important. We do believe—and I think most Australians believe—that the departure of the Saddam Hussein regime will be beneficial for the Iraqi people. We have no doubt about that. Iraq will be a happier, better country without Saddam Hussein, and that should be remembered. We will play a significant part in the reconstruction process. We are prepared to at least match—indeed, go further—than the contribution we made to the reconstruction of Afghanistan. On that occasion we contributed some $43 million. Australia has already pledged $10 million, and I see us going beyond that figure. I want to endorse the remarks that have been made by my colleague the Minister for Foreign Affairs regarding that.

I also think that the post-conflict stage, the phase 4 stage, should be characterised by a significant involvement by the United Nations. Whatever may be the reaction of some in the House, that is a view that we have put to the American administration and to the British government in the course of our discussions on this. I also think that, domestically, there could well be a role for the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade in relation to oversighting the Australian involvement in the phase 4 process. Perhaps there is a role for the committee—I know these committees are independent of the executive and I would not want to transgress in any way on their independence; but perhaps there is a place for the establishment of some kind of subcommittee to oversee that, because we have made a very strong commitment to the process of disarming Iraq. We have done that because we believe it is in Australia's long-term national interest.

We do worry about the ultimate and fateful coming together of weapons of mass destruction and international terrorism. I share the passionate view of the British Prime Minister, Tony Blair, that the world will face a bleak future if ever those two things are joined. That has been the basis of my approach on this, as it has been the basis of Mr Blair's courageous approach in his own country—an approach that has won the admiration of not only his opponents in the United Kingdom but also those who are normally separated from him politically in this country. I am proud to call Tony Blair an international friend of mine on this issue. He has shown great leadership and I admire him immensely.

Lastly, I want to address some remarks to the men and women of the Australian Defence Force—particularly today, the day when it has become known that they have begun to be involved in operations. However much we may differ and quarrel about the merits of this issue, surely we are united in the expression of a passionate hope and, for many, a prayer that they will all return home safe and sound. Surely on that issue we can all say, with one voice, that is how we feel.

talk.start.para: —They shouldn't be there!
—I remind members of their status in the House. The Prime Minister has the call.

—I accept the intervention of the Leader of the Opposition. I accept everything he said by way of his intervention. I have never impugned the commitment of the Leader of the Opposition to this country; I have never done that. We are all proud, patriotic Australians, and we ought to be able to debate these things in the context of that respect for each other. I acknowledge that people disagree violently with the view I hold on this issue. I respect that. I ask them to respect, though, the passion and the commitment that I have brought to this decision. I ask them to respect the fact that I have agonised over this, I have anguished over it, I have given it a great deal of thought—
—For about two seconds after the phone call.
—The member for Corio is warned!

—You can never quite rise above the political point-scoring. Enough of that. I simply want to say, again, to the magnificent men and women of the Australian Defence Force that you, more than any other group of Australians, are in our thoughts at this moment, and you will remain in our thoughts, as will your loved ones. We will try to understand as best we can the anguish that they must feel at present. I know that all members of the House will feel that way. I again express my thanks to my colleagues for their support, their understanding, their recognition of the long-term national interest and the way in which they have given to the government on this very difficult issue their great understanding and their great support. I commend the motion to the House.

—The original question was that the motion be agreed to. To this the Leader of the Opposition has moved as an amendment that all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting other words. The question now is that the words proposed to be omitted stand part of the question. Is a division required? Ring the bells.

para.inline: A division having been called and the bells being rung—

talk.start.para: —I wish the families of the troops could see you now—laughing and carrying on like this.
—Order! The member for Blair! The member for Cowan!
—You are a hero in here, aren't you! Spare a bit of a thought for the families.
—Order! The member for Blair will withdraw that remark!
—I withdraw.

motion.para: That the words proposed to be omitted (Mr Crean's amendment) stand part of the question.

debate.para: Original question put:

motion.para: That the motion (Mr Howard's) be agreed to.

debateinfo.title: AUSTRALIAN SECURITY INTELLIGENCE ORGANISATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (TERRORISM) BILL 2002 [NO. 2]

subdebate.1.para: Bill presented by Mr Williams, and read a first time.

talk.start.para: —Oh, you've discovered a threat between question time and now!
—The member for Wills is warned! The Attorney-General has the call.
—I move:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

speech.para: Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Legislation Amendment (Terrorism) Bill 2002 [No. 2] will strengthen Australia's counter-terrorism capabilities by enhancing ASIO's investigative powers.

The horrific and tragic events of September 11 marked a fundamental shift in the international security environment. The more recent tragedy in Bali brought the realities of terrorism to our doorstep. Those inexcusable acts of atrocity showed us no country is safe from the devastation terrorist acts inflict. The fact that we remain in this heightened security environment and are likely to do so for some time makes passage of this bill more important than ever.

The government has consistently taken a strong, decisive and balanced approach to strengthening Australia's counter-terrorist capabilities. On the legislative front, the government has enacted a package of counter-terrorism legislation to ensure that Australia, through our law enforcement and intelligence agencies, is in the best possible position to protect Australians against the evils of terrorism. This bill is part of that legislative package—its primary purpose is to protect the community. Let that be clear.

In developing this legislation, the government has been conscious of the need to protect our community from the threat of terrorism without unfairly or unnecessarily encroaching on the individual rights and liberties that are fundamental to our democratic system.

In the process of developing this bill, the government has done everything it can to ensure concerns raised about the bill have been taken into consideration. The government has included significant safeguards in the bill to ensure rights and liberties are appropriately protected. And the government has made significant amendments to the bill to address concerns that have been raised. For example, in an effort to achieve opposition support for the bill we agreed to a three-year sunset clause, despite the fact that we do not believe that a sunset clause is appropriate.
The government's position on this bill has always been consistent and clear. Our intelligence agency needs this bill to give it the tools it needs to help fight terrorism.

The government is committed to protecting the Australian community against terrorism. And the government is committed to providing these tools. But we are not prepared to accept amendments that will render the bill impotent or unworkable. Our intelligence agency has indicated that it would rather no legislation at all than a fig leaf.
Debate interrupted; adjournment proposed and negatived.

talk.start.para: —We intend to do whatever we can to deliver workable and appropriate legislation.

speech.para: Let us not forget that this bill has been subject to the highest levels of scrutiny. It was considered by three parliamentary committees. And the reports of those committees were invaluable in assisting the government to refine the bill. For example, in accordance with recommendations of the parliamentary joint committee, the bill will not apply to anyone under 14.

The bill empowers ASIO to seek a warrant which allows the detention and questioning of persons who may have information that may assist in preventing terrorist attacks before they occur. In order to prevent potential terrorist attacks, we must enhance the powers of ASIO to gather relevant intelligence in relation to terrorism offences. While ASIO is empowered to seek search warrants, computer access warrants, tracking device warrants, telecommunications interception warrants and to inspect postal articles, ASIO is not currently empowered to obtain a warrant to question a person who has information about a potential terrorist attack.

The bill establishes a warrant process to allow ASIO to question a person who may have important information relating to a terrorist attack. A person subject to a warrant may be detained by police for up to 48 hours to allow ASIO to question them.

The government recognises the need to do everything it can to ensure the security of the community while not encroaching unnecessarily on individual rights and avoiding the potential for abuse. The government has done everything it can to achieve those aims. It must be remembered that these warrants are a measure of last resort. It is anticipated that they will be used rarely and only in extreme circumstances.

The bill contains a significant number of hurdles that must be achieved before a warrant is issued. In order for ASIO to detain and question a person, the Director-General of Security must obtain the consent of the Attorney-General before seeking a warrant from an `issuing authority'.

The Attorney-General must be satisfied that there are reasonable grounds for believing that issuing the warrant will substantially assist the collection of intelligence that is important in relation to a terrorism offence and that relying on other methods of collecting that intelligence would be ineffective.

If the warrant being sought requires a person to be taken into custody immediately and detained, the Attorney-General must also be satisfied of a number of conditions. Importantly, the Attorney-General must be satisfied that the person may alert another person involved in a terrorism offence of the investigation, or the person may fail to appear before the prescribed authority, or the person may alter or destroy a record or thing that they may be requested to produce. Without this provision, terrorists could be warned before they are caught, planned acts of terrorism known to ASIO could be rescheduled rather than prevented, and valuable evidence could be destroyed.

If the warrant concerns a person between the ages of 14 and 18, the Attorney-General must also be satisfied that it is likely that the person will commit, is committing or has committed a terrorism offence.

An `issuing authority' will either be a federal magistrate, a federal judge or another authority set out in regulations. In the extraordinary situation of a warrant resulting in a person being detained for more than 96 consecutive hours, only a federal judge or another authority specified in regulations can be the issuing authority. An `issuing authority' may only issue a warrant if it has been requested in accordance with the proper procedure and it is satisfied that there are reasonable grounds for believing that the warrant will substantially assist the collection of intelligence that is important to a terrorism offence.

A warrant issued under the bill will require a person to appear before a `prescribed authority' to provide information or produce documents or things. A prescribed authority will either be a person who has previously been a judge of the High Court, Federal Court, Family Court, Supreme or District Court of a state or territory. If there are insufficient people in this category, the Attorney-General may appoint a person currently serving as a judge in a state or territory Supreme Court or District Court, or, as a final choice, the president or deputy president of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

The warrant may request that a person appear at a particular time or order the person to be taken into custody to be brought before the prescribed authority. If a person is to be taken into custody immediately and detained, this will be the responsibility of the police, normally the Australian Federal Police.

In some situations, a person with highly relevant information may refuse to volunteer it. For example, a terrorist sympathiser who may know of a planned bombing of a busy building, but who will not actually take part in the bombing, may decline to help authorities prevent the attack.

In order for the new powers to be effective, penalties must apply to those who fail to answer questions accurately or produce documents or other requested things. The maximum penalty for the offences will be five years imprisonment.

A person will not be able to decline to give information or produce a document or thing on the ground that to do so would tend to incriminate them. However, evidence obtained as a result of the questioning will only be admissible in relation to charges related to non-compliance with a warrant issued under the bill.

The bill contains a number of safeguards to ensure that ASIO's powers are exercised reasonably and that a person is treated fairly whilst in custody or detention. Questioning of a person under a warrant will always take place before a prescribed authority.

When a person first appears before the prescribed authority for questioning under the warrant, the prescribed authority must explain what the warrant authorises ASIO to do, the period the warrant is to be in force and the possibility of facing criminal sanctions if the person does not cooperate. It must also advise the person that they have the right to seek a remedy from a federal court in relation to the warrant or their treatment under the warrant and this information must be provided when the person first appears before the prescribed authority and at least once in every 24-hour period subsequently. A prescribed authority may also give directions under the warrant regarding the detention of the person, including permitting the person to contact another person. The directions must be consistent with the warrant and any changes to the warrant approved by the minister in writing.

The bill includes a special regime for questioning young people. Warrants cannot be issued in relation to a person who is under the age of 14. A warrant may be issued in relation to young people between the ages of 14 and 18 only if the Attorney-General is satisfied on reasonable grounds that the person will commit, is committing or has committed a terrorism offence. Access to a lawyer cannot be delayed for young people. And young people questioned under a warrant will have the right to contact a security cleared lawyer and to have a parent, guardian or other representative present at all times.

All persons detained under a warrant will have the right to contact an `approved lawyer'. All warrants authorising the taking of a person into custody and detaining them must provide that the person may access an approved lawyer. An `approved lawyer' will be a legal practitioner of at least five years experience who has been approved by the Attorney-General after undergoing a security clearance.

In exceptional circumstances, access to an approved lawyer may be delayed for up to 48 hours. In order to delay access to an approved lawyer, the Attorney-General must be satisfied that it is likely that a terrorism offence is being or is about to be committed and may have serious consequences. However, after 48 hours, all persons will have the absolute right to contact an approved lawyer.

A person subject to a warrant has a right to complain to the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security (IGIS) in relation to ASIO, and to the Commonwealth Ombudsman in relation to the Australian Federal Police. The IGIS will be empowered to advise the prescribed authority of any concerns he or she may have about the legality or propriety of ASIO's actions. The prescribed authority may direct that the questioning be suspended until it is satisfied that the IGIS's concerns have been addressed.

The person must also be treated with humanity and with respect for human dignity, and must not be subjected to cruel, inhumane or degrading treatment, by anyone exercising authority under the warrant or implementing or enforcing a direction of the prescribed authority. In addition, the Director-General must ensure that video recordings are made of a person's appearance before a prescribed authority for questioning and any matter or thing that the prescribed authority directs to be recorded. There are significant penalties for officers who do not follow the stringent processes and safeguards in the bill.
During debate on a previous version of the bill, the government moved a number of amendments to the bill that added to the already extensive safeguards contained in the bill.
The bill now clarifies that an ordinary or frisk search of a person must, if practicable, be conducted by a person of the same sex.

Significant amendments were made to the `prescribed authority' provisions. For example, the bill now explicitly requires the prescribed authority to explain the warrant to the person being questioned, outline that person's rights, and explain the role of the prescribed authority and the role of every other person present during the questioning.

There are new safeguards to ensure that an interpreter must be provided at the request of the person being questioned. The interpreter will also be provided at the request of the prescribed authority.

The bill now requires that there be a written statement of procedures which must be followed in the exercise of authority under a warrant. And no action can be taken under a warrant until these procedures have been adopted in accordance with the requirements of the legislation. If these procedures are contravened, a person will have the right to lodge a complaint with the Inspector-General or the Commonwealth Ombudsman.
The bill includes important measures to ensure transparency and accountability in relation to the exercise of powers under a warrant.

ASIO's unclassified annual report must include a statement of the total number of requests made to the Attorney-General and to issuing authorities for warrants during the year and the actual number of warrants issued during the year. The annual report must also include the number of warrants issued during the year that require a person to appear before a prescribed authority and the number of warrants issued that authorised a person to be detained. And ASIO will now be required to publish (in the organisation's unclassified report to parliament) statistics including the number of hours each person appeared before a prescribed authority for questioning under a warrant.

The Parliamentary Joint Committee on ASIO, the Australian Secret Intelligence Service and the Defence Signals Directorate will be asked to review the new provisions and provide a report on their operation.

The government is mindful of the need for strong laws to protect our national security, yet preserve individual rights. The bill achieves those aims. The bill was not created on a whim but in response to identified needs. Australia's profile as a terrorist target has risen and we remain on a heightened security alert. In November 2002, the government issued a security alert in response to credible information of a possible terrorist attack in Australia at some time in the months following November.

Terrorism is not like ordinary crime. The way terrorist networks are organised and the destruction that acts of terrorism cause, distinguish terrorism from other types of crime. The Howard government takes very seriously its responsibility to do everything it can to protect Australians and Australian interests against the threat of terrorism. That is why this bill was developed. That is why the government has cooperated as far as is possible in ensuring the legislation addresses legitimate concerns without making the bill unworkable. That is why the government pursued discussions with the opposition for months in order to find a way to negotiate passage of the bill.
This bill is a decisive, yet measured response to the new security environment.

When the bill is enacted, we will have appropriate laws to protect the community from terrorism while ensuring that the rights of individuals are not unnecessarily impeded. I call on the opposition to support this vital legislation and not delay its passage any longer. I commend the bill to the House. I present the explanatory memorandum to the bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Melham) adjourned.

talk.start.para: —I present the Auditor-General's audit report No. 33 of 2002-03 entitled Performance audit—Management of e-Business in the Department of Education, Science and Training.

interjection.para: Ordered that the report be printed.

talk.start.para: — Papers are tabled as listed in the schedule circulated to honourable members. Details of the papers will be recorded in the Votes and Proceedings and I move:

motion.para: That the House take note of the following papers:
Advisory Panel on the Marketing in Australia of Infant Formula—Report for 2001-02.
Private Health Insurance—Report on premium increases for quarter beginning 1 January 2003

speech.para: Debate (on motion by Mr Sidebottom) adjourned.

subdebateinfo.title: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs Committee
Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund Committee

subdebate.1.title: Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund Committee

talk.start.para: —I have received advice from the Opposition Whip nominating members to be members of certain committees.

interjection.para: Mr ABBOTT (Warringah—Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service) (4.43 p.m.)—by leave—I move:

motion.para: Mr Danby be discharged from the Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs and that, in his place, Ms Gillard be appointed a member of the committee, and

Dr Lawrence be discharged from the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund and that, in her place, Ms Gillard be appointed a member of the committee.

debate.para: Message from the Governor-General reported informing the House of assent to the following bills:

para.inline: Migration Legislation Amendment (Contributory Parents Migration Scheme) Bill 2003

debate.para: Mr McARTHUR (Corangamite) (4.45 p.m.)—by leave—I move:

motion.para: That the following bills be referred to the Main Committee for consideration:

debate.para: Question agreed to.
Miss JACKIE KELLY (Lindsay—Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister) (4.45 p.m.)—I move:

motion.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —I thank the government and opposition people who have made time available in the adjournment debate. We anticipated that the previous debate would last much longer and take us out to about five o'clock. In the event, it did not. The five minutes gives me an opportunity briefly to deal with the introduction of the legislation that the Attorney-General has just placed in the House on the amended powers of ASIO. Of course, I fully realise that, under the standing orders, I am not allowed to canvass the detail of that bill, as that would be anticipating debate. Just as that is not permitted in question time, neither is it permitted in the adjournment debate. However, there are certain features of this issue that stand outside the bill and go to the handling of the bill. Under the standing orders, they may be considered.

speech.para: There has been a deal of reportage about the motivations associated with the government's intention to reintroduce the bill now. I do not want to go into that or speculate about whether it is a piece of double dissolution legislation. What I want to do is correct some of the historical record associated with it. A bill to give ASIO these powers passed the Senate last year, with different but nevertheless workable provisions that ensured the protection of civil rights. At the same time, it ensured that ASIO ended up with powers greater than those of the FBI—that of course being a body which faces in its day-to-day duties even more serious threats to national security via terrorist activity than we do ourselves. The bill that passed the Senate at that time would have seen ASIO emerge with powers well beyond those of the American FBI. I, for one, regard it as a tragedy that the bill was not accepted at that time.

I emphasise that to emphasise the fact that the opposition does not oppose in principle the extension of additional powers to ASIO in these troubled times. We support it. Indeed, when I was Leader of the Opposition, we called for it. The opposition approaches this particular legislation not from the point of view of obstructionism but from the point of view of wanting to get the balance right. Having had discussions with the various opposition spokespersons who are directly responsible for the opposition's handling of this piece of legislation, I know that that remains the case. I think it is important that, when this legislation finally passes the parliament, it does so in a shape and form that the vast majority of the Australian people can feel comfortable with. That is important for the sense of security of the ordinary Australian citizen. It is also important for the belief that the government is being directed on the basis of not what is there for partisan advantage on security issues but what is there for protection, and ensuring that, in protecting ourselves, we uphold all the principles that make us a worthwhile and democratic nation.

That is our objective. I hope it will be the objective of the government, too. It is the intention of the opposition negotiators—of whom I am not one—that this bill, which we took a positive approach to previously, will be approached on the same basis again. I note without canvassing them that the government has made some adjustments to that legislation, and that is welcome. We suggested at the time that there were other adjustments that we were prepared to wear ourselves, and those adjustments were not taken up in the negotiations that occurred on that very fraught night, as I recollect it—almost the last night of sitting in the course of last year.

The opposition supports in principle that extension of the powers of ASIO. We support it in a context that ensures the rights of people who are not suspects. Remember that this legislation refers to people who are not suspects. If you are a suspect of a terrorist act, considerable civil libertarian rights descend upon you. That is the nature of our laws. However, these are folk who are not suspects. Therefore, this is innovative legislation in that regard. In these circumstances we as a parliament ought to be very careful in the way in which we handle this. As I said, the opposition is prepared to negotiate this on a positive basis. I do not want to see reportage of this tomorrow suggesting that we are not prepared to do that or that we were not in the past. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Leukaemia Foundation: World's Greatest Shave for a Cure

talk.start.para: —Last week, along with more than 140 people in my electorate of Dickson, I joined the ranks that the Leukaemia Foundation calls the bald and the beautiful—in my case, the not so beautiful. Scores of volunteers from all over Australia gave up their time and their hair to raise money for leukaemia research and patient support in the World's Greatest Shave for a Cure. The national target for this event in 2003 is $10 million. I am proud to inform the House that, in Dickson alone, members of the local Leukaemia Foundation branch expect to bank more than $20,000 in Shave for a Cure donations this week. When I last checked, they said the donations were still rolling in.

speech.para: This achievement is testament to the commitment and generosity of many people. I would like to thank everyone who contributed financially to the campaign, participants nationally, and all the individuals and organisations who gave the $700 to sponsor my shave in conjunction with Councillor Brian Battersby. I would particularly like to take this opportunity to inform the House of some of the personal contributions members of my community made to make this very worthwhile cause a success. These people are all volunteers. They are people who go about their work quietly and who expect no other reward than to know they have helped.

In particular, I would like to mention the efforts of Kaye and Glen Fox and Margot and Don Perrett from Albany Creek, who were my area's Shave for a Cure coordinators. The task was especially meaningful for the Foxes and Perretts, as both families have lost teenaged children to leukaemia in the past five years. Julia Fox, aged 17, and Tim Perrett, aged 19, passed away only months apart, in late 1997 and early 1998. Despite these tragedies, and because of them, the Foxes and Perretts gave up their time to organise and promote two of the shave events. Their amazing commitment and organisational skills really came to the fore as they coordinated hairdressers, sought sponsors, collected donations and ran a sausage sizzle—all of which were almost a full-time task in itself. I want to thank these people for their amazing work.

Another astounding local is Strathpine's 89-year-old Mary Crisp, who has a fine record of helping people with leukaemia. Mary's first contribution involved giving blood to a boy with leukaemia during World War II. In the past eight years, Mary has continued to help by making 601 trauma bears and by knitting 500 beanies for people who have lost their hair because of leukaemia and cancer treatments.

At the other end of the razor, there were many local people—people from businesses and groups who stepped up to shave or colour their hair. I would especially like to recognise the following people: the staff and students at our local schools; Pine Rivers councillors, including Councillor Graeme Ashworth; Dr Rhys Dallimore; Joe Minehan at the Albany Creek Tavern; the staff at Target Brookside; the staff of our northside Quest newspapers; Albany Village Shopping Centre; and Ray White Samford. I also thank Sam Riley, the Leukaemia Foundation's national ambassador, and Adrian Collins, its Queensland CEO. I recently enjoyed a breakfast with both of them at the Albany Creek Tavern, where awareness of this campaign was made known to the local community.

I also want to say thank you to all the other individuals and organisations who participated. Your work really does make a positive difference to many young lives. The Hanley family in my electorate is proof of this. Lisa and John Hanley are the parents of a six-year-old named Jackson, who is living with leukaemia. Jackson was diagnosed with the disease when he was just two years old. At that age, he was facing a disease that one in three young people do not survive, but, thanks to the love and support of his family—as well as medical advancements made possible by the work of the Leukaemia Foundation and other groups—Jackson is now in remission. He is attending year 2 at school and spending time with his little brother Maclean. His mother Lisa had her own shoulder-length hair shaved off last week so other families could benefit from the same support and education which the Leukaemia Foundation gave her family.

These examples are just a few amongst the hundreds of people in Dickson who gave their time, money and effort for this important cause in the past weeks. Since becoming a representative of these people, I continue to be astounded by the sheer effort and commitment they regularly make to help others, and today I want to thank them. Theirs is a giving spirit which, in its sincerity, will bring hope and help to many young lives. Thank you to all for your efforts.

talk.start.para: —Last week I went to the Leongatha Secondary College and spoke to a number of outstanding students in relation to a number of different things—how laws are made, current issues in political life and a number of different local issues which they wanted to speak to me about. However, the big issue they wanted to talk to me about was Australia's participation in a war with Iraq. I gave those students a commitment when we spoke, and I am going to honour that commitment now by mentioning the views of those students in the federal parliament today. The students took the time to write a letter to me and organise a petition which was signed by teachers and students at the school. In the very limited time that I have, I want to read part of their letter into Hansard:

quote.para: Dear Mr Zahra,

We have watched world events over the past year or so with increasing concern. Since the 11th September 2001, there has existed an increased air of uncertainty and international tension, which has escalated as the so-called War on Terror unfolds. Not only have many innocent people died in New York and Washington, but also in Afghanistan and Bali. Were war to be waged on Iraq, even more innocent people would die, for that is the one and only certain result of armed conflict.

We, as young people and future voters, wholeheartedly disagree with the position that the United States administration has taken on the issue of Iraq, and are ashamed that our government is one of the few supporting the US stance. It is deeply concerning that our Prime Minister and his cabinet, who are elected to represent the majority of Australians, have gone against the overwhelming tide of public opinion in order to satisfy the demands and interests of a foreign power.

speech.para: These students at Leongatha Secondary College thought a lot about what they wrote in this letter to me. They are thinking people. They are smart. They were articulate and very aware of what this issue meant for them and our nation. I made them a commitment to make sure their voices were heard in the parliament; today I honour that commitment.

I will, of course, make the arrangement to have the petition which they organised tabled in the parliament in the usual way. It is signed by hundreds of students and, it seems, a very large proportion of the teachers at Leongatha Secondary College. I would like to thank the college principal, Colin Boyd, for the mature way in which he handled the requests from the students as to how to best articulate their concerns about the war. They wanted to get advice from him as a respected person in their lives. He advised them to organise a petition and to raise it with me as their local federal MP. That is good advice. Today, in the parliament, the voices of those students at Leongatha Secondary College have been heard.

In the little time that I have left, I want to talk about the spirit of Leongatha Secondary College, which is one in which people are treated with respect. The students there are not treated like babies. They are mature, sensible young people, and they were able to organise a large group of students to come and see me. They were not required to be there but volunteered and wanted to be there. They had views to express and wanted to articulate their opinions to me. That is exactly the type of spirit that we want to see in schools and exactly the type of spirit that we want to engender in our young people. The people who presented the petition to me were Tom Quinn, Joanna O'Reilly, Conal Thwaite and Tully Fletcher—all outstanding young people in the Leongatha district and, I am sure, future leaders in their own right.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 5 p.m., the debate is interrupted. I should point out to the member for McMillan—as I am surehe is aware—that revisiting a debate is always a difficult exercise. In fact, it is outside the standing orders. I allowed him to continue because I was prepared to accept the fact that he was addressing a petition.

business.start.para: The DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Causley) took the chair at 9.40 a.m.

talk.start.para: —Today, a day when in a couple of hours we will see the world at war once again—something that I think is rather tragic—I want to bring to the House's attention an aspect of the war that does not take much prominence. We mouth platitudes but, when it comes to actually doing something about this issue, we seem to be missing in action. The issue I am referring to is the treatment of our veterans when they return. I speak with some authority because my late father was a veteran and my mum, when Dad passed away, was a war widow. It is interesting to note that one of the former ministers for veterans' affairs has wandered in; thank you. The issue is the treatment of veterans and how difficult it is for many veterans to access what I consider to be their due entitlements through DVA. These veterans have served in countries far away. They have left their families, they have put themselves under enormous pressure, they have seen their friends and cobbers killed and, in many cases, they have been POWs and gone through horrific experiences. When they come back, they have to go through the Veterans' Entitlements Act and all its complications. To my mind, we say one thing and we do the other.

speech.para: A gold card, to my mind, is an entitlement. If you have a medical problem or a mental health problem, DVA should look after you. There should be no questions asked; it should be taken for granted. But we have a situation now in my electorate—and, I know, in many electorates around Australia—where veterans go to the doctor and doctors are saying, `Look, I'm sorry, but I don't accept your gold card. I'm having this philosophical, ideological argument with the government about my due entitlements as a GP. I'm sorry, but you're going to have to make a co-payment.' I think it is bloody disgraceful; I really do. Most of these people are well into their 80s. They have done the hard yards. They have sacrificed many things for our country. As I said, we mouth platitudes as we send them off to war today but, when they come home, they are really pushing it up the proverbial hill. Let us sort out all this philosophical BS between the government and the AMA so that our diggers and our war widows do get their entitlements and these people can live in peace and harmony for the rest of their lives.

talk.start.para: —Can I say to the member for Franklin, a dear colleague of mine, that we could not agree more with what he said in his statement today. However, as chairman of the health and ageing committee, I would like to take this opportunity to discuss ovarian cancer. According to the Cancer Council of South Australia, ovarian cancer was the eighth most common cancer among women in my home state in 2000. It was the fifth most common cause of cancer death amongst women. These facts highlight the need for all women to consult their doctors should they experience any of the symptoms of ovarian cancer. This warning has been issued by the Australian Divisions of General Practice Chairman, Dr Rob Walters, during Ovarian Cancer Week 2003.

speech.para: According to Dr Walters, ovarian cancer affects about one in 70 Australian women. Early detection and treatment of the disease is estimated to provide a 90 per cent chance of surviving past five years, but the problem is that most of the 1,200 Australian women who are diagnosed with ovarian cancer each year have for too long avoided consulting their doctor. Having reached the advanced stage of the disease, many, sadly, do not survive longer than five years past diagnosis. Last year, the federal health minister, Senator the Hon. Kay Patterson, released a report by the National Breast Cancer Centre incorporating the Ovarian Cancer Program, Ovarian cancer in Australian women, which marked the first time that Australia-wide data had been collected to enable the development of a coordinated approach to improve the early detection of ovarian cancer.

The federal government announced funding of $500,000 in September 2001 for a two-year program to improve ovarian cancer control, some of which was used to establish the Ovarian Cancer Program. The report found that ovarian cancer, unlike some cancers in women, generally has a more favourable outlook for younger women. The report's author, Dr Anne Kricker, said the five-year relative survival rate after diagnosis of ovarian cancer is 42 per cent. According to Dr Kricker, about 20 per cent of women with ovarian cancer are under 50 years of age, but survival at these stages is better than in older women. On World Cancer Day this year the minister reaffirmed the Commonwealth government's longstanding commitment to cancer control, which has led to a reduction in the numbers of deaths from all cancer types by an average of 1.9 per cent for the past 10 years.

I urge all Australian women to be aware of the possible symptoms and to seek medical advice should they experience any of them. The symptoms can include pelvic or abdominal pain or discomfort, swelling in the abdomen and unexplained weight gain or weight loss with appetite loss, bloating, feeling tired and suffering back ache and cramps, vague but persistent gastrointestinal upsets, and bladder or other urinary problems. For their own peace of mind and wellbeing, it is far better for women who suffer any of these symptoms to see their doctor immediately. It may not be cancer but, if it is, by early detection and treatment they have a much greater chance of survival.

talk.start.para: —The cult of celebrity seems to be an increasing obsession in this country.
