quote.para: I don't mean to be obtuse, but my question was whether the Sydney Institute received institutional or governmental funding ... I am genuinely interested in subscribing, but not to an organisation funded by, say, the KGB or the CIA, or even the Liberal Party or the ALP. In short, I want to understand the affiliations of an organisation before I join it. Subject to clarifying this point, I am happy to send my money.

speech.para: Anne Henderson responded at 3.51 p.m. that same day:

quote.para: As the website makes clear we are not affiliated with any other organization—be it a university ... or political party. And I assume your comment on the CIA or KGB is some kind of joke.

speech.para: Again, she has refused to answer the question. This is obstruction and dishonesty. She is not giving this man an answer as to where the Sydney Institute money comes from. James Thynne emailed back at 4.34 p.m. on 20 August:

quote.para: I could find nothing in your website which addresses my concerns, or indeed “makes clear that you are not affiliated with any other organisation”, as you assert ... I don't want unwittingly to join such an organisation—

speech.para: he was referring to a `front organisation'. He then asked the questions again. Why not say where your money comes from? Why not identify the sources? At 4.53 p.m., Anne Henderson replied:

quote.para: I can only repeat—we are not “aligned” with any organizations ... At The Sydney Institute we do not do any research—

speech.para: that is obvious—

quote.para: and are more of a public affairs forum (talk tank)—

speech.para: that is also obvious—

quote.para: than anything else ... You can join as an associate or come and pay at the door—simple as that. Now I have work to do and will have to leave it at that.
Anne Henderson

speech.para: She has done everything she possibly can to obstruct and deceive Mr Thynne. All he wanted to know was where the Sydney Institute money comes from. That is a fair question about an organisation that tries to influence public life and public policy in this country. She did everything she could to avoid the truth and everything she could to avoid mentioning the funding they received from Rodney Adler—one of Australia's most notorious figures in the corporate world. This is the Sydney Institute pattern—no annual report, no financial returns lodged with ASIC and no honesty in dealing with public requests for information.

The truth is that we need some new laws in this country. If it is good enough for politicians to declare our pecuniary interests and where our election donations come from and if it is good enough for journalists to declare their financial interests, then what about think-tanks? Surely, as they have an important role in public life seeking to influence opinion and mould public policy, they should declare where the money comes from. They should be more open and transparent than the deception of the Sydney Institute. That institute is to be condemned and we need some laws to force them to declare their funding sources. (Time expired)

talker.name: Cameron, Ross, MP
Mr ROSS CAMERON
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Family and Community Services

talk.start.para: —I was interested to see some remarks by the Minister for Small Business and Tourism published today. Yesterday at the National Press Club, the minister said that what had eventually persuaded him to join in support of the coalition of the willing were the prospects it provided for a solution to the problem of peace in the Middle East. It was also his view that it created the renewed potential for the achievement of a Palestinian state. It is true that one of the issues cited as a reason for the invasion of Iraq is the support for terrorism by the Iraqi administration. The most indisputable proof of that support is Saddam Hussein's famously self-publicised support of $US25,000 cash for the families of suicide bombers in Palestine.

speech.para: I want to say as the chair of the Australia-Palestine parliamentary group that I have a profound sympathy with the cause of the Palestinian people, yet I have no instinctive hostility to the cause and the legitimate aspirations of the Jewish people in Israel. Clearly though, one of the outstanding tasks for this generation of public leaders around the world is to achieve a resolution to this problem. There can be no doubt that the seething sense of injustice that the failure to resolve the Palestinian question has caused, throughout the Middle East in particular but in other places around the world, blows wind into the sails of those who are tempted by the route of political terror. For all of us who would aspire to the title of humanitarian, however well or poorly we meet that aspiration, we have to dedicate our creativity, our resources and our energy to finding a resolution to this problem.

Can I express my deep disappointment that the Sharon government seems to be walking further and further away from the table of negotiation and from the path of genuine movement towards peace. There has been an apparently unilateral decision to reject any road map to peace that may come from the US administration. On the Israeli side, there has apparently been a stepping back from the idea of a sovereign state for the Palestinians as the objective of a peace process to something less. At the same time, we have had conciliatory moves from the Palestinians including, for the first time, a voluntary initiative towards greater power sharing by the senior leadership of the Palestinian cause—which has certainly been welcomed by the international community. While I am supporting my government's commitment to the so-called coalition of the willing, I want to make it clear that it represents no diminution of our commitment to the satisfaction of the legitimate aspirations of the Palestinian people to a secure homeland—in fact, it represents an increase in our commitment. It is possible that the establishment of a democratic government, besides Israel, in the Middle East, will actually strengthen the hand of the Palestinians. That is certainly my hope.

Finally, the most demoralising aspect for me of the performance by the Israeli government has been the support for continued housing settlements in the occupied territories. If there is to be peace in the Middle East, it will be based on the creation of a viable Palestinian state. If that state is to be viable, it cannot be honeycombed by Jewish settlements throughout the Palestinian territories. I urge the government of Israel to communicate a message of hope to the world by taking a much more constructive and proactive approach towards the road map to peace by withdrawing the settlements and by restoring the objective of a sovereign Palestinian state as the goal of the peace process.

subdebateinfo.title: Greenway Electorate: Mary Immaculate Primary School

talk.start.para: —This afternoon I would like to speak about peace. I invite honourable members to come to my parliamentary office at R2.95 to see a magnificent display of doves that have been cut out and written on by students from a school in my electorate, the Mary Immaculate Primary School at Quakers Hill. These were presented to me last week quite unexpectedly. They show the strength of the feeling out there in the community to the war in Iraq. I would like to demonstrate to the Main Committee the efforts that the children at this particular school have gone to just to get the message through that they are very strongly in favour of peace and, of course, against the war. To emphasise the strength of their argument, each one of these doves that have been cut out has a message on it. In most cases it is a prayer, and the name of the student who has written the prayer is on the back of the dove. I think it is a great indication that the general public out there, particularly the children, feel very strongly about this issue. They realise that once a war starts in Iraq the children of Iraq, in particular, will suffer.

speech.para: I am very proud of the fact that, as I said, quite unexpectedly when I went out to present some badges at the Mary Immaculate Primary School at Quakers Hill last week, the students presented me with this quite large box of doves. They have asked me to present them directly to the Prime Minister. I have tried to do that, but I appreciate the fact that the Prime Minister obviously has other things on his mind at the moment. I would certainly like the opportunity, maybe next week when the pressure eases a little, to be able to present these doves directly to the Prime Minister. In the meantime, as I indicated when I commenced my speech, I would certainly be very happy if any honourable members would like to come to my parliamentary office at R2.95 to see the magnificent display of these indications of peace by students from the Mary Immaculate Primary School at Quakers Hill. I thank the Main Committee for its indulgence.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 19 August 2002:

quote.para: (1) Are there any programs administered by the Minister's Department that provide, or have provided, funding to local government authorities in (a) 1996-97, (b) 1997-98, (c) 1998-99, (d) 1999-2000, (e) 2000-2001 and (f) 2001-2002.

(2) If so, for each program for each of the years that funding was granted to local government authorities, (a) what was the level of funding provided to each local government authority, (b) what was the purpose for which the grant was made and (c) in which federal electoral division or divisions does this local government authority fall.

(3) Have any concerns been raised with the Minister's office or the Minister's Department from (a) local government authorities or (b) other organisations regarding cost shifting onto local government in regard to any programs administered by the Minister's Department; if so, (a) to what program or programs did the concern relate and (b) were any investigations undertaken by the Minister's Department in relation to these concerns; if not, why not; if so, what were the findings of these investigations.

talker.name: Anthony, Larry, MP
Mr Anthony
talker.role: Minister for Children and Youth Affairs

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Family and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) Yes

(2) (a) I do not consider appropriate the additional expenditure of resources and effort that would be required to retrieve this information. (b) the Department contracts with a range of service providers to deliver a variety of programs. Programs are delivered by a range of organisations including Local Government Authorities. The following programs have all contracted Local Government Authorities to deliver services.
· Reconnect
· Youth Activity Service and Family Liaison Worker Program
· Job Placement, Education and Training
· Rural Youth Information Sevice
· Collaborative Youth Service Trials
· Innovative and Collaborative Youth Servicing Pilots
· Child Care Support Program
· Disability Program
· Personal Support Program
Further information on these programs is available from the Department's web site http://www.facs.gov.au/
Grants have also been provided to local government authorities for a range of Family and Children's Services through a variety of programs including...
· Provision of adolescent mediation and family therapy
· Provision of financial counselling
· Provision of after hours telephone counselling
· Provision of family relationships skills training
(c) I do not consider appropriate the additional expenditure of resources and effort that would be required to retrieve this information.
(3) (a) (part 1) Yes
(b) (part 1) Yes
(a) (part 2)
The Victorian Sponsors Network Group for Supplementary Services (SUPS) wrote to the Department of Family & Community Services in October 2000 regarding Commonwealth funding for the SUPS program.

On 13 December 2001 correspondence was received by Minister Vanstone's Office from the Local Governments Association of the Northern Territory on behalf of a number of remote Aboriginal Communities regarding Centrelink services.
(b) (part 2)
The Victorian State office of the Department has addressed these issues by working in partnership with the SUPS sponsors to:
· Clarify what the Department expects for the funding a sponsor receives and therefore the role of the SUPS worker;
· Identify and address the key issues associated with the current funding model; and
· Investigate service delivery models that are not solely based on a worker model.

Centrelink conducted a review of what was then the Community Agent Program in 2001, taking into account many of the issues raised in the 1997 Local Government Association of the Northern Territory Report. The letter to Minister Vanstone reflected issues raised in the report. The report stated that Northern Territory local government councils were not being properly reimbursed for costs incurred in the delivery of agency-type arrangements. The key issues raised in relation to the then Community Agents Program were:
1. An increase in payment made under the Community Agent Program to cover the cost incurred by remote local government councils and an expansion of the program to cover all remote communities; and
2. The establishment of “Centrelink Access Points”.

As a result of this review, Centrelink implemented an Integrated Centrelink Agent and Access Point Servicing Model from 1 July 2002, which combined the Community Agent Program and the National Rural and Regional Servicing Strategy. The new model aligns service expectations to current client agency business requirements and removes remuneration and resource inequities.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 4 February 2003:

quote.para: (1) Did the September 2001 report of the Rural Radio Inquiry recommend that the Minister should consider that, for the proposed trials for digital radio broadcasting in regional and remote areas, the potential for satellite digital radio technology should be considered.

(2) Did the December 2002 report of the Radiocommunication Review note that the accessibility to, and development of, satellite-based communications is of particular economic and social importance in Australia.
(3) Has satellite digital sound broadcasting been available to most of the world for more than two years.
(4) Can trials be commenced immediately in north-west Australia using affordable satellite digital radio equipment.

(5) Has satellite digital radio broadcasting the capability to provide early universal service coverage to all of Australia and its territories and to facilitate the early entry of new radio broadcasting interests.

(6) What is the Government's position on conducting trials of satellite digital sound broadcasting, and the application of, and the timetable for introducing, satellite digital radio technology in metropolitan, regional and remote areas.

(7) Did Australia in 1994 through DBStar satellite notification 151.5E require the International Telecommunication Union to reserve a satellite orbit position for Australia to provide satellite digital sound broadcasting services to Australia.
(8) Does the Minister's department now want to suppress this notification.
(9) If the DBStar notification is suppressed, will it set back the introduction of satellite digital sound broadcasting to Australia by at least five years.

(10) Has satellite digital radio broadcasting the capability to provide early universal service coverage to all of Australia and its territories, and to facilitate the early entry of new radio broadcasting interest.
(11) Why is the Government proposing to suppress the DBStar satellite notification.
(12) What is the current Government vision for early access to universal service coverage for digital radio to metropolitan, regional and remote areas.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) Yes (Recommendation 19).

(2) The issue of accessibility to, and development of, satellite-based communications was addressed in the Executive Summary (page 13) and raised in Chapter 11 of the June 2001 Radiocommunications Review report with the recommendation that: the Australian Communications Authority (ACA) monitors developments in satellite charging internationally and conducts public reviews of satellite licence fee charging from time to time (at for instance, four yearly intervals, with the first in 2002).

(3) The US based Worldspace Corporation commenced satellite digital radio broadcasting (direct to consumers) in Africa and the Middle East in 1998, and in most of Asia in 2000. XM Satellite Radio commenced broadcasting in the US in 2001, followed by Sirius Satellite Radio in 2002.

(4) There are no regulatory barriers to conducting such trials. The Government is supportive of trials of digital radio technologies, including terrestrial and satellite systems, particularly in regional and remote areas, depending on the specific spectrum requirements of a particular technology.

(5) While satellite digital radio technology may have the capacity to deliver universal service coverage to all of Australia, the business case for such a service would be a commercial matter to be resolved by the aspirant provider of that service. In addition, there are a number of spectrum planning and service content related requirements of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992 that would need to be considered in the context of licensing a satellite digital radio service.

It is the Government's view that the business cases for the various digital radio delivery technologies are still developing and it is important to work closely with the industry to identify the most appropriate technology for Australia.

(6) The Government is supportive of trials of digital radio technologies, including terrestrial and satellite systems, particularly in regional areas, and will await the outcome of such trials before considering further steps in the allocation of spectrum for digital radio.
(7) Yes.
(8) No. There has been no action to suppress the DBStar satellite notification.
(9) The DBStar notification is not being suppressed.
(10) Response provided at part (5).
(11) The Government has not proposed and is not proposing to suppress the DBStar satellite notification.

(12) Given the slower than expected start up of digital radio overseas, it is the Government's view that business cases for terrestrial, satellite and hybrid applications of digital radio are still developing. It is anticipated that the proposed Commercial Radio Australia digital radio trials and the continuing penetration of different technologies overseas will contribute to a better understanding of the most suitable technology for Australia.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 4 February, 2003:

quote.para: (1) Does the Sydney Harbour Federation Trust have any policies concerning conflict of interest in relation to its Community Advisory Committee.

(2) Do any members of the Community Advisory Committee have a professional, financial or commercial interest in organisations with an association with the Sydney Harbour Federation Trust's properties, activities or projects.
(3) Are members of the Community Advisory Committee required to complete a Declaration of Conflict of Interest form.
(4) Has the Sydney Harbour Federation Trust sponsored activities carried out by any members of its Community Advisory Committee; if so, which activities and what was the cost of this sponsorship.

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr Kemp
talker.role: Minister for the Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) No. The Community Advisory Committee (CAC) is made up of 76 members from a mixture of Commonwealth, State and local government and the general public selected for their detailed knowledge of the sites or issues relevant to the sites. Many members belong to non-government organisations and have a particular interest in the conservation of harbour lands. Members of the CAC were invited to join following an expression of interest process where interested members of the community were asked to submit their interest with details of their relevant experience.

(2) Some members may have a professional, financial or commercial interest in organisations with an association with the Trust's activities or projects, however, the CAC is not a decision making body. It cannot direct the Trust to make particular decisions. It contributes a component of the total community consultation process. It's role is to contribute knowledge and ideas and act as a sounding board for Trust planning proposals, in particular relating to:
· The form and content of the plan;
· Specific land use issues;
· Strategies for the management of the Trust lands;
· Public access to the Trust lands;
· Specific Conservation issues; and
· The consultation process.
(4) The Sydney Harbour Federation Trust has sponsored the following activities carried out by a member of the CAC:

· The Trust co-sponsored a program of activities including snorkelling and introductory scuba diving as part of the Coastcare Summer Program in January 2003. CAC Member Mr W. Jones, a marine biologist and co-ordinator from the Marine Discovery Centre, presented the program. The Marine Discovery Centre is a registered environmental charity.
The program was sponsored for a number of reasons being:
- Creating accessibility to the waters of Trusts sites which were previously not able to be accessed by the public. This assists the Trust in fulfilling our requirement's under the Trust Act; and
- Allowing the Trust to become a part of the Coastcare Summer Program.
The program was sponsored at a cost of $1,000.

· The Trust has commissioned Mrs M. Shelly-Clark, author and historian to write an essay on the History of Cockatoo Island. Mrs Shelley-Clark was selected for this work as she has specialist knowledge of Cockatoo Island as demonstrated in her book The Islands of Sydney Harbour. $3,960 was paid for this work.

· Preliminary work for the Cockatoo Island Conservation Management Plan was recently commissioned by the Trust. Conservation Management Plans are a necessary part of Trust activities in order to return the sites in `good order' as stated in the Trust Act. The work involved a thematic presentation by Mr. J. Semple Kerr in collaboration with Mr J. Jeremy, the former CEO of Cockatoo Island and CAC Member. Mr Jeremy was selected because of his special knowledge as the:
- Last Chief Executive of the dockyard, and
- Author of a comprehensive history of the dockyard Cockatoo Island “Sydney's Historic Dockyard” published by UNSW Press in 1998. This work cost $3,000.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 4 February 2003:

quote.para: (1) What powers does the Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman have to monitor the practices of debt recovery agencies.
(2) Does the Government intend to review the Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman's current power in monitoring debt recovery agencies.
(3) How many complaints have been lodged with the Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman in (a) 2001 and (b) 2002 regarding the practices of debt recovery agencies.
(4) Is the Government aware of debt recovery agencies using fake court notices to intimidate consumers.
(5) How many complaints have been lodged against Hutchinson Telecoms (Australia) Pty Ltd in 2002.
(6) Has the Government been made aware of alleged unreasonable debt recovery practices and failure to keep adequate records by Hutchinson Telecoms (Australia) Pty Ltd.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) The Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman (TIO) already has the authority to investigate and facilitate the resolution of complaints about credit management and debt recovery practices. The Board of the TIO has also made a decision to amend the TIO's constitution to re-affirm its jurisdiction in debt recovery practices. This will ensure that the telecommunications company will remain responsible to its customers and to the TIO in relation to debt recovery complaints, notwithstanding that the debt may have been sold to a debt recovery company.

If the TIO upholds a complaint, the TIO can make a binding determination on the telecommunications company requiring payment of compensation. If the TIO considers that there are systemic complaints about the debt recovery practices of any telecommunications company, the TIO can refer the matter to the Australian Communications Authority (ACA) or the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC).

(2) No. See answer to part (1). It is also relevant that paragraph 113(3)(i) under Part 6 of the Telecommunications Act 1997 states that an industry code may be developed to deal with debt collection practices. The existing Credit Management code developed under the auspices of the Australian Communications Industry Forum sets out minimum practices that must be observed by providers in this area. The code has been registered with the ACA, and the ACA may direct any non-compliant telecommunications company to comply with the code. The code is currently being revised following a public consultation process, prior to being submitted to the ACA for registration. The practice of revising industry codes every two years ensures that they address ongoing community concerns.

(3) The TIO has advised that, as debt recovery agencies are not required to be members of the TIO scheme, data on complaints about these debt recovery agencies is not collected. When the TIO receives a complaint regarding the conduct of a debt recovery agency, it is recorded and taken up with the telecommunications company on whose behalf that the agency is acting. It is important to note that the figures given in (a) and (b) below relate to complaints against telecommunications companies, not debt recovery agencies.

The TIO also advised that changes were made to its complaint-handling database and corresponding complaint categories at the beginning of the 2001-02 financial year. Data for credit control debt related complaints in 2000-01 and 2001-02 is not directly comparable, as data for 2000-01 covers all credit control debt related complaints, whereas data for 2001-02 relates to credit control complaints about debt recovery only.
(a) In 2000-01, the TIO has advised that 3,720 credit control debt related complaints were made against telecommunications companies.

(b) In 2001-02, the TIO has advised that 1,468 debt recovery credit control complaints were made against telecommunications companies. The TIO's media release of 8 January 2003 identified 1,814 debt recovery complaints attributed to telecommunications companies out of a total 4,504 credit control complaints for mobile, landline and internet services during calendar year 2002.

(4) The Government is aware of newspaper reports of a complaint being investigated by the TIO concerning a payment notice entitled “Notice of Summons”. Such demand for payment documents are likely to contravene laws of the Commonwealth, States and Territories dealing with impersonation, obtaining a financial advantage by deception, forgery or use of false or unauthorised documents. The laws on these matters differ depending on the jurisdiction.

(5) The TIO's 2001-02 annual report identified a total of 2,493 complaints to the TIO attributed to Hutchison Telecoms (Australia) Pty Ltd. 300 complaints related to landline services and 2,193 complaints related to mobile services.

Credit control issues accounted for 1.3% of the complaints about landline services and 12.9% of the complaints about mobile services. The TIO has advised that further dissagregation of data to identify complaints about debt recovery practices, in particular, is not publicly available.
(6) The Government has not been made aware of specific allegations about unreasonable debt recovery practices of Hutchison Telecoms (Australia) or its failure to keep adequate records.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 5 February 2003:

quote.para: Is the Minister able to say whether, since the answer by the Minister for the Arts and Centenary of Federation to question No. 1674 (Hansard, 31 August 2000, page 19963), there have been changes to British laws which constrain certain government funded institutions, such as the British Museum and the British Natural History Museum, from returning collection items.
The question was transferred to the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs on the 13 February 2003.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: The British Government has not yet amended its legislation to enable publicly funded museums and other institutions to return collection items. The British Government established the UK Working Group on Human Remains following the release of the Prime Ministerial Joint Statement on Aboriginal Remains on 4 July 2000. That Working Group, chaired by Professor Norman Palmer, is examining the current legal status of human remains kept in government funded museums and galleries in the United Kingdom. It is expected that the Working Group will report its findings to the British Parliament towards the middle of this year.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 5 February 2003:

quote.para: (1) In their joint statement on 4 July 2000 did the British and Australian Prime Ministers welcome the initiative of the British Natural History Museum in cataloguing the 450 indigenous human remains in its collection and in providing this information to the Australian Government.
(2) Have any of the Museum's human remains been returned to Australia.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The following information is provided in response to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) Yes, in their joint statement, the British and Australian Prime Ministers welcomed the British Natural History Museum's initiative to catalogue Australian Indigenous human remains held in its collection and provide that information to the Australian Government.

(2) No human remains have been returned to Australia from the British Natural History Museum. Under the current legislation, the Museum is unable to de-accession human remains contained within its collection. The British government has established an Expert Working Group to examine whether amendments to legislation should be introduced to allow publicly funded museums to return human remains.
ATSIC made written and oral submissions to the Working Group in 2001. I understand that the report is expected to be finalised towards the middle of this year.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 6 February 2003:

quote.para: What projects did the Australia Council fund in the Melbourne metropolitan area in (a) 2001-02 and (b) 2002-03 and what was the (i) expenditure on, (ii) location of, and (iii) purpose of, each project.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: The Australia Council has provided the following information.

entry.para: Hooper to build a large snowdome from moulded acrylics and wood with a cast metal skeleton. Inside the dome will be characters that relate to the `spy' theme of the exhibition which is titled `Looking around Corners'. Held at Westspace, Melbourne, Nov 2001.
Parker's work includes creating ceramic lustres over a glazed form to replicate the pearlesque and metallic qualities appearing on the surface of inflatable balloons.
Tour of Mick Thomas and The Sure Thing to UK and Ireland.

Interdisciplinary sound practitioner, Rainer Linz received a two-year Fellowship to create new work through R&D, specifically designed to investigate the behaviour of sound in responsive systems leading to new Internet, installation and performance works.

For the production and staging of `Soft', a multi-disciplined theatrical event merging architectural design, live performance, animation and surround sound to explore and examine the current social debate and implications involving genetic screening.
A collaboration between visual artist Simon Terrill and documentary film-maker Simon Price to embark on a scavenger hunt exploring the hitchhikers mode of perception.

Received funding toward `Gloss', a Japanese/Australian collaborative program incorporating a major exhibition, national and international tour, bi-lingual magazine and website commissioned by, and presented at, the Centre for Contemporary Photography and the Candy Factory, Yokohama, Japan.

Trans/Actions is a pilot program to research and implement two residencies providing direct experience to new media artists of social justice and human rights organisations - the Irati Wanti campaign of the Senior Aboriginal Women of Coober Pedy and the Asia Pacific Support Collective in East Timor.

A four week creative development period of `An Imaginary Place/A Constructed World (Something Happens)'. The first piece in Shelley's Theatre Series: Phase Two, she worked with a team of dancers and collaborating artists.

2002 Program of Activity - included the core program of performance opportunities, workshops and critical debate for dance artists and audiences. Key projects included `Bodyworks Festival of Moving Arts', `Great Escapes', `B'Screen' and the Choreographic Development and Residency Program.

Development of practice whereby community stories are told through the collaborative process of developing digital media product to further the work of historical societies and museums in regional towns in Victoria and SA.

A comprehensive multi-artform program of community cultural development with a focus on advocacy and lobbying, sustainability and regional, national and international development for artists with a disability and their communities.
North Richmond Community Health Centre Inc

Arts program involving culturally and linguistically diverse communities including public housing residents and community health centre clients. The program will cover a broad range of arts activities from multi-media through to community arts festivals.
Attendance at ARCO (Arco Cotemporaneo) 2002, international contemporary art exhibition, Madrid.
Attendance at ARCO (Arco Cotemporaneo) 2002, international contemporary art exhibition, Madrid.
Attendance at ARCO (Arco Cotemporaneo) 2002, international contemporary art exhibition, Madrid.
Attendance at ARCO (Arco Cotemporaneo) 2002, international contemporary art exhibition, Madrid.
Attendance at ARCO (Arco Cotemporaneo) 2002, international contemporary art exhibition, Madrid.
Attendance at ARCO (Arco Cotemporaneo) 2002, international contemporary art exhibition, Madrid.
Costs for the Artistic Director Douglas Horton to attend meetings in Europe with artistic collaborators, opera companies, and the conference NewOp 10, 1 to 21 October 2001.

Contribution to the Manager's travel costs associated with the performances of Archie Roach and Ruby Hunter at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Next Wave Down Under Festival in New York, and associated market development activities, 2 to 11 October 2001.

Arena produces work that has an intimate dialogue with young people. Based in Melbourne their shows address new theatrical conventions and tour nationally and internationally. Works included the premiere of `Game Girl' and tours of `Australian Marriage Act' and `Oblong'.

Based in Melbourne, the partnership of director Ariette Taylor and playwright Daniel Keene have produced 19 new plays and will continue to create works which give audiences an immediate, exciting theatrical experience reflecting unexplored areas of contemporary Australian life.

MWT is a professional, research-based and artist-controlled company developing new works in Melbourne. At the forefront of Australian political/social theatre scene since 1987, their program includes a new work `Fever', that re-unites the creative team of `Who's Afraid of the Working Class?'.

`The Ice Lillies' is a new opera composed by Elena Kats-Cherin, libretto by Xenia Hanusiak, exploring the quest for eternal life, society's relationship to beauty and anti-aging processes. The workshop explored and developed the written text and the visual staging of the work.

5 Angry Men plan to develop and produce `The Flag' after successfully touring `The Bells' to festivals all over Europe. The Company integrates traditional theatre with performance art and innovative technology in highly physical outdoor productions.

Lally Katz to curate `Primetime', 5 new theatre projects by young artists, to be presented every night of the 2002 Next Wave Festival in Melbourne. Each new work explores unconventional approaches to theatre making employing a range of media with a duration of 24 mins each.
Sixth novel exploring psychological themes connecting Australia with Mediterranean societies, with a particular focus on cultural and historical stereotypes of Mediterranean women.
A second novel from award winning writer about two Australian backpackers who spend a turbulent summer in a farming community in the south of France.
A third work of fiction by award winning author that delves beneath the surface of Western optimism and prosperity and finds social, economic and emotional disenfranchisement.
A novel written in Gelbach's native Russian about three men living on different continents whose lives are uncannily linked by a controversial novel set during the Cold War.

A novel investigating what it is to be a farmer in a land with no agricultural history. Set in the Mallee during the 1930s and inspired by Victoria's Better Farming Train, the novel investigates our relationship with the land and the many myths surrounding the outback and farming communities.
Book of poetry, photography and photographic essays involving the documentation of eight of Australia's well known outback tracks.

Three theatrical works; a full-length play exploring the divide between city and country, a sequence of short, thematically linked plays dealing with homelessness and a series of short plays and monologues focussing on contemporary social issues.
Novel for young adults about how we `interpret' our families, both biological and those we recognise as `our own', and a collection of short stories for young adults.

Sequel to fourth novel, `The Art of the Engine Driver', this new story picks up the characters' lives, four years later. A family saga set against the backdrop of the legendary 1960-61 West Indies cricket tour of Australia.
Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Arts Board

To support the 2002 Next Wave Festival Indigenous program `Black is the New Black'. The program will be curated by Sarah Bond in collaboration with Next Wave's Indigenous Art Reference Group and integrated into the main program of the Festival.
Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Arts Board

To record and promote the artist's CD `Kasa Kedtha'. The CD is Ricardo's first and will tell the traditional and contemporary stories of Mer, the people of Murray Island, through songs with high cultural values.
University of Melbourne through Asialink Centre
Program costs for visual arts, literature, performing arts and arts management residencies in Asia.

The grant was given towards the 2002 annual concert series of contemporary chamber and choral music at various venues around Melbourne. The series commenced 7/4/2002 at the Gasworks Theatre, with the Astra Choir conducted by John McCaughey.

The grant was a contribution to 2002 activities including The Boite World Music Cafe, the 12th Boite Singers' Festival at Daylesford, the Melbourne Millennium Chorus, the 10th Boite Winter Festival, and collaboration with the other organisations.

The grant was towards core costs for the 2002 program of support and development of community music in Victoria. The organisation engages in partnerships with local government to present workshops and music projects and resources community music practitioners through expansion of its web site.

This grant was a contribution to Dominik Karski's fee to compose a new work for solo piano (Mark Knoop), winds and percussion for premiere in 2003. The work forms part of Libra Ensemble's strategy to commission `companion' pieces to established works from the past century.

The Music Board's grant was a commission for new works by Adrian Sherriff, Elliott Dalgleish and Daryl Pratt. The new work added to the existing body of work `Into the Fire', an ongoing collaboration between the Australian Art Orchestra and the Sruthi Laya Quartet.

The Music Board's grant was a contribution to costs for the manufacture, distribution and promotion of the CD `Symbol Chaser'. `Symbol Chaser' is a collaboration between Frances Tang and Leigh Ryan. The CD was to be launched at Revolver, Melbourne, during March 2002.
Melbourne International Festival of Organ & Harpsichord

The grant was for the presentation of the 2002 festival of early and contemporary music. The Festival featured 22 concerts held over ten days in the autumn from Friday 26 April to Sunday 5 May 2002 and featured the Australian Brandenburg Orchestra and new music group Machine for Making Sense.
Three month residency at the London Studio, UK.

Three temporary commissioned projects for the opening of ACCA at new cultural precinct. Works by Louise Weaver; Callum Morton; Mathew Jones were exhibited over a six month period for two months each, from January 2001.
Four issues of LIKE art magazine (No.17 -20). LIKE Art Magazine is a forum for the analysis, review and record of current developments in visual arts and crafts culture.
Australian participation in exhibitions at Wienstation and Palais Porcia, `Vienna for Global Fusions' in March 2002.
Three month residency at 18th Street Arts Complex, Los Angeles, USA.
Three month residency at Tokyo Studio, Japan.
Three month residency in the Milan Studio, Italy.

Explore and produce cast metal objects with asymmetric shapes. In order to achieve this Karl set up a program defining the parameters of lost wax metal casting and established a relationship with AW Bell castings.
Three month residency at 18th Street Arts Complex, Los Angeles, USA.
Development of a manuscript on contemporary Australian artists entitled 40 good ideas, which is an introduction to 40 contemporary Australian artists.
International visitor: Fergus Linehan, Director, Dublin Theatre Festival, to Australia October 2001.
Commission to create a medal for the 2001 recipients of the Visual Arts/Craft Board Emeritus Award and Medal.
Australia Business Arts Foundation Awards Event 2002.
Assistance towards publication and distribution of `Silent Army: An Australian Comic Anthology' (collaborative partnership with Next Wave Festival).
Assistance towards marketing and advertising of `Silent Army: An Australian Comic Anthology' (collaborative partnership with Express Media).
Primary Source Inc Trading as Strange Fruit
Business planning and risk management consultancy, and administrative support for the company.

The 2002 International Jazz Festival was held from 18-27/1/2002 and featured leading and emerging artists, including international guest artists such as US ensemble The Mingus Big Band, US Saxophonist Marshall Allen, and Australian artists, Mark Isaacs, Joe Chindamo and the Australian Art Orchestra.

Travel to South Africa, New Zealand and Tasmania created opportunities for Victorian craft practitioners through international exchange and to develop projects based on craft practice in the Southern Hemisphere.
A contribution to IMPACT presenting artists Little G, Native Ryme Syndicate, Brolga Boys and Nokturnal.
University of Melbourne through Asialink Centre

Partnership between Asialink, the Australia Council, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and State/Territory agencies for a tour of a group exhibition to the Philippines, an exhibition of Peter Callas to Taiwan, Malaysia and India and to develop an artists exchange between Hanoi and Melbourne artists.

The triennial grant assisted the Orchestra to expand its performance activities principally in Melbourne and Sydney, assisted by a partnership agreement with the Sydney Opera House Trust. The improvising orchestra draws musicians from NSW, Victoria and Queensland and is directed by Paul Grabowsky.

The grant assisted a three-year program of choral performance. The Melbourne Chorale performances include collaborations resulting in innovative presentation of choral music. A co-commission with the Swedish Radio Choir was to result in a new work by Brett Dean in the 2002 season.

Creative Time in New York is a world leader presenting new work by artists in unlikely and abandoned public spaces. The residency was to enable Andy to initiate partnerships between organisations in Melbourne and New York and contribute to his work in the youth and public art sector.
To increase Julie's skills in multimedia and website design to further her work with multicultural communities and in the area of community cultural development.
Towards fares, fees and expenses for Australian writers to participate in the 2002 program of the Australian Centre for Youth Literature.

Commissioning of a new work developed from the stories of newly arrived `boat people' from central Asia and the Middle East. The project aims to disseminate the true stories of people granted Temporary Protection Visas.
The development and presentation of a multimedia performance piece with Melbourne Worker's Theatre in conjunction with the Yorta Yorta community and the Cummeragunja choir.
The Centre for Education and Research in Environmental Strategies
Development of an entrance artwork for the Centre for Education and Research in Environmental Strategies (CERES) Environmental Park, through community participation in the design and construction.
Towards writers' fees and journal costs for the publication of ten issues of Australian Book Review in 2002. Australian Book Review is edited by author/editor Peter Rose.
Supported the work of young Australian writers under 25 through the payment of fees to young writers published in Voiceworks in 2002. Four issues of Voiceworks are published every year.
Meanjin Company Limited - University of Melbourne
Towards the payment of fees to writers and journal costs for the publication of four issues of Meanjin in 2002. Meanjin is edited by Ian Britain.

Towards the payment of fees to Australian contributors in the four issues of the literary journal Overland to be published in 2002; and towards one issue of the on-line magazine, overland express; and four public lectures scheduled for 2002; and towards conference costs.
6 week residency at the Tyrone Guthrie Centre, Ireland, 2002.
200 Gertrude Street (Gertrude Street Artist Spaces Inc)
Attendance at ARCO (Arco Cotemporaneo) 2002, international contemporary art exhibition, Madrid- Exhibitions - Screen Life.
Mentorship and development program for young and emerging writers.

Collaboration between Lucy Orta and Australian artists to develop work with marginalised communities through interdisciplinary arts practice. Australian artists from a range of disciplines push the boundaries of their practice by creating work within the context of social disadvantage.

Erik Griswold, Sarah Pirrie and Craig Foltz to develop `Permanent Transit', a multimedia installation exploring themes of transit and community. Innovative use of text, music, visual and communications media create a performance work including live internet and film projections.

`Motherload' was a research and development project exploring themes of contemporary genetic science and theory, and the female body. The three performance artists consulted with genetic scientists and work with multi-media artist Sarah Waterson to create an integrated performance and installation.

`Petrol Head' was a dynamic, large-scale, site specific interdisciplinary performance work, inspired by the real life story of Australian motorcycle daredevil Dale Buggins. `Petrol Head' was to be premiered as part of the Next Wave Festival, Melbourne 2002.

Collaborated with Jans Anger to create new work titled `DON'T EVEN GO THERE', utilising a limited edition of palm pilots installed with GPS (Global Positioning Systems). The work/map plotted sentiment, and the GPS will alert the user whenever they came close to a sad coordinate.

Attendance at 11th International Symposium on Electronic Art (ISEA) in Nagoya, Japan. While in Japan Mr Mowson also visited museums and galleries, and made recordings in connection with his current practice - the use of radio in sound art and textile/sound hybridity.

Two-week residency at the Tokyo Metropolitan Museum of Photography in Japan, December 2002. The residency was devised as a research and inquiry project into contemporary Japanese photography and new media arts practice. Ms Rhodes was mentored by Ms Michiko Kasahara, Curator at the TMMP.

For travel to Aichi Prefecture in Japan to study under Shobei Tamaya, a ninth generation karakuri ningyo craftsman. The project developed the artist's skills to produce kakakuri robot dolls. A public exhibition/installation of the karakuri dolls made was presented.

Development and presentation of the second stage of a trilogy of new works, titled `Self-Encasing'. Inspired by the Thomas Grunfield Exhibition `Deformation Professionnelle' (Cologne, 1999), this is a collaborative project and was performed in Melbourne by four dancers in June 2002.
Sarah Cathcart to study and research choreography and physical forms in America and Belgium, conduct a laboratory with physical performers in Melbourne and to research material for a new solo work.

`Teratology' is a multi-arts, site-specific, promenade performance work exploring the new frontiers of genetic science. Created by ICE, the same creative team behind the Green Room award-winning `Tower of Light', `Teratology' will be staged in the disused Preston and Northcote Community Hospital.
Primary Source Inc Trading as Strange Fruit

Internationally acclaimed physical theatre company Strange Fruit to tour their new production `The Spheres' to Europe, Singapore and Canada. `The Spheres', performed on large free standing poles, is a whimsical poetic outdoor spectacle taking us from the everyday to celestial wonder.

To investigate the influence that sign language can have within the artforms of mime, voice, music and physical theatre, theatre maker Jodee Mundy attended an intensive training in corporal mime in London and attended the International Deaf Way Festival in July 2002 in Washington, USA.

Professional development for actor/director Kate Herbert to develop advanced skills in the process of creating full length improvised plays through attachments with four American improvisation companies (BATS Theatre, True Fiction Magazine, Three For All, LATS Theatre) from June to September 2002.
Australian Children's Television Foundation - 20th Anniversary Symposium - Assistance towards International Speakers.
Australian Exposure - Sapphire Music Pty Ltd.

Placement with Shopfront Theatre for Young People and Big hART as assistant director and writer/facilitator. Return to Melbourne to establish The Crucible- International Centre for Social Action and the Arts.
Sarah Bond will work with Ibijeri and Next Wave towards the development of five text-based works from young indigenous writers for KickstART 2003.

The publication of a theoretical model of community cultural development articulating a range of professional practice considerations for artists working in the area. It will be based on longitudinal research based within the Artful Dodgers Studio.

Melbourne Workers Theatre's Assistant Company Manager, Michelle Evans, to undertake a period of mentorship and training with John Paxinos and Associates to develop skills and expertise in financial management.

This grant was towards the creation of a continuous 18-hour electronic soundpiece for Next Wave's Colony project. Held during the Next Wave Festival, 17 to 26 May 2002, Colony involved five `angels' occupying the spire of the Victorian Arts Centre, with an `other-world' aural soundscape.
This grant was a contribution toward the creation of the musical score and libretto for a new chamber opera titled `Media' created between May 2002 and May 2003.

This grant was a contribution to the creative development of the sound art work `Oculus'. The work is a collaborative project between Yetnikov (string trio), Opera Somatica (performance group), and Snawklor (electronic duo) creative development to take place in September 2002.
This grant was a contribution to the creation and development of the musical score, libretto and sound design for a new media opera titled `Artesian' developed collaboratively from May to July 2002.

The grant was towards the inaugural Sheer Pluck Festival of plucked string instruments curated by Geoffrey Morris (guitarist) and Samantha Cohen (lutenist). The Festival, held from 21 November to 24 November 2002, featured repertoire from the Renaissance to new works.

The grant was a contribution to the completion of the debut recording of the Fiona Burnett Trio and CD manufacture /marketing. The Trio presents a new musical direction for the leader and features original compositions by Fiona Burnett. The music embraces a range of musical influences.

The grant was a contribution towards a performance series in Bendigo and Melbourne, with a final performance of emerging composers' work. Geminiani Chamber Orchestra provides training for young and emerging professional musicians.

The grant was a contribution to the recording, manufacture and marketing of Arte Kanela's debut CD release. The group presents an innovative approach to contemporary Flamenco music and performance over the past ten years through its references to jazz, funk and rock.

The grant assisted saxophonist Fiona Burnett participate in a three-week jazz program with five other Australian musicians at Banff Centre in Canada. The residency allowed the musicians to collaborate and develop new repertoire.

The grant was towards a period of study in France focusing on traditional Persian music with Hossein Omoumi, to develop modal improvisation techniques. Rachael Cogan is a recorder player who has expanded the repertoire through her collaborations with other instruments and musical traditions.

The grant was towards a period of professional development at the Tianjian Conservatory of Music in China to expand repertoire and develop instrument repair skills for Chinese instruments such as the sheng (Chinese mouth organ).
For a tour of Brazil by the Melbourne Chorale from 8 - 23 May 2002.
Literature International Market Development - Interim Funding Round - Spinifex Press.
Literature International Market Development - Interim Funding Round - Melbourne University Press.
Provision of a small and fast response grant program to Victorian craft practitioners to assist them with expenses associated with the presentation and promotion of craft exhibitions.

As part of the Commonwealth Government's Emerging Artists Initiative the Visual Arts/Craft Board provided support to BUS, an artist-run-space in Melbourne's CBD. Opened in August 2001, the gallery's philosophy is to support new and emerging practitioners with an emphasis on collaboration and audience involvement. A Sound Space was established to facilitate new media within contemporary art practice.

As part of the Commonwealth Government's Emerging Artists Initiative the Visual Arts/Craft Board provided support to Platform Artists Group, an artist-run-initiative established in 1990. The support offered in 2002 assisted with the representation of traditional and non-traditional media, electronic media, related art and design practice and comment. Platform will continue to explore modes of display which stretch the traditions of public art practices.

As part of the Commonwealth Government's Emerging Artists Initiative the Visual Arts/Craft Board provided support to Seventh Gallery. Established in 2000, the gallery's aim is to bridge the gap between art school and professional practice. The 2002 program continued to provide support for artists as well as maintained the established curatorial objective of 2001.

As part of the Commonwealth Government's Young and Emerging Artists Initiative, the Visual Arts/Craft Board provided support for program costs for West Space. Established in 1993 in Melbourne, the gallery has encouraged artists to broaden their activities to include new technologies and offers artists specialised equipment to assist them with their practice. The 2002 program included a range of exhibitions by emerging and less established artists as well as six West Space projects such as `Gating' a visual and sound exhibition and publication project which included local, interstate and international artists.
Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Arts Board
Funded Children's Entertainment Group, Koori Connection for props and costumes.
Tour of `Los Mariachis Ilegales', an open-air music theatre work, to the Just for Laughs Festival, Montreal, Canada.
Phillip Adams Workshop at the International Dance Festival Berlin 2002.
International visitor: Mr Masaaki Koga, Daidogei World Cup, Japan, to Next Wave Festival, Melbourne, May 2002.
Major Festivals Initiative (MFI): Love in the Age of Therapy at the 2002 Melbourne International Arts Festival and 2003 Sydney Festival.

To develop, produce, promote, and evaluate `p>review', an audience development strategy for Arena Theatre Company's production, `Petrol Head', targeting senior secondary school and university students.

To develop, produce, promote and evaluate `fART', an exhibition of humorous contemporary visual art, to be held in conjunction with the Melbourne International Comedy Festival and the Next Wave Festival, targeting 18-35 year olds.
Australian EXPOSURE - Rubber Records for Popkomm 2002.
Travel and related costs for Libra Ensemble to participate at the 2002 Roaring Hoofs Festival of New Music in Mongolia, 9 to 17 June 2002.

As part of the Commonwealth Government's Young and Emerging Artists Initiative, the Visual Arts/Craft Board provided support for a youth craft mentorship at Craft Victoria. This three month project was offered to emerging craft practitioners to enable them to work with a mentor to further develop their practice. A furniture designer, Warren Hansford was the recipient of this mentorship in 2002 and he worked with an established designer, Tony Stuart, to develop furniture designs for production.
Kultour 2002 Fouad Harraka, Arabic-Australian 8 piece band.
A visual arts exhibition entitled `Human Nature' by Italian-Australian artist Lee Salamone.

Juan Ford to travel to Spain for four months to research new ideas to combining imagery subjected to planar anamorphosis (a distorted image on a flat surface appears normal when viewed from a particular point) with realist imagery in painting, promote his work internationally and network in Europe.

Blanche Tilden to, through a focused period of research, design development and technical experimentation, create a body of new jewellery. The new work will challenge conventional ideas about the use of glass in contemporary jewellery. The works were exhibited at Gallery Funaki, Melbourne in 2004.

Charles Green and Lyndell Brown to create a new body of works based around four words: arcadia, utopia, microcosm and island. The works began as paintings that are then transformed into digitally printed photographs. They were exhibited in solo and group shows in Melbourne and Sydney in late 2003.

David Harley to create a series of new digital prints that will be exhibited in selected architectural spaces in Melbourne such as lifts, foyers and cupolas of buildings. The works explore the optical and physical conditions of the two dimensional surface.

Gary Wilson to create a series of large three dimensional forms made of copper and steel that are shaped using heat and the assistance of a sheet metal worker. The steel works will incorporate some painted surfaces and will be a synthesis of earlier painting and sculptural works.

Lisa Young to create a new body of sculptures and installations that give form to the possibilities of modular interlocking systems. The idea that repeated units when cojoined with others can form endlessly flexible compositions is explored.

Lyndal Jones to create a series of installation works where strong emotions are focussed upon. The project involved working with a range of people from different cultures/linguistic backgrounds to create a series of video/sound projections for exhibition in 2003.

Melinda Harper to create a series of large silk screen prints that were presented as a boxed portfolio containing six prints accompanied by text. The aim of the work was to explore colour and form in a more reductive and concentrated way. Exhibited in Brisbane, Melbourne and Sydney.

Peter Atkins to create three separate bodies of mixed media works over a three month period for solo exhibition in 2002 and 2003. The works were to be exhibited at Sherman Galleries in Sydney, Tolarno Galleries in Melbourne and Greenaway Gallery in Adelaide.

Suzanne Spunner to research and write a critical survey of contemporary visual art made in the Northern Territory over the last twenty five years. Entitled `Looking Both Ways: Art since Land Rights', the survey takes into consideration works produced by black and white artists during this period.
Gail Patricia Hannah trading as Black Pepper
Publication of four new poetry titles and one novel.
Publication of four reprints and at least one new work of fiction.
Afshin Nikouseresht to coordinate the production of his script, `There is Nothing There', a new work which tells the story of an asylum seeker trying to assert his cultural identity.

Red Cabbage 8 are a collective of contemporary visual, performance and multimedia artists. Their project `Halful of Happiness' is an outdoor/indoor installation incorporating live music and movement and built around the themes of emptiness, invasion and fear.
AMA Professional Development Program for the multicultural arts sector.

Public Art project involving four communities of marginalised young people in Melbourne. This project explored issues of homelessness amongst young people in Ballarat, Macedon Ranges Shire and Melbourne.
The Centre for Education and Research in Environmental Studies

Seeking Sanctuary - Stories of Migration developed the migration parallels between people and Kingfishers through theatre and storytelling it was the featured performance at the 9th Return of the Sacred Kingfisher Festival.
A community writing project involving people who care for children or adults with a disability in the rural community of Cooinda. A publication with participants stories and photos to be produced.
`The Torch, Re-igniting Community', a theatre-based project that explores history, culture, identity and belonging in the Bairnsdale and Warrnambool regions of Victoria.
2003 Museum Leadership Program to deliver a tailored world-class professional development program for high level Australian museum professionals.
To exhibit sound/video installation `Close' at `Emocao Art.ificial', Symposium, Sao Paulo, Brazil.
Attendance at Frankfurt 2002, visit to London and Attendance at Bologna 2003.
Attendance at Frankfurt and, visit to London, Amsterdam, New York.
Attendance at Frankfurt 2002, London Book Fair 2003, BEA 2003, and extension stays in New York and London and Catalogue production.

To develop a performance and interactive project, utilising digital technologies, about gesture in India, Ireland and Australia. Research to be undertaken at the Sarai Centre, New Dehli and in Ireland, culminating in an installation performance at Mass Gallery and Experimenta, Melbourne.

Attendance at two concurrent conferences held at IRCAM: `Resonances 2002', the international convention on technologies for music and `ISMIR 2002', the third international conference on music information retrieval, Paris, France, October, 2002.

Attendance at the `QUINTESSENCE: The Clumpy Matter of Art, Math and Science Visualisation', a summit for advanced science visualisation hosted by the Banff New Media Institute, Alberta, Canada, September, 2002.

Australian Sound Design website to publish online artists' work for sound design in public space, an emergent interdisciplinary practice. Video, text, audio and drawings will provide a new form of documentation, allowing the viewer to enter work in an audio visual temporal manner.

The 2003 program for Dancehouse includes regular classes, choreographic development and research, mentor and production support and curated performance platforms - `Bodyworks', `Mixed Metaphor' and `Great Escapes at the Fringe'.

Lucy Guerin Dance Company's 2003 activities include a USA/Canada tour of `Melt', a film collaboration with UK-based Ricochet Dance Company and a new work titled `Multiple Solos' to be presented at the Melbourne International Festival.

Johnny Tedesco to travel to Spain to undertake an intensive study and master classes in Flamenco dance. He attended master classes at the Festival de Jerez in Seville as well as classes at Amor De Dois, Madrid and Escula Cristina Heeren, Seville.
A contribution towards the recording of three contemporary percussion works.
A six-week tour of the UK and USA by Darren Hanlon from 16 Aug - 1 Oct 2002.
To present `Variable Resistance' at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, 7-17 September 2002.
Cultural Development Network of Victoria (Melbourne City Council)
Program support to develop resources, networks and discourse for community cultural development in Victoria focussing on partnerships with non-arts sectors.
Assistance to participate in `Maps', a Danish-Australian music project from 1 Oct - 31 March 2003.
Assistance with production of a spoken word CD featuring young writers.
Assistance with development of a text-based performance, `The Glass Garden', featuring young writers.
Assistance with production of a video-zine, DV:Neo Poetry.

Melbourne Workers Theatre is a professional, research-based and artist controlled company developing new works. At the forefront of Australian political/social theatre scene since 1987, their program includes a new work `1975' a populist opera and `No!' about the land rights claim of the Yorta Yorta.
Primary Source Inc Trading as Strange Fruit

Strange Fruit is a company dedicated to presenting large-scale outdoor performance, which uniquely blends dance-theatre with sculpture, circus and spectacle. The company tours extensively and in 2003 will visit Spain, Japan, China, North America and Chile.

International collaboration with Centre Choreographique National de Creteil et du Val-de-Marne and Compagnie Montalvo-Hervieu with Mene Mene, director Michael Kantor, writer Tom Wright, composer Jonathon Mills. `The Southern Land Known' is a vision of Australia from a 17th Century Frenchman.

Writer/ performer Caroline Lee's new work `The Three Interiors of Lola Strong' is a solo installation performance piece about an architect whose search for her own identity leads to an exploration of interior, exterior and mythic spaces. Performed in Melbourne, February 2003.

`Inhabited Woman' is a collaborative, visual, textual, physical performance project written by Richard Murphett, performed by Leisa Shelton, exploring the new place contemporary women occupy in society. Production will be in Melbourne, June 2003.
Venice 2001 - OnTouring - Contribution towards artist's trip to Sweden.
AbaF Business Arts Partnership Awards: Australia Council Major Partnership for Media Arts Award and Artistic Program.
University of Melbourne through Asialink Centre
Asialink: Literature Touring in Asia program (2002-03).

Davis to explore the relationship between globalisation and race in his second work of non-fiction. He will track the rise of the new right since the mid-1970s, showing how new economic rationalism has impacted on non-whites in both the developing world and in major Western democracies.

The completion of a first collection of poetry which sets out to create a sense of the marvellous through each poem's representation of uncanny, eccentric and oddball scenarios which translate into moments of truth and/or beauty.

Award-winning playwright will continue her exploration of culture, judgement and right and wrong through a play about the suicide of a young teacher following allegations of sexual misconduct with pupils.

Final draft of a first novel about family and dysfunction told in the unconventional voice of a gifted teenage girl from a poor Sydney family who lives as an exchange student for a year in an affluent mid-west city in the US. First/second draft of a second novel about family, first-love and lies.

Award-winning writer will work on a collection of short fiction containing previous pieces published in literary magazines and journals, as well as new material in the form of very short prose pieces with a satirical thrust and some longer pieces to form the spine of the collection.

The grant is a contribution to the 2003 Astra concert series of choral and chamber music. The series presents contemporary music making as well as little-known repertoire from the past, and features the Astra Choir conducted by John McCaughey.

The grant was towards the state-wide program of community music facilitation through music co-ordination, core activities such as information exchange through data base development and production and distribution of the bi-monthly newsletter `Shout'. The program also initiates training and projects.
Melbourne International Festival of Organ & Harpsichord

The grant is for a contribution to the presentation of the 2003 Autumn Music Festival and related costs. The Festival from 2 to 11 May 2003, under the direction of recorder virtuoso Genevieve Lacey, plans to present a program of innovation and revitalisation of the presentation of early music.

The grant is a contribution to the 2003 program featuring professional artists from diverse musical cultures. The grant will assist core costs of the program including the World Music Cafe and Daylesford Singers' Festival. The 15th World Music Cafe series will promote new works and collaborations.

The grant will assist the 2003 program of contemporary music theatre commissioning, development and presentation. The company aims to broaden the parameters of music theatre performances through cross-artform collaboration and commissioning.

This grant was for Richard Mills to compose a 15 minute song cycle with text by Judith Wright for mezzo soprano Elizabeth Campbell. The work is to be performed at the Coriole Festival in Victoria in 2003 and recorded on the Tall Poppies label.

The grant is to assist a multi-state tour to promote a newly recorded CD featuring the jazz group IshIsh. The tour beginning 21 November 2002 to NSW, SA and ACT and includes performances and workshops in regional and metropolitan centres.

This grant was a contribution towards the presentation of the 2003 Melbourne International Festival held from 17 to 27 January 2003. Festival Director Adrian Jackson has assembled leading and emerging artists across a range of jazz styles, from overseas, interstate and the local jazz scene.

The grant was a contribution towards the recording of new works by New Music Lighthouse Association for CD release. The CD will feature works performed by Michael Kieran Harvey and will act as a promotional tool for the ensemble. The recording will also serve to promote new Australian music.

This project involves the recording of new jazz compositions by the Paul Williamson Quintet for CD release. This recording called `Mutations' will feature new jazz compositions inspired by visual artist Joanna Posa's recent work. The CD will be recorded in Melbourne and promoted through the VCA.
Studio 52 Recordings P/L (ITF Studio 52 Management Trust)
This grant is a contribution towards national live showcases of emerging bands for the Kool Skools project. Showcase performances will be held in each State capital city in October 2003.

This grant was towards a professional development program for the Flinders Quartet at the Banff Centre for the Arts, Canada. The Melbourne-based quartet spent 6 weeks between 6 January and 28 February 2003 rehearsing and preparing repertoire prior to participation in international competitions.

This grant was towards an advanced study tour in India for guitarist/tabla player Glen Kniebeiss to develop his skills as a tabla player. He will be the guest and pupil of Ustad (master) Anthony Dass in New Delhi between 5 January and 5 April 2003.
The grant provides travel costs for the artist to perform at the Centre for the Study of Free-Reed Instruments in New York and promotional activities, 17 March to 5 April 2003.
Australian Exposure 02/03 - Trifekta Records for CMJ, New York, USA, Oct/Nov 2002.
International visitors Maria Magdalena Schwaegermann and Frie Leysen to attend Chamber Made Opera's Motherland at the 2002 Melbourne Festival, October 2002.
Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Arts Board

Tong Briggs will research and write a musical theatre titled `The Sapphires'. The work will tell the true story of four young Aboriginal women who travelled to Vietnam to entertain the Australian troops.
Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Arts Board

The Melbourne Workers Theatre with 6 Yorta Yorta artists will present a theatre production entitled `No' at the New Ballroom in Melbourne between September and October 2003. `No' will examine the negative judgement by the Federal Court in 1998 against the Yorta Yorta nation.

Art and Film', an exhibition and catalogue exploring the influence of the cinema on contemporary art practice. Intended to coincide with the 2003 Melbourne International Film Festival, the exhibition is interdisciplinary in nature and includes photography, video, painting, sculpture and installation.
`Between You and Me', a national forum and publication connecting a range of Indigenous and multicultural issues for craft practice in the Asia-Pacific region.
Gertrude Contemporary Art Spaces (Gertrude Street Artists Spaces)

`A Short Ride in a Fast Machine - Gertrude Contemporary Art Spaces 20 Years On'. Research and compilation of archived and newly commissioned texts and images related to the history of Gertrude Contemporary Art Spaces and its role in the development of contemporary art practice.
University of Melbourne through Asialink Centre

Three touring exhibitions of Australian art and craft to ten venues in Asia: `Photographica Australis' curated by Alasdair Foster; `Dorothy Napangardi', curated by Vivienne Webb; `Out There: contemporary Australian fashion and textiles design' curated by Meredith Rowe.
Undertake an internship at a major New York art museum to further develop professional practice.
Publication of a full colour catalogue and the further development of a website to promote an exhibition by the artist titled `Blinded by the Light' focussing on cinematic encounters with light.
Attendance and participation at the 2002 International Shibori Symposium, Harrowgate, United Kingdom.
Export Marketing Advance 02/03 - Milefire Management for Warped in Japan.
2002 APAM touring: Museum of Modern Oddities (MoMo) to the International Street Theatre Festival, Gent, Belgium, and the Terschellings Oerol Festival, The Netherlands, June-July 2003.
Visual Arts Export Strategy - Art Miami 2003 - Gallery Gabrielle Pizzi.
A contribution towards recording, marketing, promoting and distributing a five track EP.
2002 VACB Emeritus Award recipient, Robert Owen, Vic.
A community writing and visual art project with refugees, which uses stories about important meals as a catalyst for the work.
North Richmond Community Health Centre Inc

Production of a publication and support for an exhibition which will document, celebrate and analyse the diverse cultural strategies used by organisations and arts practitioners working in Melbourne's inner city high rise housing estates.
The production of the `Tramjatra Book' - documenting and examining the CCD processes and effects of the project `Tramjatra'.

The `Iraqi Women's Storytelling Project' will involve newly arrived and refugee Iraqi women in writing and quilt making workshops. A publication of the women's stories and an exhibition of the quilt will inform the wider community of the women's experiences coming to a new country as asylum seekers.

The project aims to develop a secure, stable and sustainable future for Visionary Images by training 2 young people and to develop new project ideas and alternative exhibition sites for future artistic project outcomes.

This grant is a contribution towards the Instrument Building exhibition, workshops, lectures, demonstrations and concerts to be presented at Linden St Kilda Centre for Contemporary Art in Melbourne, between 2 and 14 December 2003.
Towards writers' fees and journal costs for the publication of four issues of `Australian Book Review' in 2003.
Towards writers' fees and journal costs for the publication of four issues of `Voiceworks' in 2003. Voiceworks publishes the work of writers aged 25 and under.
Meanjin Company Limited - University of Melbourne
Towards writers' fees and journal costs for the publication of four issues of `Meanjin' in 2003.
Fares, fees and expenses for Australian writers participating in the 2003 program of the Australian Centre for Youth Literature.
Shortlisted for Yaddo, New York 6-week residency (subject to selection by Yaddo committee).
6-month residency at the B.R. Whiting Library Rome, 1 February - 31 July 2003.
6-month residency at the Keesing Studio Paris, 1 August 2003 - 31 January 2004.
Association of Performing Arts Presenters (APAP) 2003 (Brooklyn Academy of Music Follow Up) Project Manager - Keep Breathing Pty Ltd.
University of Melbourne through Asialink Centre
Asialink Australia-Japan Visual Arts Exhibitions Initiative 2002-2005.
Australian Exposure 02/03 - Sent Rubber Records to Midem 2003 (37th International Music Market).
Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Arts Board
Cultural exchange and research with Middle East for the development of new work looking at the impact of war on young children.
Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Arts Board
Development of Arts Page on ATA Website- to promote Indigenous arts in their existing website.
