Research into the feasibility of establishing a Technology Loan Facility in response to Recommendation 11 of the Myer Report into the Contemporary Visual Arts and Crafts.
Visual Arts Export Strategy - ARCO (Arco Cotemporaneo) 2003 - Participation by Alcaston Gallery.
A contribution to tour Europe, Tokyo and USA by 1200 Techniques from February - March 03.

A two-stage USA tour including the presentation of filmscore shows and band performances in clubs and venues, targeting theatre-programmers and festival directors, 4 to 28 February and 29 March to 1 June 2003.
The presentation of `Variable Resistance: Ten Hours of Sound from Australia', Transmediale Media Arts Festival, Berlin, 1-5 February 2003.
Development of networked audio installation `Summoned Voices' and exhibition of work in Holland.
A tour by ensemble of experimental electronic musicians to Europe, USA and Japan, April-May 2003.

subdebateinfo.title: Bowman Electorate: Work for the Dole Schemes
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1450)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment Services, upon notice, on 12 February 2003:

quote.para: (1) How many people in the electoral division of Bowman participated in Work for the Dole schemes in (a) 1999-2000, (b) 2000-2001 (c) 2001-2002.
(2) In the same years, how many participants went on to find full-time work within (a) 3 months, (b) 6 months, (c) 9 months and (d) 12 months of completing their Work for the Dole projects.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The number of job seekers who commenced in a Work for the Dole activity in Bowman in 1999-2000 was 177, in 2000-01 was 293 and in 2001-02 was 414.
(2) Data is not collected to respond to this question.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 13 February 2003:

quote.para: (1) Does the Minister's Department administer any Commonwealth funded programs for which community organisations, businesses or individuals in the electoral division of Newcastle can apply for funding; if so, what are the programs.

(2) Does the Minister's Department advertise these funding opportunities; if so, (a) what print or other media outlets have been used for the advertising of each of these programs and (b) were these paid advertisements.
(3) With respect to each of the Commonwealth funded programs referred to in part (1), (a) what is its purpose and (b) who is responsible for allocating funds.

(4) With respect to each of the Commonwealth funded programs referred to in part (1), how many (a) community organisations, (b) business or (c) individuals in the electoral division of Newcastle received funding in 2001 and 2002.
(5) What sum of Commonwealth funding did each recipient receive in 2001 and 2002.
(6) What is the name and address of each recipient.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: The Department of Communications, Information Technology and the Arts offers the residents of the electorate of Newcastle a wide range of benefits across both its cultural and information and communications program streams. These various programs are described in this answer so that they correspond with the structure of the department.
(1) Yes, Visions of Australia.
(2) Yes, the funding opportunities are advertised.
(a) Advertisements are placed in major metropolitan papers plus the Koori Mail; Industry journals such as Museums Australia and Art Monthly.
(b) Yes, they are paid advertisements.

(3) (a) The purposes of the Visions of Australia program is to provide all Australians with access to high quality exhibitions of cultural material. It provides grants to cultural and community organisations to develop and tour exhibitions of historical and scientific material visual arts and craft, multimedia and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander culture throughout Australia. Exhibitions should have a predominantly Australian source or theme.

(b) A ten-member committee appointed by the Federal Minister for the Arts and Sport considers applications. The Visions of Australia Committee meets twice a year, after the close of each grant rounds, to consider the applications on a competitive basis against the assessment criteria and in the context of available funds. The Minister approves grants on the recommendation of the Committee. The Department administers the program.
(4) (a) No community organisations in the electoral division of Newcastle received funding in 2001 and 2002.
(b) The Newcastle Region Art Gallery received funding in 2001.
(c) No individuals in the electoral division of Newcastle received funding in 2001 and 2002.
(5) The Newcastle Region Art Gallery received $40,000 in 2001.
(6) Newcastle Region Art Gallery's address is 1 Laman Street Newcastle NSW 2300.
(1) Yes
Playing Australia
Festivals Australia
Contemporary Music Touring Program
(2) Yes

(a) Each program has two grant rounds per year. A paid block advertisement is placed in all major metropolitan dailies, including The Weekend Australian and The Sydney Morning Herald. These advertisements, under the heading of `Cultural Touring Grants' appear either in the early general news section or the arts pages, usually in late May and late October, after the announcement of successful applicants for the previous round.

Festivals Australia rounds are also advertised in more than 60 regional newspapers, 21 of them in New South Wales, including the Newcastle Herald and the Maitland Mercury. This program is also advertised in the NSW & ACT, Special Events Directory. Advertisements are also placed in a number of local government publications on an ad hoc basis.
Additional advertisements for the Contemporary Music Touring Program are placed in a selection of `street press' and music industry journals.

Information on all programs is accessible of the Department of Communications, Information Technology and the Arts website. State and Territory arts ministries, and Regional Arts Organisations, provide information on the programs via their own publications and/or via website links.
(b) Newspaper advertising is paid advertising. Some local government publication advertising is free, as is website information.

(3) (a) Playing Australia is the Commonwealth Government's National Performing Arts Touring Program. It is designed to assist the touring of performing arts across State and Territory boundaries where this is currently not commercially viable and there is a demonstrated public demand.

Festivals Australia is a funding program designed to assist the presentation of arts and cultural activities at Australian regional and community festivals. The emphasis is on supporting projects which adds to the quality and diversity of the arts and cultural programming of a festival.

The Contemporary Music Touring Program aims to develop viable touring opportunities within Australia for Australian musicians, and to increase audience access to live Australian contemporary music, particularly in rural and regional Australia.

(b) Expert technical committees, broadly representative of the sector, make recommendations after assessing applications in each round. These are forwarded to the Minister for the Arts and Sport for consideration and approval.
(4) (a) Two community organisations received funding in 2001 and 2002.
(b) No businesses received funding in 2001 and 2002.
(c) No individuals received funding in 2001 and 2002.
(5) This Is Not Art received $10,000 under the Festivals Australia program in 2002.
Cultures in Actions received $4,000 under the Festivals Australia program in 2002.
(6) This Is Not Art
3/231 King Street
NEWCASTLE NSW 2300
Cultures in Action
PO Box 522
NEWCASTLE WEST NSW 2302
(1) Yes.

In the past, community organisations could apply for funding through the Commonwealth Networking the Nation (NTN) program (although individuals and for-profit businesses were not eligible NTN applicants.) These funds have now all been allocated.

(2) Over the life of the NTN Program the advertising requirements changed. As more applications were received, the need for promotional advertising has been reduced. In those States where NTN funds were fully committed (this includes NSW), the Program was not promoted.

(a) Advertisements for the NTN Program have in the past been placed in a range of newspapers including “The Australian”, “The Broken Hill Barrier Truth”, “Bourke Western Herald”, “The Land” and the “Koori Times”. There were a number of advertisements placed in specialist publications including the “Australian Local Government Association Yearbook” and the “NT Cattleman's Association Yearbook”. In addition, the Program was promoted on the DCITA Website, presentations at conferences, newsletters and directly with State Governments.
(b) The NTN Program has promoted the program through a number of media outlets using a mixture of paid and unpaid advertisements.
(3) (a) The objective of Networking the Nation Program is to assist the economic and social development of regional, rural and remote Australia by funding projects which:
· enhance telecommunications infrastructure and services in regional, rural and remote areas;
· increase access to, and promote use of, services available thruogh telecommunications networks in regional, rural and remote areas; or
· reduce disparities in access to such services and facilities between Australians in regional, rural or remote areas and those in urban areas.
`Regional, rural and remote areas' are any areas located outside the capital city of each State or Territory.
(b) The NTN Board approves funding, which is then released in instalments through funding Deeds administered between recipients and the NTN Secretariat in Canberra.

(4) (a) Five NTN projects were managed by community organisations based in the electoral division of Newcastle. All of these projects benefited the broader Hunter region, including the electoral division of Newcastle. No NTN projects benefited only the electoral division of Newcastle.
(b) No businesses received funding.
(c) No individuals received funding.
(5) The only payment in either 2001 or 2002 to the Hunter Telemedicine project was the final instalment of $26,400 in February 2002 out of the total project funding of $864,628.
The only payment in either 2001 or 2002 to the Hunter Tourism E-Commerce project was the final instalment of $14,000 in June 2001 out of the total project funding of $304,000.
The only payment in either 2001 or 2002 to the Hunter Internet Access Exchange project was the final instalment of $3,000 in February 2001 out of the total project funding of $21,000.
Payments to the Hunter Region Online project totalled $160,000 in 2001 and $50,000 in 2002, as the final instalments of the total project funding of $400,000.
Payments to the Networking the Hunter IT Coordinator project totalled $40,000 in 2001 and $2,500 in 2002, as the final instalments of the total project funding of $90,000.
The recipient for the Hunter Telemedicine project was the Hunter Area Health Service, which had the registered address of Lookout Road, NEW LAMBTON NSW 2305.
(6) The recipient for the Hunter Tourism E-Commerce project was the Hunter Regional Tourism Organisation, which had the registered address of Level 1, 45 Hunter Street, NEWCASTLE NSW 2300.
The recipient for the Hunter Internet Access Exchange project was the Hunter Internet Access Exchange, which had the registered address of Unit 2, 80 Grinsell Street, KOTARA NSW 2289.
The recipient for the Hunter Region Online project was the Newcastle & Hunter Business Chamber, which had the registered address of 475 Hunter Street, NEWCASTLE NSW 2302.
The recipient for the Networking the Hunter IT Coordinator project was the Hunter Economic Development Corporation, which had the registered address of Level 3, 251 Wharf Road, NEWCASTLE NSW 2300.

para.inline: Telecommunications Consumer Representation and Research Grants

quote.para: (1) Yes.
The Department administers the Telecommunications Consumer Representation and Research Grants. These grants are administered under Section 593 of the Telecommunications Act 1997.
(2) Yes.
(a) The Grants are advertised annually, usually in March, in the major metropolitan newspapers.
(b) They are paid advertisements.

(3) (a) The Consumer Representation grants are provided to consumer bodies for the purpose of representation of the interests of consumers in relation to telecommunications issues. The Research grants are provided to individuals or a body for purposes in connection with research into the social, economic, environmental or technological implications of developments relating to telecommunications.
(b) The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts.
(4) (a) No grants were made to community organisations in the electoral division of Newcastle in 2001 and 2002.
(b) No grants were made to businesses in the electoral division of Newcastle in 2001 and 2002.
(c) No grants were made to individuals in the electoral division of Newcastle in 2001 and 2002.
(5) Not Applicable.
(6) Not Applicable.
(1) Yes.
Television Black Spots Program (TVBSP).
(2) Yes.

(a) The TVBSP was initially advertised after Round 1 was announced on 21 June 2000, with advertisements placed in two national papers and 34 regional papers across the country. Information kits were sent to 642 local shires and councils at that time inviting all local governments to apply for funding under the Program. The Program was also widely advertised following the announcement of Round 2 on 1 November 2000, with advertisements placed in three national and 75 regional newspapers. Revised information kits were also sent to the 642 local shires and councils at that time. A final round of `reminder' advertising followed in February 2001, with advertisements placed in the Weekend Australian and 65 regional newspapers.
(b) These were paid advertisements.

(3) (a) The Federal Government, in recognising the difficulties that some communities, particularly those outside of capital cities, were having in getting access to free-to-air television services, established the $35 million TVBSP, which is one component of the $120 million Television Fund, funded from the sale of the second tranche of Telstra. The TVBSP aims to assist communities to fix between 200-250 television black spots by funding the capital cost of `self-help' analog retransmission facilities (up to $25,000 per television service, including up to $2,000 to cover the cost of the technical survey, and up to $25,000 for site establishment costs).

(b) All communities across Australia were eligible to apply for funding under the TVBSP. All applicants that applied under the TVBSP and met the Program's Guidelines were eligible for funding. The Minister is responsible for approving recommendations for funding made by the TV Fund Unit in the Department of Communications, Information Technology and the Arts.
(4) (a) No applications were received under the TVBSP for the electorate of Newcastle.
(b) No applications from businesses were received under the TVBSP for the electorate of Newcastle.
(c) No applications from individuals were received under the TVBSP for the electorate of Newcastle.
(5) Not Applicable.
(6) Not Applicable.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 4 March 2003:

quote.para: (1) Will the Minister provide details, by electorate, listing which areas have received funds from the Television Black Spots Program.
(2) How much of the money allocated under the Television Black Spots Program has been spent.
(3) Which areas in Western Australia have received funds from rounds 1 or 2 of the Television Black Spots Program.
(4) What percentage of the Television Black Spots Program funding was allocated to the capital cities.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) 62 electorates covering 464 black spot areas have received funds from the Television Black Spots Program (TVBSP) - see Table A.
(2) To date, $14.3 million of the $35 million allocated has been spent under the TVBSP.
(3) In Western Australia, 50 black spot areas have received funds under the TVBSP - see Table B.

(4) The TVBSP is a needs-based program, relying on applications from communities with poor television reception, and therefore there was no specific allocation to any electorate, state or capital city. Eligible metropolitan applications were received from East Perth in Western Australia, Geelong and Monbulk in Victoria, and Wollongong and Woronora in New South Wales.
